The major indexes made piecemeal moves in afternoon trading Wednesday, but techs continued to lead the way higher with just three more trading sessions left in March.Cisco Systems (CSCO) is taking a breather, falling nearly 0.7% to 33.76 in light volume and hampering efforts of the Dow Jones industrial average to rally. The 30-member Dow is down roughly 0.2%, while the Nasdaq composite and the tech-rich Nasdaq 100 are both up about 0.3%. The S&P 500 inched slightly higher and is just above 2360.Cisco shares, however, are still up more than 5% past a recent flat-base entry at 31.99. It's been featured frequently in IBD's Income Investor column, which highlights companies that have excellent earnings stability, a minimum 2% annualized yield, and decent relative strength.Cisco, the greatest stock market winner of the 1990s as it literally built the plumbing of the world wide web, no longer has the same growth characteristics as it did when it initially cleared a double-bottom base as a small-cap growth leader right after the stock market bottomed in October 1990. Now, with a $169 billion market cap and a 3.4% annualized dividend yield, the Silicon Valley stalwart in data networking routers, switches and other communications gear has been busy battling new upstarts including Arista Networks (ANET), currently ranked No. 1 in the IBD 50.Arista, embroiled in a technology patent court battle with Cisco, is down nearly 0.7% to 133.00, but volume is quiet and the stock's uptrend is firmly intact since its breakout past a 75.50 cup-shaped pattern in the week ended Aug. 12, 2016.That cup helped put the finishing touches on a long bottoming base pattern, seen among many current stock market leaders today. Arista went public in June 2014 at 43 and quickly ramped up to 94.84, then went into a deep freeze for nearly two years before finally building that first-stage cup pattern and eventually breaking out to 52-week highs.Arista has grown earnings per share 54%, 47%, 51%, 36%, 37%, 41% and 30% vs. year-ago levels over the past seven quarters. That amazing track record of profit growth is one reason why the Santa Clara, Calif., firm holds a 98 EPS Rating from IBD Stock Checkup.Revenue rose 33% to 42% over that same time frame. Wall Street sees FY 2017 earnings growth slowing, up 14% to $3.77 a share.As noted in a recent Big Picture column, while policy at the federal government level can certainly spur entrepreneurship and risk-taking, it's the innovative companies themselves that are the true engines of economic growth and job creation. Look for those companies that have outstanding products and services, rock-solid management, and stocks that have the ability to power to new highs and rise above their 10-week moving averages.All of these factors go into IBD's seven-point CAN SLIM investment paradigm, noted by AAII as the top investment strategy for stocks across multiple time periods going back to the late 1990s.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which has redefined the way people shop for cosmetics, hair and skin care products and services, has made a terrific move since clearing a three-month cup at 188.58 back on March 11, 2016.Ulta today gained 0.57 to 283.43 and is currently in the proper buy zone, up 3% past a 274.09 entry in a double-bottom-with-handle base. Shares broke out of the slightly warped-looking pattern in early February in light volume. Both the advance and volume picked up steam on March 10, a day after Ulta reported a 33% jump in fiscal Q4 earnings per share and a 25% rise in revenue to $1.58 billion.That matched the biggest year-over-year top-line increase in 16 quarters.The top-performing specialty retailer is expected to see strong double-digit EPS growth during the next two fiscal years (up 24% in FY 2018 to $8.07 a share, up 21% in FY 2019). In tech land, NetEase (NTES) also deserves continued watch. The Chinese giant in online video games is basing after rising past a 257.78 cup-with-narrow-handle entry. Watch for potential support at the 10-week line.Symantec (SYMC) is staging a stunning turnaround, not just in stock price but also in profits. The stock, up more than 1% to 30.84, has shot 19% past a 25.82 flat-base entry.Wall Street sees earnings rising 14% to $1.19 a share in FY 2017, which ends this month, then galloping 47% higher to $1.75 a share in FY 2018. Industry peer Fortinet (FTNT) rose 4% to 38.08 in above-average turnover.The stock joined IBD's new SwingTrader premium service as one with potential to make a strong move over a period of several days to potentially a few weeks.Finally, digital marketing and imaging software leader Adobe Systems (ADBE) continues to thrive, edging up for a sixth straight session to 129.21. The San Jose, Calif., firm cleared a 107.90 entry in a shallow double-bottom base with handle in early January and has climbed as much as 19%.Adobe gets a solid 95 Composite Rating from IBD Stock Checkup on a scale of 1 to 99. Wall Street sees profit rising 31% to $3.95 a share in FY 2017, ending in November, and another 26% to $4.99 a share in FY 2018.RELATED:Stock Market Today I: Can Snap Finish A First-Stage Base?Stock Market Today II: 5 Solid Big Cap Names For 2017How To Invest: The Elements Of A Bottoming Base PatternHow To Invest: How To Find An Outstanding Cup-With-Handle Base

Look up "sad mall" or "dead mall" online and you're likely to be confronted with images of desolate, shuttered shopping centers that have been left for dead. Overgrown plants crack through abandoned storefronts; crumbled tile litters broken-down escalators. It's a common-enough phenomenon that entire photography projects revolve around the state of the country's retail centers.Is this what 2017 holds for American shoppers?Not quite, but the upcoming year isn't exactly going to be a cakewalk, either. The hundreds of collective store closures (from Macy's (M), Wal-Mart (WMT) and others, combined) and bankruptcies (Sports Authority, Sports Chalet) in 2016 are enough to make even the most devoted shopaholic wonder if the future of commerce is one big Amazon.com (AMZN) screen."It's going to be a year of transition and a year of reckoning and a year of awakening for retailers," said Marshal Cohen, NPD Group's chief industry analyst.Retail sales excluding autos and gasoline rose 4% from Nov. 1 to Dec. 24, according to MasterCard's SpendingPulse. That suggests a stronger-than-expected holiday season, perhaps reflecting more optimistic consumers. But while digital sales continued to boom, with Amazon grabbing an ever-larger e-commerce share, brick-and-mortar locations faced declining traffic. And those trends are likely to intensify into the new year.The big discounts offered at apparel stores this holiday season echoed prior sales-heavy years, particularly 2015's. While retailers generally went into this important shopping period claiming that inventories were lean, stores feel they have no choice in an already cutthroat environment."Consumers have been trained that if they hold out, they will get a promotion," said Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar. "The other problem is that it's a really overcrowded space with no barriers to entry. A lot of retailers are choosing to compete on price."IBD'S TAKE: What's holding Amazon back from becoming a major player in beauty? For an in-depth look, read: "Why Amazon Has Been Powerless Against Beauty Stores."Retail Metrics President Ken Perkins said that outside of a few busy hours on the weekends, Holiday 2016 was "somewhat eerily quiet" at the mall.During store checks, his research firm observed but a "handful of people" at Foot Locker (FL), Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) brand Hollister, American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Macy's. L Brands' (LB) Bath & Body Works "always seems to have a buzz," he said, but even Apple (AAPL) stores seemed less bustling than in years' past."Each year it feels like that lull is a bit deeper and deeper," said Perkins.Some of the lag can be attributed to holiday promotions being pushed up earlier in November, said NPD's Cohen, spreading out the spending. But the perhaps greater problem is the lack of product innovation and uniqueness on shelves, he said.In other words, there's not enough new, fun stuff to buy — for other people or for self-gifting purposes.NPD, which tracks the November-December shopping period week by week, said in its latest report that as of the week ending Dec. 10, dollar sales in the first six weeks of the holiday retail season were lagging the prior-year period by 4%.Brick-and-mortar traffic fell about 10% at stores through Dec. 17, according to Prodco Retail Traffic Index.One saving grace for brick-and-mortar locations: Christmas Eve — also the start of Hanukkah this year — was on a Saturday, while Dec. 26 was also a day off.The issues that faced retailers in 2016 are likely to continue to face them in 2017, without much abatement. Perkins highlighted the ongoing shift to online and mobile spending, a consumer taste for experiences instead of products, high promotional activity and a "hollowing out" of the middle class that leaves less disposable income on the table.And, of course, Amazon's insistent gains. On top of Prime shipping and Prime Video, the company's smart-home device, Alexa, can help Prime members place orders."(Alexa) cuts retailer out of the equation for consumers that are pressed for time," he said.Upper-tier malls — the kind that house Tiffanys (TIF) and Louis Vuittons and Shake Shacks (SHAK) — are expected to continue to perform well enough. But the average mall might still see some individual stores close up shop, say experts, unless they go out of their way to attract more foot traffic."Mid-tier malls are going to need to step up their game" with restaurants, movie theaters and lifestyle stores, said NPD's Cohen, adding that "the food court won't be good enough."Simon Property Group (SPG), a major mall operator, has tumbled 24% over the last five months, sinking Wednesday to the lowest level in nearly 16 months.That young people are doing more mobile shopping and are craving experiences is no surprise. But how retailers respond may foreshadow the brick-and-mortar industry's fate.Wal-Mart (WMT) investments (which include its e-commerce efforts) may weigh on short-term income growth but lead to foreseeable rewards in the future, said Perkins, whose store checks found that Wal-Mart has been "one of the busier stores" this season.In 2017, the top-performers list should feature some familiar names, by Perkins' estimate. Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's (LOW) are "two of the strongest performers in retail." He also sees off-price trio TJX (TJX), Ross Stores (ROST) and Burlington (BURL) continuing to do well, as well as Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which is "obviously a standout player."Home improvement, off-price and beauty all involve some element of in-store necessity: looking for just the right part, digging through bargain racks and trying on new makeup brands are usually best done in person.Department stores have had a choppy year, though Nordstrom (JWN) frequently gets a shout-out from analysts for being an "omnichannel" retailer that knows how to engage its customers across platforms. And unlike Macy's or Kohl's (KSS), which compete "with Amazon and everyone else on the internet," says Morningstar's Weishaar, Nordstrom has differentiated itself by catering to more affluent shoppers with a highly curated selection."If you go to Amazon and type in 'red dress,' you're going to get literally hundreds of pages of results to sift through that (are) not useful," she said. "If you go to Nordstrom, you're going to get 10 (products in line with) your price points and brands."Even so, Nordstrom was recently handed a downgrade from JPMorgan after the department store's management team said brick-and-mortar levels hadn't been that bad since 1972.In the future, being omnichannel might not be enough, particularly in a world increasingly populated by Alexa and Google Home devices.Retail "omnipresence" is key, said NPD's Cohen.That is, instead of simply giving customers a way to buy products both in-store and online, it would behoove retailers to latch onto shoppers before, during and after the transaction, he said. Educate them and anticipate their needs ahead of potential transactions, allow them different ways to buy, then stay in touch via product reviews or other methods following the purchase.The goal, said Cohen, is "that the store becomes the epicenter for the entire process."RELATED:Amazon's Top Selling Holiday Products Came From ... Tesla surged over 3% after Piper Jaffray upgraded the electric automaker to overweight from neutral, while raising its price target to 368 from 223. Alibaba, a recent addition to Leaderboard, jumped almost 2% and is now extended from a 104.67 cup-with-handle entry. On Monday, though, it cleared a three-weeks-tight buy point of 110.55.Among other analyst actions, Amazon (AMZN) moved up 1.1% after Needham upgraded the e-commerce giant to buy from hold, expecting continued online retail dominance. Shares are holding up nicely after a strong rebound from the 50-day. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) advanced 0.6% after Loop Capital upgraded the beauty products retailer to buy from hold, while boosting its price target to 350 from 285.Netflix (NFLX) dropped 0.9% amid senior executive changes as shares fell under the 50-day for the second time since a Jan. 4 cup-with-handle breakout. Two weeks ago, the stock fell under the 50-day only to recover into positive territory at the close. The video streaming giant will report its Q1 earnings next Monday after the close.Among stocks breaking out, JD.com (JD) cruised past a 32.57 flat-base buy point as shares rallied 2.5% higher. The Chinese retailer is 13% above a 29.01 cup-with-handle entry. Apple supplier Cirrus Logic (CRUS) fell 0.4% in midday trading as the stock followed up on Friday's breakout above a 64.26 cup-base buy point.Action within the IBD 50 was mixed in midday trading. On the upside, BioTelemetry (BEAT) soared 12% after entering into an agreement to acquire LifeWatch AG, a Swiss-based company that supplies cardiac monitoring products. China-based Momo (MOMO) jumped 6.9%. Shares are back at new highs, 56% above a 23.96 cup-with-handle buy point.On the downside, chip leader Nvidia (NVDA) continued its string of declines as shares dropped near 2%. Small caps outperformed with the Russell 2000 rallying 0.9%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. the same time Friday.Truckers, automakers and generic drug issues were among the biggest gainers in early trade. Gold miners, steel and utilities lagged.Caterpillar, up nearly 2% in heavy trade, led the Dow in today's stock market action. Shares continue to build the right side of a flat base and are 3% below a 99.56 buy point.Chevron added 1% as it moves off the bottom of a flat base with a potential entry at 119.10. West Texas intermediate crude prices were up 1% at $52.75 a barrel.Apple climbed 0.3%, stemming a three-session slide. Shares remain in buy range from a 141.12 four-weeks-tight buy point.Tesla motored more than 3% higher in rapid volume, hitting an all-time high. The stock is now extended past a 287.49 buy point. Piper Jaffray upgraded the electric car maker to overweight from neutral and boosted its price target to 368 from 223.Knight Transportation (KNX) and Swift Transportation (SWFT) gapped up and soared 16% and 24%, respectively, in heavy turnover. European health care company Fresenius Medical (FMS) is mulling a bid for Akorn, according to a Bloomberg report late last week.In the IBD 50, BioTelemetry (BEAT) gapped up and rose 14% in active trade. XStocks tiptoed to modest gains in lighter trade on Thursday amid investors' multiple concerns that range from talks between President Trump and China's Xi Jinping, news that the Federal Reserve is getting ready to deleverage its monster balance sheet of debt, and the ongoing nuclear threat from North Korea.The Dow Jones industrial average edged up about 15 points, less than 0.1%, to 20,662. The Nasdaq composite outperformed, rising nearly 0.3%. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%.Small caps outperformed by a mile. The Russell 2000 gained 0.9%, helped in part by a rebound among smaller banks after the Federal Reserve signaled that it's getting more committed to a tighter monetary policy and lightening the debt load on its balance sheet later this year.These future monetary actions are likely to keep interest rates on an upward path, which could boost profit margins for many lenders. In March, the U.S. central bank pushed the fed funds rate up by 25 basis points to a target range of 0.75%-1%.Currently, the top 20 industry groups are dominated by the computer technology, finance, building and medical sectors. Just one hails from the defensive utility sector, gas distributors.Among these top-ranking groups, steel, superregional banks, mortgage services, scientific and measuring equipment, education, and integrated computer systems enjoyed the biggest gains, up 1% or more.While the financial media and talking heads have sounded plenty of worries about the risk of a serious trade war that would hurt the global economy, IBD's screens are seeing continued fine action by a number of stocks that are showing good relative strength and may see robust or increasing demand for their products going forward.Celgene (CELG) draws the majority of its revenue, $11.2 billion in 2016, from North America and Europe. The developer of therapies to battle cancers and immunological disease is trading tightly lately, but holding above a 122.49 buy point in a somewhat choppy cup base. That base formed after Celgene shares popped up big on Nov. 9, then stalled.Even during the Great Recession, demand for excellent medicines was so fierce that Celgene's revenue still grew 19% in 2009 and in the double digits every year since then. In 2009, earnings per share rose 33% to $1.04 a share.Wall Street sees Celgene's earnings jumping 22% this year to $7.22 a share, then 21% to $8.77 in 2018.Keep watching the stock's weekly chart. A new handle has formed, creating a potential breakout point at 127.74, or 10 cents above the March 17 intraday high.Caterpillar (CAT) is not in one of the top 20 groups, but increased construction activity in the U.S. and the rest of the world provides a bullish backdrop for the construction and mining equipment giant.The Dow 30 component, aided by bullish comments from Goldman Sachs earlier this week, rose for a third straight session and gained nearly 2% to 95.69 in thin volume. More importantly, the stock regained the north side of its 50-day moving average.Cat's profits have withered since hitting a peak in 2012. But the Street sees earnings rebounding in a big way in 2018, rising 41% to $4.45 a share after an expected 8% dip this year.In the IBD 50, these three names also likely would suffer less from a future trade spat and retaliatory measures taken by either the U.S. or China due to incredible demand for their products. Priceline Group (PCLN), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Arista Networks (ANET) have all done well so far in 2017 by fueling the needs of travelers, beauty-conscious women and companies that rely on fast data networks to run their businesses.Priceline is extended since clearing resistance near 1,393 with a nifty gap up in heavy volume on Aug. 5. Notice how the stock has hugged its 50-day line most of the way up.The inventor of name-your-price rates for hotel room reservations has branched into new fields such as private car rentals and restaurant reservations. These investments have paid off: Revenue grew 17%, 12%, 19% and 17% vs. year-ago levels in the past four quarters. Earnings per share rose 30%, 12%, 23% and 32%.Go to IBD 50 to see the latest concise chart analysis and potential buy and sell points for Ulta and Arista as well as the rest of the IBD 50.A few new IPOs are cooling off. Snap (SNAP) briefly touched the 20 level. China is unlikely to become a target market and it already has some highly popular social media sites. The Snapchat operator has a more pressing issue: finding a way to turn its big sales growth in healthy earnings.Snap is expected to lose 53 cents a share this year and 33 cents in 2018.Adient (ADNT), a car supplier, bounced off intraday lows and rose 0.2% to 66.68 in fast turnover. Watch to see if it can rebound back above the critical 50-day moving average and keep its uptrend intact.The car seat specialist debuted on the NYSE in October and immediately formed a narrow IPO base with a 48.30 entry. Shares rolled past that buy point during a three-day spurt that began on Nov. 15, just days after the Trump surprise election win.RELATED:Can These 6 Growth Stocks Turn Into The Next Cisco Systems Of This Decade?The Income Investor: Can This Hot Chipmaker Keep Its Uptrend Going?How To Win In Stocks: First, Invest Time In Understanding The Logic Behind The Cup With Handle

The key indexes traded mixed but generally showed mild action in late trading Monday, just ahead of a pivotal two-day meeting by the U.S. central bank on monetary policy.While the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%, the Nasdaq composite gained 0.2% while the S&P 500 was virtually flat. None of the 30 components in the Dow industrials are up more than 1 point, but building sector play Home DepotHD padded its recent gains, rising 0.5% to 147.59. Shares are now up 7% past a 137.42 buy point within a shallow saucer-with-handle base.The Nasdaq is up despite a 2.2% drop by Intel (INTC) on news that it's paying up big for self-driving tech firm Mobileye (MBLY).The Russell 2000 edged up 0.3%. The Nasdaq 100, comprising 100 of the largest nonfinancial companies in the all-electronic stock exchange, got a 0.1% boost, in part courtesy of Apple (AAPL), which is also a component of the Dow Jones industrial average. Shares in the largest company by market cap (now at $731 billion) rose 0.1% to 139.32, holding near its all-time peak of 140.28.Currently, Apple has risen 20.3% since Jan. 1, a stellar start in 2017 after a rebuilding year in 2016. Last year, Apple finally bottomed out after a long correction from its then peak of 134.54, then cleared buy points in two cup-with-handle patterns.From the first breakout at 110.33, the iPhone giant has now gained as much as 27%, a good time to take profits. However, those with strong conviction may decide to hold longer and see if the consumer electronics hardware and services play can rise 30% to 40% before undergoing a serious correction.Meanwhile, several companies within the IBD 50 are holding their own and may catch up with or even exceed Apple's brilliant start.Advanced Energy Industries (AEIS)is up 22.6% year-to-date, and shares gushed nearly 4% higher to 67.12 in the stock market today, clearing a narrow, tight consolidation. Aggressive investors or long-term holders could have bought when the stock move past the 63.75 high within this tight trading pattern.Shares are now 5% past a 63.85 buy point. Looking at a daily chart, the recent tight trading is long enough to meet the five-week (or 25 days) time requirement for a flat base. What makes Advanced Energy's flat base unusual, however, is the fact that both the high and the low of the pattern is in the same session of trading, on Jan. 31.Advanced Energy is a small-cap name in IBD's semiconductor equipment industry group, and that group is currently No. 1 in the latest IBD Weekly.The company is enjoying a fine turnaround profits-wise. Earnings dropped 50% in the fourth quarter of 2015, then another 14% in Q1 of 2016. But after that, earnings rose 16%, 28% and 231% in the three most recent quarters.Sales have taken a similar path, falling 21% and 6%, then accelerating to gains of 9%, 15% and 56%. In Q4 of last year, revenue hit $135.3 million, the biggest in 12 quarters.Advanced Energy is No. 4 in the IBD 50.Also in the IBD 50, cosmetics and skin care retailing giant Ulta Beauty (ULTA) (No. 30 in the 50) added to Friday's monster gain, up 0.4% to 287.54. Ulta has had a huge run since the March 2009 market bottom. It's up 12.6% year to date.Last week, Ulta reported another quarter of solid double-digit earnings and revenue growth. The 33% spike in Q4 earnings per share and 25% gain in revenue also marked a second quarter of mild growth acceleration.The Street sees Q1 numbers to continue Ulta's double-digit increases with profit expected to rise 24% to $1.80 a share on a 19% lift in revenue to $1.27 billion.Dave & Buster's (PLAY) sank 1.4% to 58.79, yet remains above a recent 58.35 buy point in a narrow flat base. Shares are up just 4.2% year-to-date. The casual dining and arcade chain is No. 22 in the IBD 50. Marvell Technology (MRVL), not in the IBD 50 but a member of IBD Leaderboard, pulled back 1% after stroking new highs. Shares in the turnaround chip play for high-speed data networking are up nearly 17% since Jan. 1.RELATED:These Three Leading Stocks Show Bullish Action Ahead Of Fed MeetingInside The IBD 50: Why The Banks Cannot Be IgnoredHow To Invest I: Is Too Much Bullishness Always A Bad Thing?How To Invest II: Why The Shakeout + 3 Pattern Makes MoneyHow To Invest III: Why You Need Patience To Win Big With The Saucer Base

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) saw its IBD SmartSelect Composite Rating rise to 96 Tuesday, up from 94 the day before.The revised score means the stock currently tops 96% of all other stocks in terms of key performance metrics and technical strength. The best stocks tend to have a 95 or better grade as they begin to launch a significant move.Ulta Beauty is currently forming a flat base, with a 274.09 entry. Look for the stock to break out in heavy trade at least 40% higher than normal.The stock sports a 98 EPS Rating, which means its recent quarterly and annual earnings growth tops 98% of all stocks.Its Accumulation/Distribution Rating of B- shows moderate buying by institutional investors over the last 13 weeks.The company reported a 33% earnings-per-share gain for Q4. That means it's now generated 2 straight quarters of rising EPS gains. Top line growth increased 25%, up from 24% in the prior report. The company has now posted accelerating growth in each of the last 2 quarters.Ulta Beauty holds the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Retail-Specialty industry group. Luxottica (LUX) and Sothebys (BID) are also among the group's highest-rated stocks.RELATED:Stocks Mixed; Can These 3 IBD 50 Names Keep Up With Apple?

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) delivered another Street-topping quarter late Thursday, one that marked a second consecutive period of accelerating profit and sales growth. The specialty beauty retailer's same-store sales growth of 16.6% is practically unheard of in this lukewarm retail environment.Yet Ulta Beauty tumbled in after-hours trading Thursday and fell at Friday's open to test its 50-day moving average before soon reversing higher. Shares finished 4.6% higher at 286.42 trade after setting an all-time high of 285.92 in the stock market today. Ulta is back in buy range from a 274.09 buy point, but this is the first time it's crossing that entry area in heavy volume.So what gives? Was that overnight selling a sign that investors are getting nervous about this retail outperformer's stamina?Guidance was soft, for one. For 2017, Ulta said it expects "low twenties percentage range" profit growth, below current analyst expectations for 26% gains in per-share earnings. First-quarter outlook of $1.75-$1.80 EPS on $1.244 billion-$1.265 billion also came in light vs. views for $1.80 a share and $1.273 billion in revenue.But longtime followers of Ulta know that management has historically provided conservative guidance."ULTA has beaten its sales guidance in all but one quarter since 1Q10 as one of the best guiders we cover," wrote Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel. "We expect this to prove conservative yet again."Another cause for concern late Thursday? A miss on gross margin estimates. Ulta's gross profit fell by 10 basis points from the prior year quarter, short of forecasts for a 40 basis point gain, "as management called out tough compares against reduced promos (last year) and ongoing fixed cost investments," according to Wells Fargo's Ike Boruchow.He added that while Ulta's quarter was "clearly a standout in retail today," the gross margin miss was "a little surprising," since it was the first quarter in two years that the company's gross margin did not expand. Boruchow maintained a market perform rating on the stock and raised full-year earnings estimates.But analysts don't seem particularly worried by the gross margin miss. Piper Jaffray's Stephanie Wissink, who rates Ulta overweight, said this was "less of a concern given the favorable dollar contribution of lower margin rate prestige brands."Additionally, Wissink pointed to Ulta's 63.4% e-commerce growth, which points to improved logistics and fulfillment, in her view, boosted by distribution-center investments, inventory management and quick order-turnaround times.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon.com is a formidable foe for retailers, but it lacks a satisfying in-store experience and other "It" factors that cosmetics shoppers want. Lackluster foot traffic and e-commerce giant Amazon.com (AMZN) have weighed heavily on department stores like Macy's (M) and specialty apparel retailers.But Ulta's online sales now account for 9.8% of total sales, as of Q4, even as retail same-store sales rose 12.8%, bucking a retail earnings season littered with strong online numbers but weak or declining in-store comps.Management expects total comparable sales to rise 9%-11% in the current quarter and 8%-10% for the year.That has many looking sunnily on the stock."Although we fully understand setups & sentiment, a (high single-digit to low double-digit) traffic-driven comp guide from a perpetually conservative management seems like a win in this environment of brick & mortar pain," wrote Instinet's Siegel, who has a buy rating on Ulta.Separately, value cosmetics maker e.l.f. Beauty (ELF) closed down 2.5%, ending above its 50-day line after undercutting that support level earlier. On Thursday, e.l.f. shot up 12.3% on strong earnings and guidance, though the stock closed well off its session high.RELATED:Ulta Beauty Earnings, Sales Strong, But Guidance Isn't Pretty

U.S. stock indexes tacked on minor gains midday Friday, as volume appeared poised to fall on the Nasdaq for the first time all week.The Nasdaq added 0.2%, while the S&P 500 echoed the gain. The small cap Russell 2000 led with a 0.4% gain and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average was flat. Volume in the stock market today fell sharply across the board.Winners and losers were mixed, with the postelection uptrend looking tired. In the IBD 50, banks and financials were mostly down. Technology stocks, which were hammered Thursday, had some rebounds but others scored some additional losses. Among stocks attracting heavy volume, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) dropped about 1%.After Thursday's close, the company delivered a three-sided beat. Results topped views on earnings, revenue and guidance.One possible reason for the stock-price drop might have nothing to do with Ulta or its earnings. The Retail-Specialty group is a laggard, rating No. 148 among 197 industry groups. For a stock to advance, a tailwind from its group is a critical component. Lone-wolf winners exist but are rare.Blue chips were mostly up, but the gains were generally small. The day's biggest pop on the Dow belonged to United Technologies (UTX), up 1% in slow trade. The Dow's biggest loser was Goldman Sachs (GS), down 1.7% in heavy volume.Goldman was in for some profit-taking. The big-cap financial booked weekly gains of 16%, 3%, 0.5% and was headed for a 5% weekly gain Friday. The stock is extended and nowhere near a valid buy point.West Texas intermediate crude oil was quiet for a change, holding above $52 a barrel.RELATED:Is More Growth Ahead For Ollie's Bargain Outlet?The Case For A Donald Trump Era Secular Bull Market

Ulta Beauty's (ULTA) beat-and-raise quarter and whopping 16.7% same-store sales growth make the specialty shop something of a unicorn in the rather uncertain world of retail. What's driving growth? Good investments by management plus a broad consumer enthusiasm for beauty products, say the experts."ULTA's multi-year investment spend is clearly generating positive results (improved ecommerce, targeted marketing, product mix, in-store experience, new planning/forecasting systems) as the concept continues to attract new customers to the box," wrote Wells Fargo analyst Ike Boruchow, who rates the stock market perform.Ulta shares shot up to 273.90 soon after the opening bell, clearing a 268.88 buy point briefly. But the stock reversed to trade down as low as 244.75, finding support at the 50-day line. Ulta closed down 1.6% at 253.39 in the stock market today. It wasn't clear why Ulta reversed lower.Something similar happened after its Q2 earnings report, when Ulta delivered strong results but shares tumbled 6% the following day and continued to slide for the next few weeks. But with that report, Q3 guidance was a little cautious. That was not the case with Ulta's Thursday report, which included a solid Q4 outlook.Q3 comps were driven by both transaction (11.1%) and average ticket growth (5.6%). Retail comps rose 14.3%, including 10.3% salon comps.The in-house salons and makeup services "keep Ulta 'un-Amazon-able,' " wrote Cowen's Oliver Chen, who believes that its service offering "continues to become more compelling," particularly with the addition of online booking. He has an outperform rating on Ulta.While Amazon.com (AMZN) threatens to devour other retailers whole, Ulta's e-commerce sales rose 59.1% during the quarter.IBD's TAKE: What's holding Amazon back from eating into Sephora and Ulta's market share? For an in-depth look, read: "Why Amazon Has Been Powerless Against Beauty Stores."Beauty has been pegged, for now, as an Amazon-proof market. The experiential nature of cosmetics and skin care products means that shoppers like to see and try items in person, bringing foot traffic into brick-and-mortar locations. (Plus, the in-store experience is designed to be engaging — look at the product-tester playground that is Sephora.)Ulta's rewards program grew 28% to 21.7 million active members, year over year, bolstering its strong base of loyal shoppers.It's unclear as to when Amazon and other e-tailers might begin to encroach on Ulta and Sephora's precious beauty space. And high valuation concerns dog Ulta's stock.Perish the thought, says Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel."We think investors should ignore the hang up and buy the best retailer in the business, or wait for market pullbacks & do it then," he wrote, "as ULTA is proving repeatedly that it sits at the top of the retail pack, in our view."And as the beauty train chugs along, value beauty brand e.l.f. Beauty (ELF) could also stand to benefit. Cowen says "the momentum and significant addressable market size ULTA sees for this consumer bodes well for long-term sustainable growth for ELF."E.l.f. shares fell 1.7% to 29.65 after rising as high as 30.69 and dropping as low as 29.05. The stock is in buy range again from a 29.02 buy point first cleared on Nov. 14. E.l.f., which came public at 17 in late September, plunged 4.2% on Thursday, moving back into the entry zone. Plunging back into a buy zone in heavy volume should raise some concerns.Amazon shares fell 0.45% to 740.34, their fifth straight decline.RELATED:Ulta Shines Late; Ambarella, Workday Reverse Down; Five Below Jumps

The stock market closed mixed Wednesday as indexes faded late but continued a trend of modest price movements.The Nasdaq edged out a gain of less than 0.1%, but the S&P 500 lost 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3%. Just like on Tuesday, the indexes weakened into the close and ended near session lows.Dow component Caterpillar (CAT) weighed on the industrials after the New York Times reported that the heavy-equipment maker was accused of tax fraud.Volume was higher in the major exchanges, according to early numbers.Retail, a sector that's been battered, led the market. Just like it was unclear why the sector sold off Monday, there were no obvious reasons to explain Wednesday's rally.Apparel retailers did get a boost after Children's Place (PLCE) soared past the 11.30 buy point of a base-on-base pattern. The chain beat profit expectations and raised its dividend.Biotechs also were up broadly. The group climbed 1.5%, among the day's top five.Homebuilders continued their emergence in the market leadership. Century Communities (CCS), Lennar (LEN), Pulte Group (PHM) and a few other builders continued to rise from their latest breakouts.But the energy sector tumbled after U.S. oil futures slid 5.4% to $50.28 a barrel. U.S. oil production climbed last week to the highest level since February 2016, and crude inventories rose for the ninth straight week.Utilities were in the bottom as well. IBD's four utility industry groups finished in the bottom 20 of 197 groups.An early burst in financials came apart quickly. The SPDR Financial (XLF) ETF erased most of a 1.4% increase to close with a minimal gain.On Thursday, earnings are due out from Finisar (FNSR), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Embraer (ERJ). Economic data being announced Thursday include the weekly jobless claims at 8:30 a.m. ET.RELATED:Puma Leads Massive Biotech Surge As Esperion Hits 15-Month High Macy's, Costco, Kohl's And Other Retailers Are Getting SlammedOil Just Had Its Worst Day In 13 Months As U.S. Output, Stockpiles Boom

Amazon (AMZN), Tesla Motors (TSLA), GrubHub (GRUB), Domino's Pizza (DPZ) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) could all soon provide actionable trading opportunities, with catalysts ranging from earnings to pending tax cuts under Trump.Amazon is still within the 5% buy range from an 821.75 handle entry cleared last Tuesday, and it's also just under an alternate entry at 847.31, which would put it at a new all-time high. The e-commerce giant reports quarterly earnings late Thursday.Tesla has rallied nearly 40% since the beginning of December and is now 6.1% away from a potential buy point at 269.44. Investors see the made-in-America electric automaker as a beneficiary of the Trump administration's pending corporate tax cuts.GrubHub has been in consolidation mode since last September, and is now trading 6.3% below a 44.68 buy point. Shares have made considerable gains over the past few weeks as analysts say the online food delivery service, too, is set to be a big beneficiary of tax cuts.IBD'S TAKE: With an IBD Composite Rating of 98 and considerable share-price gains as of late, GrubHub earns a spot on the IBD 50 list of leading growth stocks. For details on why GrubHub is such a fundamentally strong stock, check out our latest New America article.Domino's is just pennies away from a cup-with-handle buy point of 172.10. The stock, which closed Friday at 172.02, has made considerable gains over the past year amid accelerating bottom-line growth.Ulta is 1% below a 274.09 entry in a base-on-base pattern. Shares saw a wild negative reversal in the last earnings report on Dec. 2, but the stock has steadily risen since.

A yawning trench of dirt, wood and exposed cables currently sits at the mouth of the Westfield Century City in west Los Angeles. The Apple (AAPL) store is still open and the Tesla (TSLA) showroom has been moved to a different spot, but much of the shopping center remains under construction.When it reopens this year, it will have expanded into a glamorous 1.2-million-square-foot beast of a mall — 422,000 square feet larger — complete with Italian food emporium Eataly, hip burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK) and "new high-fashion streetside boutiques."XIn fact, the Century City mall won't just be a mall, it will be "an immersive sensory experience unprecedented in the modern retail space," according to a 2015 Westfield press release. This location hardly needs a tuneup. With $1,457 in sales per square foot, it is the ninth-most productive mall in the country, according to a CNBC story from May, citing real estate research firm Green Street Advisors. So why spend $800 million on a makeover?Looks matter more than ever, particularly as social-media bragging rights become an essential part of the millennial shopping experience. So these days, every retailer has to put on a good show, ramping up the drama to boost foot traffic and cheat death as Amazon (AMZN) spells doom for more and more American malls."(Young people are) very into cataloging everything they do via social media, and so these more luxury experiences have more social currency," said Talmage Advisors CEO Liz Dunn.That could mean Snapchatting from inside a Tiffany (TIF) — regardless of whether you buy something — or taking a topside photo of your artisanal lunch. (Never has flat lay photography been so popular.)"Whatever it is, there's a lot more social currency to that than saying 'I'm at a TGI Friday's,' " she said.The mall's transformation into an "immersive sensory experience" contrasts with the post-World War II bloom of malls, which attracted Americans to cookie-cutter hubs with their one-stop-shopping convenience. That has since given way to the splendid isolationism of two-day shipping via Amazon Prime, hollowing out traditional malls and forcing the survivors to become purveyors of experiences that can be shared online.Fellow L.A.-based shopping center The Grove, owned by Caruso, underscores the trend and is a social-media maven's dream.It houses many of the same stores as a regional mall does — like Banana Republic, J. Crew and Anthropologie — but also features a fountain, trolley and live music, helping put it at No. 2 on CNBC/Green Street Advisors' list with a $2,200 in sales per square foot. The photogenic plaza was even once the backdrop for Hollywood-gossip show "Extra," which has no doubt upped its social cred among tourists who want a glimpse of glam."This is where all the B-list celebs, YouTube stars, and Instagram influencers shop (I saw an Instagram male model there myself when I went)," gushed one Yelp reviewer visiting from Toronto.The lure of exclusivity, that close cousin of luxury, is another way retailers have amped up the theatrics.It's a tactic long employed by an athletic-footwear industry that routinely releases shoes in small batches, driving up demand from sneakerheads and high-schoolers alike. There's even a sneaker stock exchange, StockX, devoted to the resale of Jordans, Kobes and anything Kanye has ever designed for Adidas.Other retailers have since caught on. Coach (COH) and Disney (DIS) last year introduced a limited-edition House of Mouse-themed handbag line. Spice Girl-turned-fashion designer Victoria Beckham is behind Target's (TGT) upcoming capsule collection. And H&M seems to have an endless series of designer linkups in the pipeline.The New York Times even declared 2016 "the year of the drop," referring to the slew of limited-edition releases and pop-up shops, like Kylie Jenner's blink-and-it's-gone store, designed to create shopper frenzy.The Hollywood Reporter called the December opening of Jenner's pop-up, located within the Westfield Topanga Mall in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley, "mayhem."Mayhem is the antithesis of convenience, when it comes to shopping. But that is the point. No one wants to stand in line outside for hours waiting for laundry detergent. A Kylie Lip Kit, however, is not long for this world.To get a teen or 20-something to the mall — and most "drop" shoppers are under 30, noted the Times — the mall must act a little more like a nightclub, velvet ropes and all.Even supermarkets are in on the action: Some Whole Foods Market (WFM), Kroger (KR) and Gelson's locations feature wine bars, a premium add-on meant to keep grocery shoppers in stores longer.Such theater may seem gimmicky, but it works, and is also being seen in actual theaters. The local cineplex, a requisite component of any shopping mall, is also undergoing a revamp.On the defensive from Netflix (NFLX) and massive TVs, theaters have been making screens bigger, audio better, and seats more spacious. And as an alternative to grabbing popcorn from the concession stand and trying to find a decent seat, more theaters now serve cocktails and dinner to your reserved Barcalounger while that summer blockbuster plays in Imax 3D.AMC (AMC), for example, embarked three years ago on a $600 million reseating project to rip out traditional chairs and replace them with recliners.AMC, which has called its collective upgrades a "winning playbook," outlined at a recent presentation that attendance has grown 53% and revenue leapt 70% in its 1,500 or so reseated theaters. It has thousands more theaters in line to be updated.Top exhibitor chain Regal Cinemas (RGC) also recently attributed recent outperformance to plush seating, calling out recliner sites as the "biggest driver.""Theaters have to do something to differentiate themselves from the in-home experience," said RBC analyst Leo Kulp. "That's really what's driven these investments over the past several years."Theaters, full-service restaurants and other bells and whistles have woven themselves into a successful mall's narrative, but it may be a while before the experiential stuff surpasses retail stores that sell shirts and shoes."The future will certainly bring less retail, but it will take a few years to tip the scale" so that retailers become a mall's minority residents, said NPD Group retail analyst Marshal Cohen.There is also some hope for once-reliable mall anchors like Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), even as Macy's reportedly considers selling itself after a brutal holiday season.The Grove has a Nordstrom, and the revamped Westfield Century City is actually adding a department store to the mix, for a total of three major names. It will now house a two-story Macy's, three-story Bloomingdale's and a three-story Nordstrom that is being relocated from the next mall over.But the massive upgrades being made to shopping arenas could even further widen the gap between top-market malls and their less-moneyed brethren.Of the more-than-1,000 malls in America, the 300 or so top-market "A-malls" account for 75% of mall value (a metric comprised of sales productivity, size and other factors), according to Green Street Advisors.So what's a midtier mall to do? For developers, the answer may be: Change or die.Strong anchors are "imperative" for a shopping center's long-term viability, according to Green Street's 2017 mall outlook report, since income-generating tenants want malls with "vibrant," traffic-driving anchors.As department stores waver, Green Street's research points to restaurants, movie theaters and "traditional power-center tenants" — like Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and pet stores — as rising power players.But Talmage Advisors' Dunn is not optimistic."The problem is, it's a little bit of a self-fulfilling prophesy," she said. "The landlords aren't willing to invest in the lower-tier centers, and the thing that would potentially take a lower-tier center to help it jump a bracket is investment. But it's hard to justify the investment if the center's performance isn't in that top-tier range."

March dawned with new highs for the major stock indexes. The last time U.S. stocks posted a negative month was before the November election. Thus far, the Trump effect retains its grip on the ETF market.That same old glow, a jaded investor might say, but that is no excuse for investment decisions to get stuck in a rut. While sector-equity "Trump Trades" are still the rage, some successful investors are on the prowl for a different approach to playing this remarkable stock rally with exchange traded funds.Eric Biegeleisen, director of quantitative research at Beaumont Capital Management, looks through the prism of factors for his best ETF investment ideas as market conditions evolve.A factor approach to investing aims to harvest the drivers of return in a group of stocks — such as the momentum and size factors, or attributes, that Biegeleisen currently favors.Click Here For A List Of The Best-Performing ETFs Of 2017His list of potential winners all focus on U.S. stocks and are backed by the same provider, but have little else in common. Each produces a markedly distinct basket of stocks as a result of its targeted factor."These exposures should perform well if the growth that is anticipated remains intact throughout the year," Biegeleisen said. Beaumont has $3.57 billion in total client assets and offers several ETF-based portfolio strategies including a popular tactical sector rotation strategy.Biegeleisen serves as portfolio manager of the firm's factor-based and smart-beta strategies. Here are the investing pro's own words:Following the unexpected results of the election in November, we have seen U.S. equities race higher along with dollar strength, initially at the expense of severe declines in U.S. Treasuries and emerging markets. Since then, U.S. Treasuries have remained down and are now trending sideways, while emerging markets came back strongly and are now positive.Through the lens of a BCM factor (smart beta) strategy, we have seen very low levels of volatility, leading the strategy to remain fully invested overall but with emphasis on momentum, yield and size. These exposures should perform well if the growth that is anticipated remains intact throughout the year.These ETFs are currently owned by Beaumont Capital Management or could be purchased at any time:Year to date through the end of February, momentum has been the best performer of the major equity factors followed by yield. Size has actually been the worst performer (yet still positive), which may be due to the strong performance it achieved immediately following the election last November.Nonetheless, the new administration seems intent on delivering on all campaign promises. We believe those firms who exhibit strong positive momentum should continue to perform well as the market continues higher.In addition, firms that deliver return to shareholders through dividends should also see a continued boost as investors remain invested generally, but also are searching for yield as interest rates remain subdued.Finally, the smaller, more U.S.-focused companies should have renewed investor interest if U.S.-centric trade policies, i.e., a border adjusted tax (BAT), are enacted.RELATED:Growth ETF Strategy Taps Rally That Trump Has Ignited In 7 S&P SectorsWhat Going On In The Stock Market Now?

The Dow Jones industrial average and other stocks edged lower during the latest week, digesting recent gains as oil tumbled. Health care stocks were in motion as President Trump and the GOP Congress pushed major health care changes. A strong jobs report locks in next week's Federal Reserve rate hike. Snap (SNAP) retreated in its first full week.The Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite fell modestly for the week, as plunging oil prices weighed on energy stocks, including Dow components Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX). Investors didn't appear fazed by a likely Federal Reserve rate hike in the coming week. Treasury yields closed in on recent peaks, but homebuilders were among the stronger groups. Fiber optic stocks sold off on weak earnings from Ciena (CIEN) and Finisar (FNSR). Ulta Beauty (ULTA) hit a new high on blowout same-store sales and e-commerce gains. Snapchat parent Snap fell back while Facebook (FB) hit a new high and China's Momo (MOMO) soared on earnings. did well.U.S. oil futures tumbled 9.1% for the week to $48.49 a barrel as a U.S. shale revival is offsetting OPEC-led production cuts. U.S. crude stockpiles surged by 8.2 million barrels to an all-time high while U.S. production continued to ramp up and the number of rigs in operation continued to climb Saudi Arabia reportedly warned top U.S. shale producers at IHS' CERAWeek not to automatically expect an extension of the OPEC output deal. Saudi and other OPEC officials had been trying to convince markets that they will hold firm on cuts, but that's only encouraged U.S. shale producers to race in to fill the gap.Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) CEO Ben van Beurden said oil demand could peak as early as next decade but Chevron (CVX) CEO  John Watson said that peak demand is "wishful thinking." BP (BP) CEO Bob Dudley said Russia is "very misunderstood" and is a good business investment. Shell agreed to sell the majority of its Canadian oil sands assets and Exxon Mobil (XOM) bought natural gas assets off the shore of Mozambique. BP and Russia also announced natural gas expansion hopes during the conference.RELATED:The U.S. economy added 235,000 jobs in President Trump's first full month in office, while the unemployment rate dipped to 4.7%. Meanwhile, average hourly earnings rose 2.8% from a year ago, just a tad behind the fastest growth of the recovery. The Federal Reserve had already telegraphed a near-certain rate hike on March 15 before Friday's report confirmed the second straight month of stellar job gains. Job gains were lifted by warm weather, which fueled a 58,000 rise in construction employment. Yet enthusiasm about the Trump agenda of deregulation, tax cuts and infrastructure spending has clearly been a factor behind the spurt in job growth and economic confidence. The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index, though dipping slightly to 55.3 in March, remained close to February's 12-year high.The key question is whether the optimism — and strong job growth — is sustained throughout the spring, in which case the Fed's rate-hiking timetable will accelerate.RELATED:House Republicans rolled out legislation to repeal and replace much of ObamaCare, with the legislation clearing some hurdles despite opposition from various liberals, conservatives and moderates. Hospital operator, Tenet Healthcare (THC) sold off during the week amid concerns of losing paying customers. Rivals HCA Holdings (HCA) and Universal Health Services (UHS) also retreated. Insurers were mixed, with Anthem (ANTM) closing in on a 20-month peak. But Molina Healthcare (MOH) fell sharply. Meanwhile President Trump tweeted out that he's working on drug pricing, sending some drug and biotech stocks lower.RELATED:Shares of Snapchat-operator Snap (SNAP) reversed sharply following its initial public offering on March 2, when the stock jumped 44% from its IPO price of 17 on the first day of trading. The stock hit a record high of 29.44 the next day, a Friday. This past week, as Snap was showered with sell ratings, hit a low of 20.64, and then rebounded. Snap fell 18.5% for the week to 22.07. Facebook (FB), which continued to roll out features that ape popular Snapchat offerings, hit a record high.RELATED:China mobile app Momo (MOMO) hit a record high after reporting fourth-quarter earnings that beat estimates, as did its first-quarter outlook. Momo reported a 633% jump in Q4 earnings, while revenue rocketed 524% to $246 million. The Chinese internet play has thrived since introducing a paid video-sharing service to its users last year. Momo shares soared in a volatile week.RELATED:Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reported its second-straight quarter of accelerating EPS and sales growth, as e-commerce revenue soared 63%. The beauty products retailer guided low for the current quarter. Ulta shares initially fell Friday, but rebounded to close up nearly 5% in strong volume to a record high as investors downplayed Ulta's outlook as typically conservative. Meanwhile, value cosmetics maker e.l.f. Beauty (ELF) reported better-than-expected holiday results and gave bullish guidance. Its stock soared 12% on Thursday, paring gains somewhat on Friday.RELATED:LGI Homes (LGIH) earned $1.01 a share, up 35% vs. a year earlier, while revenue climbed 34% to $234.6 million. Wall Street had expected EPS of 94 cents on sales of $235.9 million. The builder sees 2017 EPS of $4-$4.50, well above analyst targets of $3.74. LGI Homes shot up nearly 13% to a five-month high Tuesday. Meanwhile, other builders such as Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH) continued to advance even with mortgage rates rising.RELATED:Ciena (CIEN) and Finisar (FNSR), both reported weaker-than-expected earnings and revenue, sending both stocks plunging and putting pressure on other fiber-optic gear makers. Ciena, a maker of fiber-optic systems, said fiscal Q1 adjusted earnings per share rose 44% while revenue climbed 8% but missed analyst forecasts. Ciena's current-quarter revenue guidance midpoint is above the Wall Street consensus. Finisar, a maker of optical components, reported adjusted Q3 EPS surged 136% while revenue jumped 23% to $380.6 million, also below targets. Finisar also guided low for the current quarter.RELATED:The kid's apparel chain's earnings jumped 58%, easily beating views. Sales grew 4%, slightly below views, but same-store sales climbed 6.9%. Children's Place also gave upbeat earnings guidance. The retailer also doubled its dividend and OK'd a stock buyback program. Children's Place shares surged 18% on Wednesday to a record high. Meanwhile, apparel, department and other brick-and-mortar retailers are struggling. Urban Outfitters (URBN) fell modestly after reporting earnings and sales just below views. Express (EXPR) dived on weak guidance while men's apparel retailer Tailored Brands (TLRD) crashed on an all-around grim report.RELATED:Thor Industries (THO) got decked after RV maker reported thinner margins for fiscal Q2, and the company said it would increase spending during the fiscal year amid rising demand. REV Group (REVG), which owns a variety of RV, firetruck and ambulance manufacturers, reported a mixed fiscal Q1 but guided full-year sales just above views. REV Group also fell during the week but reversed up. Sales of RVs could pick up as the economy improves and baby boomers retire, while an aging population and needed upgrades put off during the recession could lift demand for firetrucks, ambulances and related parts.Camping World (CWH), a retailer of camping supplies, reported solid earnings but sales fell short. The stock, which came public in early October, fell 6% on Thursday, undercutting a recent buy point.RELATED:

Following yesterday's tech-sector sell-off, the Nasdaq looked to recover some of those losses Friday morning in the stock market today after payrolls came in above expectations.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both rose 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrials hovered around the break-even mark, weighed down by financials. Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL), Starbucks (SBUX) and Foot Locker (FL) lead your stocks to watch this week.Ulta went on a wild ride Friday, initially breaking out past a double-bottom entry at 268.88. Then shares reversed lower, found support at the 50-day line and ultimately closed down 1.6% at 253.39. The beauty products retailer reported another estimate-beating quarter late Thursday and issued strong Q4 guidance. See if the stock can continue to hold above the 50-day line and break out of the base.Google-owner Alphabet and Facebook have been notable losers in the postelection sector rotation. Facebook fell back below its 200-day line this past week, coming close to its Nov. 14 low of 113.55 — a level the stock hadn't seen since four months prior. Shares are now 13.5 below their Oct. peak. Alphabet lost support at its 200-day line on Friday, and is trading 9% below its high.Starbucks is nearing a test of support at its 200-day line after retaking that level on Nov. 22. The stock has been consolidating, i.e. moving sideways, since October 2015 and is trading 10.6% below its high reached at that time. The late-Thursday announcement that CEO Howard Schultz will be stepping aside to become executive chairman is weighing on shares.After issuing estimate-beating earnings on Nov. 18, Foot Locker found support near the 50-day line and reversed to close the session higher. It soon after cleared a cup-with-handle base with a 73.47 buy point, and though the stock dipped below that level, it's now back in buy range.IBD'S TAKE: Want to be able to learn how to spot bases and buy points for yourself? Stocks opened mainly higher Friday, following a positive November payrolls report and edgy international trade ahead of Sunday's constitutional referendum in Italy.The Dow industrials fell 0.1% while the S&P 500 rose 0.2% and the Nasdaq 0.3%. Small caps were lower, with the Russell 2000 off 0.6%.For the week, the Nasdaq headed into Friday down 2.7% and the S&P 500 off 1% — both tacking toward their first decline in three weeks. The Dow was up 0.2%, and the Russell 2000 was down 2.5% vs. last Friday's close.U.S. nonfarm employers added 178,000 new workers during November, the Labor Department reported, up sharply from 161,000 new hires in October and outpacing estimates for 170,000 added jobs. Private companies did the bulk of the hiring, adding 156,000 employees, vs. expectations for hirings to increase to 155,000.The unemployment rate dropped to 4.6%, down from 4.9%, easily besting the consensus forecast for no change. The work week and participation rates held steady.Two Federal Reserve Board governors are scheduled to speak this morning: Lael Brainard at 8:30 a.m. ET and Daniel Tarullo at 12:30 p.m. ET. Baker Hughes (BHI) delivers its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m.ET.Five Below (FIVE) rung up an 10% gain at the open. The dollar store chain reported third-quarter earnings just above analyst targets. Revenue rose 18% but just missed views. Fourth-quarter guidance was in line with expectations. But management said it was pleased with the start of the holiday shopping season, and had launched an expanded TV advertising campaign. Five Below shares have been working on the right side of a four-month consolidation.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) jumped 4%. A 26% gain in earnings and a 24% sales advance outpaced analysts' third-quarter estimates. The IBD 50 stock broke out past the 268.88 buy point in a double-bottom base at the start of trading.Human resources software provider Workday (WDAY) clocked a 16% loss. But several large contracts expected to close in the fourth quarter had been pushed back, management said, due to political and economic uncertainties.  Shares gapped well below the 200-day moving average, ruining a base that Workday was forming.Starbucks (SBUX) slipped 1.5% after founder Howard Schultz said he would turn over his chief executive role to President and Chief Operating Officer Kevin Johnson. Schultz, who will maintain his position as company chairman, said he plans to focus his efforts on Starbucks' high-end coffee shops, a new strategic initiative for the company.  Starbucks is forming the right side of a 13-month-old consolidation.Oil trimmed its early declines to 0.2%, leaving West Texas Intermediate near $51 a barrel and up more than 9% for the week. Gold climbed 0.2% to above $1,171 an ounce, 4% below last Friday's settle price. The dollar was down vs. the yen and up slightly against the euro. Bonds gained, sending the 10-year yield down 2 basis points to 2.42%.Overseas markets were unanimously lower. China's Shanghai Composite ended down 0.9% Friday and the Hong Kong Hang Seng Index dropped 1.1%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 slipped 0.5%.Europe's markets came off their lows in early afternoon trade, with the CAC 40 in Paris off 1.2%, Frankfurt's DAX down 0.8% and the FTSE 100 in London showing a 0.8% loss.RELATED:Ulta Shines Late, Amabrella, Workday Reverse LowerJust One Thing Matters In Friday's Jobs ReportAuto Suppliers In Buy Zone; Investing Action Plan
