A lukewarm shopping environment hasn't put a blemish on the beauty industry, which has been the fastest-growing retail segment for the last three years, according to NPD Group.Specialty players Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and LVMH-owned Sephora are flourishing — and value cosmetics brand and recent issue e.l.f. Beauty (ELF) appears poised to take advantage of the on-fire trend.E.l.f., which sells its wares mostly via CVS (CVS), Target (TGT), Ulta Beauty and other national retailers, went public at 17 in late September, rising roughly 70% to about 29 a share as of Wednesday.In an email Q&A with Investor's Business Daily, e.l.f. CEO Tarang Amin outlined his approach to engagement, the significance of its small but growing brick-and-mortar presence, and the company's greatest growth opportunities in 2017.IBD: Social media — Instagram in particular — has become a hot spot for beauty enthusiasts. Following e.l.f.'s Beauty Scape activation, how does social media play into your engagement strategy in 2017, and how do you see that impacting the new loyalty program?Amin: Our approach to engage consumers is deeply rooted in social media and digital platforms, and will continue to be a main pillar of our engagement strategy. We were extremely pleased with the outcome of our e.l.f. Beauty Scape activation, which delivered a 25% increase in Instagram followers and reached a combined community of 53 million across social media platforms. We believe we can further build awareness and deepen engagement with our consumers in different ways, including our new Beauty Squad loyalty program. We enrolled 80,000 consumers in just the first six weeks and look forward to continuing to expand the program as we strengthen our CRM capabilities and deliver more fun, relevant content for our consumers.IBD'S TAKE: What's holding Amazon back from becoming a major player in beauty? For an in-depth look, read: "Why Amazon Has Been Powerless Against Beauty Stores."IBD: You've previously said that the majority of growth will be driven by your presence in retailers such as Target and CVS? How do you see the sales mix of e.l.f. direct-channel, third-party e-commerce (such as Amazon) and national retailers shifting over the next few years, if at all?Amin: We expect the U.S. to be the largest source of our growth over the next few years as we grow space allocation with existing retailers, increase new customers and grow our direct-to-consumer business through elfcosmetics.com and e.l.f. stores. The majority of our growth will be driven by national retailers, given the white space that we see here in existing doors as well as new doors. That being said, our direct channel plays an incredibly important role in terms of validating our innovation and engaging with our consumers, and we believe there is significant room to grow here as well.IBD: There are fewer than 20 stand-alone e.l.f. brick-and-mortar retail locations. What's the significance of building out a brick-and-mortar presence?Amin: In Q3 of 2016, we opened seven e.l.f. stores, to bring our total to 15, including our first California stores, with two locations in the Los Angeles metropolitan area. Our stores showcase a broad assortment of e.l.f. products, create an environment dedicated to play beautifully, and allow us to test and validate new products. We believe our stores provide a great opportunity for us to connect with our consumers in an experiential format, and drive both awareness and engagement.IBD: Cosmetic and skin care products are still selling well, even as other areas of retail have struggled. Do you see interest in beauty peaking any time soon?Amin: We believe that the cosmetics category is highly attractive given its scale, growth dynamics and consumer demand trends. And, given the importance of cosmetics in a woman's daily regimen and the availability of products across price points, the category has demonstrated resiliency through economic cycles. We expect cosmetics to continue to be among the fastest growing and most consistent consumer categories.IBD: What's the biggest area of growth and opportunity for e.l.f. in 2017?Amin: We believe we are in the early innings of growth as we continue to make progress on our four key strategies: Build a great brand, lead innovation, expand brand penetration and drive world-class operations. We continue to see momentum in both our direct channels and leading national retailers, as well as strong operational results and remain excited about our business as we head into 2017.RELATED:How Instagram, Twitter Beauty Selfies Are Changing The Face Of RetailRetailers Face 2017 'Reckoning,' More 'Sad Malls' As Amazon Keeps BoomingWhat's Driving The Success Of 'Un-Amazon-Able' Ulta Beauty?Domino's CEO Doyle On Netflix, Trump And Pizza's 'Jetsons' Future

The stock market enjoyed a mild yet broad rally on Friday following stellar U.S. job gains and a decent rise in hourly wages for February.The Nasdaq composite's 0.3% gain exceeded advances of 0.2% for both the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average. But the Nasdaq is still on track to snap a six-week winning streak.Some sector indexes fared better. The Dow Jones transport average rose 0.7%. The S&P SmallCap 600 kept pace with the large-cap gauges, up 0.3%.In the stock market today, a handful of high-quality specialty retailers showed that investors are still seeking excellent companies that can capitalize on consumer spending.Restaurant-cum-arcade chain Dave & Buster's (PLAY) gained 1.6% to 59.51, gaining further ground past a 58.35 flat base entry. The flat base, which can show a decline of no more than 10% to 15% from the base's intraday high to low, began with the down week that ended on Jan. 6 this year.Dave & Buster's, which still qualifies as a small-cap stock with a $2.5 billion market cap, has the highest Composite Rating within IBD's restaurants industry group at 94 on a scale of 1 to 99, as seen in IBD's proprietary time-saving research tool, Stock Checkup.Wall Street sees the Dallas-based firm posting double-digit EPS growth in both fiscal 2017 (up 36% to a record $2.06 a share) as well as in fiscal 2018 (up 16% to $2.38). Top-line growth is expected to be lighter yet still robust (up 16% in FY 2017 ended in January, up 15% in FY 2018).Industry peer Domino's Pizza (DPZ) continues to be a long-term market leader, rising more than 1% to 186.74.Notice on a daily chart how the global consumer spending play has held above its rising 50-day moving average in recent months following a light correction in December.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reversed in glamorous form, erasing early losses to rise 4% to 285.12, good for a new high. Shares are still in buy range, up 4% past a 274.09 early buy point within a choppy, unusual-looking base that began with a sharp decline in the week ended Aug. 26 last year.The cosmetics, hair and skin care retailer notched mildly accelerating EPS growth for a second quarter in a row as Q4 profit grew 33%, up from gains of 24% and 26% in the prior two quarters.Ulta's revenue jumped 25% to $1.58 billion, extending a string of 20%-plus year-over-year increases to six quarters. After-tax margin improved to 8.9% vs. 8.5% in the year-ago quarter.Ulta's Composite Rating of 89 is not great yet still decent, and it's tops in the small Retail-Specialty industry group. Keep in mind that many retail stocks these days tend to have lower Composite ratings due in part to poor industry group relative strength. Apple (AAPL) rose 0.3% to 139.14, reaffirming its dominance among blue chip techs in 2017.The megacap iPhone maker is now up 26% past a 110.33 cup-with-handle buy point that IBD noted in a Stock Market Today column on Sept. 14 last year. That cup with handle is part of a long bottoming base that began with Apple's peak of 134.54 on April 28, 2015. In Apple's bottoming base, shares fell as much as 33% to a low of 89.47 in May 2016 before finally rebounding.Apple has also acted well since forming another cup with handle and breaking out of that base on Jan. 6 at 118.12.In that 11-week cup with handle, the decline was extremely mild at just 12.3% from head to toe. This is actually a good thing, however, when you consider that most solid cup-with-handle patterns tend to show a decline of 20% to 30%.Plus, Apple's handle, which formed over six sessions in late December, showed a very light drop in bone-dry trade (please see a daily chart to spot the handle forming. That's ideal action for the final shakeout of uncommitted holders before a potential new breakout and big rally to 52-week or all-time highs arrives.In the small-cap kingdom, thinly traded MYR Group (MYRG) broke out with a big gap up, rising more than 12% to 42.41 and surpassing a 41.52 flat-base entry.The specialist in transmission, distribution and maintenance services for utilities reported a 66% lift in adjusted fourth-quarter profit, roasting Wall Street views by 20%. Revenue jumped 27% to $343.7 million, the biggest year-over-year jump since the second quarter of 2012.MYR trades just 63,000 shares a day, but institutional sponsorship is clearly rising. Mutual and hedge funds owning a stake increased from 276 at the end of 2015 to 332 at the end of 2016.A mediocre 66 Composite Rating belies MYR's solid 85 RS Rating. Plus, the relative strength line, which tracks a stock's performance vs. the S&P 500, is spiking into new high ground.RELATED:How To Invest: Why The Bottoming Base Matters For Growth Stock Pickers, Even In 2017Investor's Corner: How To Analyze The Handle's Quality In A Good Base PatternInside The IBD 50: Will These 15 Bank And Finance Stocks Make Big Strides In 2017?News On Apple: Go To IBD's Technology Section And Click Blog

Ulta Beauty's (ULTA) estimate-beating results and double-digit same-store sales make it a retail outlier amid a landscape beset with weak traffic and comparable sales declines. But can it keep up this pace?When the specialty beauty retailer reports late Thursday, Wall Street expects 26% profit growth to $2.13 a share on 21.5% revenue gains to $1.54 billion.Shares fell 2.1% to 269.92 in the stock market today, moving back below a 274.09 buy point and testing its 50-day moving average for the first time in three months. The stock has been rising just above or below the entry area for the past several weeks.Other retailers — including Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and Target (TGT) — have disappointed investors. Amazon.com (AMZN) looms ever larger as the reason for many retail woes.But the off-price, home improvement and specialty beauty sectors frequently get call-outs for eluding Amazon's tentacles.And one indicator of Ulta's holiday-quarter performance may come from rival Sephora, whose parent company LVMH reported results in late January."We're optimistic on the opportunity for sustained growth at ULTA, as LVMH reported further (double-digit) growth in revenue and profit at Sephora, driven by market share gains in all regions," wrote Cowen analyst Oliver Chen in late January, adding that strong shopper demand for specialty beauty products "bodes well for Ulta."In fact, he appears to prefer it over Sephora, which only carries high-end "prestige" brands. Ulta carries mass brands such as Revlon (REV), Maybelline and NYX in addition to upscale products from the likes of Urban Decay Cosmetics and Nars."While we acknowledge ULTA and Sephora overlap on some brands, we continue to like ULTA's exposure to a wider demographic with a broad spectrum of brands from mass to prestige."IBD'S TAKE: What's holding back Amazon and other e-commerce pure plays from eating into Sephora and Ulta's market share? There are several reasons why Amazon has been powerless against beauty stores. But even strong reports don't always provide Ulta shares with an immediate post-earnings boost. Its last two quarterly disclosures have been accompanied by declines before shares picked up steam again.E.l.f. Beauty (ELF) reports Q4 results Wednesday after the closing bell. The value-cosmetics brand's stock fell 2.9% to 25.92 on Tuesday. E.l.f. came public last September at 17 a share, rising as high as 32.54 on Nov. 29, but has struggled since then.RELATED:Ulta Beauty Forms New Holding Company For 'More Efficient' StructureMacy's, Costco, Kohl's And Other Retailers Are Getting SlammedE.l.f. Beauty CEO Amin On Social Cosmetics And The Ageless Beauty Boom

Stocks opened higher Friday after a better-than-expected reading on February hiring.Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Nasdaq 0.5%. Dow component United Technologies (UTX) swung up 0.3%.The Labor Department's payrolls report showed U.S. employers added 235,000 workers in February, above the 200,000 new hires projected by economist consensus. Private employers shouldered the bulk of the hiring, adding 227,000 new jobs. The department also revised its January estimate upward, to 238,000, from an initial 227,000 tally.The unemployment rate dipped to 4.7%, down 10 basis points and in line with expectations. The participation rate added 10 basis points to 63%. Average hourly earnings gained 0.2%, double January's increase but below the 0.3% consensus target.Oil prices — a key factor in this week's trading action — bobbed off the week's lows, with West Texas Intermediate trading up more than 1% to $49.91 a barrel. Oil is trading down 6% for the week, erasing the bulk of gains booked since November, when the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries forged a production agreement with several key non-OPEC producers. Oil prices may see some further effect from Baker Hughes' (BHI) weekly rig count, due out at 1 p.m.VeriFone Systems (PAY) fell nearly 3%. It reported after Thursday's close its fiscal first-quarter earnings and narrowly topped analyst expectations while revenue fell less than forecast. But management's second-quarter earnings guidance was light. The stock is up more than 30% from a December low, but still deep in a multi-year correction.Finisar (FNSR) toppled 17% at the open. The Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of fiber-optic networking gear reported late Thursday a 136% gain in fiscal third-quarter earnings and a 23% rise in revenue, with both marking a third straight quarter of acceleration, but they were also below analyst expectations. In addition, the company trimmed its fourth-quarter sales and earnings guidance to below consensus views. A cup-with-handle base the stock was shaping is now wrecked.IBD 50 stock Momo (MOMO) added more than 3% at the start of regular trade. The China-based social networking site ended Thursday up 12% so far for the week, after trimming about half its gains marked by a high Wednesday. The stock is extended from a breakout in February.Biotech drugmaker Cara Therapeutics (CARA) dived 11% after reporting a deeper-than-expected loss, and no revenue, in its fourth quarter. Management said cash would fund operations through the first quarter of 2018. Cara shares remain extended from a January breakout past a 12.84 buy point.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) climbed more than 2% after reporting strong fourth-quarter results and first-quarter earnings guidance in line with analyst targets. But management's first-quarter revenue outlook was just shy of expectations. Ulta has been trading tightly, but has failed for the past six weeks to gain altitude above a 274.09 buy point in an undefined base pattern.Royal Dutch Shell (RDSA) rose 1% after announcing late Thursday it would sell its Canadian oil sands developments to a subsidiary of Canadian Natural Resources (CNQ) for $7.5 billion. Shares of Canadian Natural rose 2% at the open. The Treasury Department reports its February budget at 2 p.m. ET.Gains across European markets strengthened in afternoon trade. Benchmark indexes in London, Frankfurt and Paris rose between 0.6% and 0.8%.RELATED:Why You Need To Watch Friday's Jobs Report Like a (Fed) Hawk

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reported better-than expected earnings and sales growth late Thursday, but Q1 guidance was light. Meanwhile, e.l.f. Beauty (ELF) soared during the regular session after topping estimates late Wednesday and gave upbeat guidance.Estimates: Earnings were seen jumping 26% to $2.13 per share with sales up 21.5% to $1.54 billion.Results: Ulta earned $2.24 a share, up 32.5% vs. a year earlier. Sales rose nearly 25% to $1.581 billion. It was the second straight quarter of accelerating profit and revenue growth. Same-store sales surged 16.6% as e-commerce sales surged 63% to $154.9 million.Outlook: Ulta Beauty sees Q1 EPS of $1.75-$1.80 and sales of $1.244 billion to $1.265 billion. Analyst had expected EPS of $1.80 on revenue of $1.27125 billion. Ulta sees Q1 comps, including e-commerce, up 9%-11%.Stock: Ulta fell nearly 5% to 260.49 in after-hours trading, suggesting the stock will tumble below its 50-day line at Friday's open. Shares closed down 0.6% to 273.77 on the stock market today, just below a 274.09 buy point. On Wednesday, shares rose 2.1% to 275.47. Ulta has been moving above and below the buy point for several weeks.Meanwhile, e.l.f. shares closed up 12.2% to 28.38 after rising as high as 31.10 intraday.Analysts were bullish on Ulta's holiday season after upscale rival LVMH's (LVMUY) Sephora showed robust growth."We're optimistic on the opportunity for sustained growth at ULTA, as LVMH reported further (double-digit) growth in revenue and profit at Sephora, driven by market share gains in all regions," wrote Cowen analyst Oliver Chen in late January, adding that strong shopper demand for specialty beauty products "bodes well for Ulta."IBD'S TAKE: Amazon is a formidable foe for retailers, but it lacks a satisfying in-store experience and other "It" factors that cosmetic shoppers want. E.l.f. earned 19 cents per share in Q4, topping analyst views for 14 cents. Sales climbed 17% to $76.4 million, also beating views for $74.5 million.Looking ahead, e.l.f. sees 2017 EPS of 40-43 cents and sales of $285 million-$291 million, both above analyst forecasts for EPS of 37 cents on sales of $281 million.The company's makeup lines are sold in Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT) and at some of its stand-alone stores.RELATED: Ulta Beauty Forms New Holding Company For 'More Efficient' Structure

GoPro on Wednesday unveiled a restructuring plan after it missed Q3 targets badly and gave weak Q4 guidance early this month. Zumiez broke out of a cup-shaped base with 22.24 entry point on Oct. 7 and have since moved out of buy territory.Estimates: Per-share profit it seen rising 12.5% to 9 cents, while sales are expected to grow 18% to $200.8 million. Shares dipped 0.15%.Results: EPS of 10 cents on sales of $199.5 million. Same-store sales fell 0.2%.Outlook: Q4 EPS of 89-92 cents, in line with consensus for 91 cents, on sales of $391 million-$397 million, with the midpoint above consensus for $393.65 million.Stock: Five Below spiked 10.8% late. The teen-focused specialty discounter's stock finished up 1.3% at 39.88.Estimates: Per-share loss of 4 cents from break-even prior-year quarter; sales seen climbing 31% to $400.4 million.Results: Per-shares loss of 3 cents on revenue of $409.6 million.Outlook: Full-year revenue of $1.560 billion-$1.563 billion, above consensus for $1.557 billion. But the implied Q4 revenue guidance is below views.Stock: Workday plunged 12% late after initially rallying in extended trade. The human resources software firm's shares finished down 3% to 81.60, though they found some support at the 200-day moving average. Shares continue to paddle below the 50-day since late October.

High expectations got the better of Ulta Beauty (ULTA) last quarter, despite solid results and bumped-up guidance. Could that happen to the specialty beauty retailer again, even if its third-quarter results shine late Thursday?As of Monday, Wall Street analysts are anticipating per-share profit to rise 23% to $1.37 a share on 22% revenue growth to $1.11 billion.Cosmetics and skin care are retail standouts. Specialty shops Ulta and LVMH-owned Sephora have been riding the beauty trends, with Ulta able to serve up double-digit same-store sales growth during a time when many other retailers are hoping for comps that are simply in the black. And analysts often call out Ulta Beauty as a top retail pick, immune to the charms of shopping on Amazon (AMZN).So why would investors expect anything but a rally from positive results? A quick recap:Despite reporting better-than-expected Q2 results in late August, shares tumbled over 6% and sank below their 50-day line. Slightly light Q3 profit guidance and concerns of high valuation were tossed around as possible causes.One equity strategist even mused on Twitter that male investors might not "get" the beauty business.Since then, however, Ulta has raised its Q3 and full-year guidance. For the 2016 fiscal year, it now expects mid-20% EPS growth and 12%-14% comps gains, up from low- to mid-20% growth and 11%-13% increases, respectively.Shares popped back up above their key 50-day level on the news.IBD'S TAKE: Ulta isn't the only retailer taking advantage of shopper lust for beauty products. Department stores and mall names are trying to build on a social media-driven interest in makeup to lure in foot traffic: "How Instagram, Twitter Beauty Selfies Are Changing The Face Of Retail."Flash forward to the present: Ulta fell 0.8% to 261.60 in the stock market today, after hitting 265.38 earlier. Shares are closing in on a 268.88 buy point in a double-bottom base. Ulta had climbed in 13 of the prior 14 sessions as of Friday.The current holiday quarter is looking good so far.Beauty department traffic was solid on Thanksgiving eve and Black Friday, according to one analyst."Traffic overall in beauty was solid; we expect ongoing strength in the category to persist through the December quarter," wrote Piper Jaffray analyst Stephanie Wissink on Friday.And shoppers are currently in the thick of Cyber Monday sales, so the numbers have yet to roll in, but the National Retail Federation expects a slight uptick to 122 million Americans who intend to plunk down dollars online today.E.l.f. Beauty (ELF) stock rose 0.9% to 31.15 intraday, extended from a 29.02 IPO base that it cleared earlier this month. E.l.f. Beauty came public in late September. E.l.f. sells low-cost cosmetics in stores such as CVS (CVS) and Target (TGT). It also has a handful of its own locations in Southern California and the New York area.RELATED:OPEC, Jobs, Ambarella, Ulta, Kroger Headline Investing Action PlanApple, Amazon, Best Buy, Ulta Beauty: Stocks To Watch As Holidays Kick Off

Adobe also delivered its sixth straight quarter of 20%+ sales growth.In IPO news, online travel firm Trivago (TRVG) had an OK debut after pricing last night at 11, well below the proposed range of 13-15. Shares were recently trading around  11.75.IBD'S TAKE: Recent new issues with top-notch fundamentals can deliver explosive gains in the early stages of business. IBD offers extensive coverage of the IPO and new-issue market.In the biotech sector, Gilead Sciences (GILD) slid 1% after a federal jury ordered Gilead to pay $2.5 billion to Merck (MRK) in a hepatitis C patent dispute.RELATED:Apple Is A Buy, FedEx PT Raised, Oracle PT Cut, Veeva UpgradedTrivago IPO Priced Below Range, Raises $287 Million

Earnings season is winding down, but investors will still get a lot of questions answered in the coming week. Will Ulta Beauty's (ULTA) results impress again? Will Finisar (FNSR) be able to clear a cup-with-handle base? Or will new issue Camping World (CWH) be back in buy range ahead of its earnings report Wednesday? The latest week had some winners…

Here's a look at four stocks that could make notable moves as the holiday shopping season officially kicks off.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which reports earnings on Thursday, closed Friday at 263.62, in sight of a double-bottom-base buy point at 268.88. Shares were able to find support at the 200-day line on Nov. 7 and have risen in 13 of the last 14 sessions. The beauty segment is expected to be a hot performer again this holiday season, which should benefit Ulta and potentially its stock.Best Buy (BBY) and Amazon are competing for your consumer electronics spending for the remainder of the year. Best Buy gave bullish holiday guidance earlier this month. Shares surged 14% on earnings to become quickly extended from a 40.31 buy point. The stock closed Friday at 46.58, nearly 16% above the entry. When a stock is 20% to 25% above a buy point, that's a good time to take at least partial profits.Amazon (AMZN) has been a highflying stock this year, but shares recently corrected as much as 16% in the wake of the e-commerce giant's latest earnings report. But the stock has now started to climb higher, and is nearing its 50-day line. At 780.37, it's 8% below an 847.31 buy point. Stellar Black Friday weekend stats could boost Amazon.Apple (AAPL) is also expected to benefit from its new product releases — the iPhone 7, Apple Watch Series 2 and MacBook Pro — this holiday quarter. Like Amazon, Apple has fallen off its peak and is still below the 50-day line. But it has retaken its 110.33 buy point, initially cleared Sept. 14, closing Friday at 111.79. Apple also is building a new base with a potential buy point at 118.79.And if you're still looking for stocking stuffers for your portfolio, Patrick Industries (PATK) and Cantel Medical (CMN) are both staging breakouts from bases. Chipmakers Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Broadcom (AVGO) are nearing buy points as well, while Semtech (SMTC) closed right at a 23.30 buy point ahead of its earnings report on Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Want to be able to learn how to spot bases and buy points for yourself? Check out IBD University. You can also get in-depth chart analysis on top-rated growth stocks by visiting Leaderboard. Take a free trial of Leaderboard.RELATED:Applied Materials Among Chips Dominating Leading-Stocks List

Paycom Software (PAYC) has a big opportunity selling human resources and payroll processing software to small- and medium-size business, says Jefferies, which hiked its price target to 69 from 58 on Monday."Proven execution in its core SMB (small to mid-size business) market, direct sales force with strong product expertise, and regular releases of new modules, make it well positioned to capture this opportunity," said John DiFucci, a Jefferies analyst in a report."The transition to SaaS is most appealing for SMBs, which historically haven't been able to spread the cost of required expertise across a large employee base," said DiFucci. "We believe SMBs remain particularly ripe for SaaS adoption given they tend to use standardized solutions that don't require customization."Paycom on Feb. 9 reported fourth-quarter earnings that topped views and forecast 2017 sales slightly above consensus estimates. They came amid uncertainty over whether the Trump administration and a Republican-controlled Congress will repeal the Affordable Care Act, also known as ObamaCare.Shares in Paycom Software fell 2 cents to 56.45 in the stock market today. Paycom Software stock has cleared a buy point of 53.03 and is trading above its 50-day moving average, a key metric.Paycom Software is ranked No. 13 in the IBD 50 roster of fast-growing stocks. It's also a member of IBD Sector Leaders.IBD'S TAKE: Aside from Paycom Software,  Inphi and Ulta Beauty are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. Oklahoma City-based Paycom targets companies in the 50- to-2,000-employee range. Paycom's focus on smaller businesses has kept it out of the cross hairs of software giants such as Salesforce.com (CRM) and Workday (WDAY).Just like Salesforce.com and Workday, Paycom Software sells subscriptions to human resource tools under a software-as-a-service (SaaS) business model.Paycom forecast 2017 revenue of $423 million at the midpoint of its guidance range, up about 28%, vs. Wall Street consensus estimates of $421 million.RELATED:Paycom Revenue Outlook Tops Street Amid Obamacare UncertaintySalesforce.com Price Target Hiked On Artificial Intelligence Push

Fiber optic stocks have had an up-and-down month, following big misses from Ciena (CIEN) and Finisar (FNSR). But IBD's Telecom-Fiber Optics group was the best-performing group on Friday, ahead of a key industry conference.So when executives from Lumentum Holdings (LITE), Finisar (FNSR), Infinera (INFN), Oclaro (OCLR), Acacia Communications (ACIA) and other optical communications providers gather next week in Los Angeles, what will be the hot topics?For one, prospects for industry consolidation could be on the minds of top management when the Optical Fiber Communication (OFC) exhibition in Los Angeles starts March 19."The optical component space continues to have too many vendors and not enough buyers," said Meta Marshall, a Morgan Stanley analyst in a report previewing the OFC. "However, it has been difficult for any strategic activity to take place as the industry is in the midst of multiple investment cycles that have increased profitability and valuations."She went on to say: "Ultimately, this industry needs to have fewer players to be healthier when current cycles end. Capital raising by many market participants in the past few months certainly raises the probability of an event, something we hope to hear more chatter about next week."According to a Jefferies analyst, Finisar could be eyeing Oclaro or other companies.Stocks in IBD's Telecom-Fiber Optics group have seesawed in early 2017 amid a bumpy earnings season and weaker-than expected demand from China. But they closed the week strong, extending post-Fed gains on Friday. Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) rose 5.9%, Acacia Communications 5.35%, Lumentum 1.1%, Oclaro 4.1%, Finisar 2% and Ciena 0.85%. Infinera dipped 0.6% after rising more than 8% on Thursday.Applied OptoElectronics and Lumentum have the highest IBD Composite Rating, an investing metric, in the group, with both at 99. Oclaro comes next with a composite rating of 95 out of a possible 99.Shares in Lumentum have climbed on speculation it could push into a new market, consumer electronics, and lasso a big customer in Apple (AAPL). Lumentum is developing 3D sensors for smartphones. Finisar is also targeting the 3D sensor market.IBD'S TAKE: Paycom Software and Ulta Beauty are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. Demand from China has been driving revenue growth for makers of fiber-optic components and network infrastructure, as is the upgrade to 100-gigabit-per-second technology by telecom firms such as Verizon Communications (VZ) in the U.S. New demand also is coming from interconnecting cloud-computing data centers packed with computer servers."While China will definitely be an area of conversation at OFC, we wouldn't expect component vendors to have any clearer view on 2017 demand than they did at earnings until they hear what has come out of the National People's Congress (currently in progress) early in April," added Marshall.RELATED:Finisar Flubs Q3 Earnings; Revenue, Outlook Miss, Stock PlungesFiber-Optic Gear Giant Ciena Dives On Earnings, Sales MissAmazon, Facebook 'Server-Side Optics' Good For Lumentum, Finisar

Shares of E.l.f. Beauty (ELF) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) look to be in a good spot ahead of the shopping crush this Thanksgiving weekend.Value cosmetics brand E.l.f., which can be found at mass stores like CVS Health (CVS) and Target (TGT), dipped back into buy range Tuesday, falling 1% to 30.02 on the stock market today, rebounding from an intraday low of 28.73.Shares first broke out of a flat base with 29.02 entry point last Monday, which means that this buy range has a ceiling of 30.47, or 5% from the buy point.Beauty names are about as popular with the Wall Street analyst set as they are with consumers. Specialty retailers like Ulta and LVMH (LVMUY)-owned Sephora thus far appear well-shielded against Amazon's (AMZN) e-commerce appetite, and experts are optimistic about the growth prospects of e.l.f.'s low-cost products.IBD'S TAKE: Retailers are gearing up to do battle against Amazon and friends. See what Black Friday and the rest of the holiday season has in store: "Retailers' Holiday Outlook: Not So Horrible This Year."Ulta's stock was up 2.9% to 258.39. Shares have been intermittently popping back above their 50-day moving average over the last couple of months, but have held above that key support area for several sessions.Ulta Beauty is in a double-bottom base with a buy point of 268.88.The last big market move came on Oct. 13, with shares spiking 11.4% after management upped its full-year outlook, guiding per-share profit up to mid-20s percentage growth from prior outlook for low- to mid-20s percentage range growth.It also raised same-store sales growth outlook to 12%-14% vs. prior comp targets for 11%-13%.RELATED:How Instagram, Twitter Beauty Selfies Are Changing The Face Of Retail Teens Help This Top Retailer Resist 'Amazon Effect' Why An Upward Price Gap In Ulta Shares Is Thing Of Beauty

The major indexes hit a little turbulence on Friday, but that doesn't mean compelling chart action is lacking. Your stocks to watch this week are Apple (AAPL), Starbucks (SBUX), Tesla (TSLA), Mobileye (MBLY) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA).Apple is extended about 16% from its cup-with-handle buy point of 118.12, with gains fueled by a strong quarterly report on Feb. 1. When a stock gains 20% past an entry, that's usually a good place to take at least partial profits. And when the market uptrend is under pressure, it can be sensible to sell part of your position at a 15% increase to protect your gains.Starbucks dropped hard after its last earnings report, which included its slowest profit growth in at least five years, but the stock is now looking to form a base. Shares have been able to retake the 50-day moving average and are nearing a shallow double-bottom entry at 59.10. But keep in mind that Starbucks has a weak Relative Strength Rating of 28 out of 99.Tesla sold off in the wake of its quarterly results late Wednesday. That has caused the stock to go on a "round trip" after breaking out past an entry at 258.56, which can be deemed as a sell signal. But shares were able to find support at the 250 price level on Friday.Mobileye was hit with bearish comments from short-seller Citron research on Friday. The loss put the stock back in the upper bound of the 5% buy range after clearing a 45.03 handle buy point in strong volume on Feb. 13, but it's still holding up relatively well. When Citron targeted Mobileye back in September 2015, the stock lost 10% for that week.Ulta Beauty has sneaked into buy range past a 274.09 buy point from a flat base, inching up in low volume over the past few weeks. Though the stock is trading near all-time highs, you want to see heavy volume when a stock enters a buy zone — that indicates institutional support.

Salesforce.com's (CRM) push into artificial intelligence could "support price increases, share gains and customer retention over time," says Pacific Crest Securities, which upped its price target on the software provider.Pacific Crest analyst Brent Bracelin increased his price target on Salesforce.com to 106 from 95.Salesforce.com stock ended virtually unchanged at 83.48 on the stock market today. Salesforce.com stock is nearing a technical buy point of 84.58 in a flat base. Salesforce.com is the sixth-ranked stock in IBD's enterprise software group, with Paycom Software (PAYC) as the top ranking company in that group.San Francisco-based Salesforce.com, whose software helps businesses organize and handle sales operations and customer relationships, last year unveiled an AI platform known as Einstein. Salesforce.com aims to embed data analytics and "machine learning" into its software, making it easier for customers to automate tasks.IBD'S TAKE: Paycom, Alibaba Group and Ulta Beauty are among IBD's Sector Leaders, a list that highlights the best stocks in 33 sectors. All Sector Leaders show outstanding earnings and sales growth in recent quarters. IBM (IBM) and Salesforce.com on March 6 announced they will partner to create artificial intelligence-based service platforms for enterprise customers."We have growing confidence in Salesforce's AI strategy," Bracelin said in a report. "We came away from multiple discussions with industry contacts, competitors and management over the past two weeks with more confidence that Salesforce can lever early AI wins at 50 pilot customers into a competitive advantage that can be easily replicated via a highly automated data-capture and modeling process."Microsoft (MSFT,) a growing rival of Salesforce.com, also is pushing AI tools into the enterprise market, targeting large companies, government agencies and medical institutions. Microsoft launched its AI-based Dynamics 365 sales software late last year.The biggest cloud-computing vendors — Amazon Web Services (part of Amazon.com (AMZN)), Microsoft and Alphabet's Google — are also targeting AI tools. Cloud service providers lease number-crunching computers and data storage via the internet.RELATED:What To Expect When Oracle Reports EarningsSnap Hits Record Low As Alphabet, Facebook Flex Ad Muscles

The stock market turned flat in afternoon trading, erasing solid morning gains following a better-than-expected jobs report from the Labor Department.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were fractionally higher, while the Dow Jones industrial average edged lower. Turnover was tracking lower on the NYSE, but modestly higher on the Nasdaq vs. the same time Thursday.Among the Dow industrials, action was mostly quiet. IBM (IBM) paced the advancers, moving up 0.2% after testing support around the 50-day level on Thursday. On the downside, Boeing (BA) has declined six of the last seven days. Shares were off 1.4%, but remained well-extended from a 160.17 flat-base entry.FANG stocks initially acted well in the stock market today as they continue their steady uptrends, but erased those gains along with the marketFacebook (FB) hit a record high of 139.49 in the morning, but was trading unchanged at 138.25 intraday. Since its mid-January breakout, gains haven't come at a dynamic pace, but the stock has steadily advanced to a 7% gain from a 129.37 cup-with-handle entry.Amazon (AMZN) shares also erased a modest morning gain to trade flat. The e-commerce giant is trading about 1% above a 843.94 cup-with-handle entry.Netflix (NFLX) crept 0.1% higher. The video streaming company is holding just above its 50-day line.Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) fell back to unchanged as well. Shares are 1% away from record highs that were set on Jan. 27.Willdan Group (WLDN) strongly broke out of a flat base with a 32.01 entry. Shares soared 16% to 32.31 after the company reported higher-than-expected Q4 earnings and revenue figures.Among other earnings reports, Finisar (FNSR) plummeted over 21% after the fiber-optics company missed both top- and bottom-line estimates. Shares had been forming a cup with handle with a 36.51 buy point, but never reached that level.Leading growth stocks were mainly positive heading into midday trading as chip stocks advanced; financials traded mixed.On the upside, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) jumped 3.1% to emerge as one of the top performers on the IBD 50. The beauty salon and cosmetics company reported higher-than-expected quarterly earnings and sales growth, but Q1 guidance was light.Among chip stocks, Broadcom (AVGO) and Applied Materials (AMAT) continued to shine. Broadcom marched 1.1% higher, while Applied Materials capped off a nine-week winning streak with a 3% weekly gain.On the downside, Sinclair Broadcast (SBGI) dropped over 4% after the company priced its stock offering at 42 a share.RELATED:February Jobs Growth Strong, But Not Too Strong To Unnerve Investors, FedUlta Beauty Earnings, Slaes Strong, But Guidance Isn't Pretty

Stocks ended the week quietly mixed, but it was a rough week for the Nasdaq composite, which fell nearly 3%.The Nasdaq edged 0.1% higher, the S&P 500 rose less than 0.1% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in about 20% lower than Thursday's levels.Goldman Sachs (GS) and Caterpillar (CAT) lagged in the Dow, while Intel (INTC) outperformed with a 1% gain. Shares jumped nearly 7% early but reversed after a short-lived breakout attempt over a 268.88 buy point.Inside the IBD 50, Applied Materials (AMAT) reclaimed a 31.17 buy point after a volatile session Thursday for chip stocks that saw the Philadelphia semiconductor index dive 5%.Starbucks (SBUX) fell 2% on news CEO Howard Schultz is stepping down. The stock market liked, but didn't love, news of better-than-expected job growth in February as major stock indexes closed out the week with modest gains.The Nasdaq composite's five-week win streak came to an end, but not by much. The tech-laden index rose 0.4%, but fell nearly 0.2% for the week. The S&P 500's six-week win streak also ended. It gained 0.3% Friday; down 0.4% for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average picked up 0.2%, but lost 0.5% for the week. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE coming in about 10% lower than Thursday. Nasdaq volume ended close to Thursday's level.Advancing stocks outnumbered decliners on both exchanges by nearly 2-to-1.Chip names like Lam Research (LRCX), Applied Materials (AMAT) and Broadcom (AVGO) outperformed in the Nasdaq 100, with gains of around 2% each.February employment numbers came in better than expected, just like the ADP report earlier in the week. February nonfarm payrolls rose to 235,000, nicely above the consensus estimate of 200,000. The unemployment ticked lower, as expected, to 4.7%.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, April WTI crude oil lost another 1.6% to $48.49 a barrel. For the week, it lost 9%, partly due to a government report earlier in the week that showed an 8.2-million-barrel weekly rise in domestic crude supplies to a record level of 528.4 million barrels.In the stock market today, the airline group held up relatively well despite a big dive by Southwest Airlines (LUV) after the company lowered its unit revenue guidance. U.S. stock indexes faded Friday afternoon, giving up nearly all of the quick gains scored in the first half hour of trade.The Nasdaq held a 0.1% gain after being up 0.6% in the morning. The S&P 500 rose 0.1% and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average was flat. Volume in the stock market today was running lower on the NYSE but higher on the Nasdaq.The bulls bolted out of the gate Friday morning on unexpectedly strong economic news. February payrolls surged to 235,000 or about 18% above the consensus estimate. A look under the headline number showed more bullishness. Construction jobs spurted 58,000, the most in 10 years. Manufacturing added 28,000 jobs.The Federal Reserve will meet Tuesday and Wednesday, and the good news on jobs increases the odds for an interest rate hike. CME Group's FedWatch tool pegs the odds for a hike at 93%, up from 88.6% a day ago.In the IBD 50, a proxy for stocks with elite ratings, winners led losers by a 9-7 ratio. Restaurant chain Dave & Buster's (PLAY) added 1% in heavy volume, following up nicely on Thursday's 3.5% pop. The Dallas-based company grew earnings 51%, 57%, 25% and 108% in the past four quarters. Revenue grew in the 13% to 19% range over the same period. After-tax margin rose vs. the year ago quarter in each of the past eight quarters.Banks, which make up a chunk of the Big Cap 20, were mostly down. Super regional bank KeyCorp (KEY) slid 2% in moderately higher volume.Blue chips were mostly up. General Electric (GE) led the Dow Jones industrial stocks with a 2% advance in volume about 30% above average.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, retail and building stocks posted good gains. Hospitals, steel and banks were among the day's biggest losers.RETAIL:Is Ulta Beauty Too Good To Be True?Housing Market's Lost Generation Could Be Ready To Come Home

Beauty stocks are having a beautiful day Monday as recent initial public offering e.l.f. Beauty cleared a buy point and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) is attempting to retake its 50-day line.E.l.f. shares jumped 8.8% to 29.37 on the stock market today, clearing its IPO base buy point of 29.02. The stock hit a record 30.50 intraday.Late Thursday, e.l.f. -- which makes low-cost makeup and brushes sold at Target (TGT), Wal-Mart (WMT) and CVS Health (CVS) — reported third-quarter earnings and revenue well above Wall Street estimates. E.l.f. (which stands for eyes, lips, face) went public in late September.Ulta Beauty — which sells cosmetics, hair care and other beauty items — rose 0.6% to end trading at 240.41, working on its sixth straight gain and trying to close above its 50-day moving average.IBD'S TAKE: The rise of the selfie culture on Facebook and Instagram have helped fuel beauty product sales as millennials aim to be picture perfect. E.l.f. isn't the only recent IPO breaking out Monday.  Airgain (AIRG) stock soared 27.5% to 19.45, popping well above its buy point of 17.04.Last week Airgain, an antenna maker, reported Q3 earnings results that beat analyst estimates. Airgain came public in August.But not all recent IPOs look so pretty. Acacia Communications (ACIA) and Twilio (TWLO) were red-hot IPOs over the summer, but have fallen and can't get back up. Acacia, a maker of fiber-optic gear, tumbled 5% by the closing bell as the once-highflying stock reported disappointing guidance late Thursday. Twilio fell fractionally to 31.39.RELATED: Beauty's A Hot Industry, But Does That Make E.L.F. Beauty A Buy?Recent IPO Airgain Flies To New High After Strong Earnings

Major index-tracking ETFs retreated from their stunning postelection rally on Cyber Monday despite a surge in oil prices and amid mixed news tied to holiday shoppers.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) slipped 0.5% on the stock market today.This exchange traded fund serves as a proxy for the broad U.S. market and set a fresh all-time high of 221.56 last week.Energy Select Sector SPDR (XLE), which tracks energy stocks in the S&P 500, booked a 1.4% loss despite strong gains in the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures for January delivery. WTI settled 84 cents higher at $46.90 a barrel.Oil rose on reports that Iraq will lend support to the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) in its efforts to curb or freeze production at a Wednesday meeting.Defensive sectors, such as real estate, consumer staples and utilities, advanced. Most other S&P 500 sectors tracked lower, weighing on ETFs holding the related stocks.However, Technology Select Sector SPDR (XLK) nudged up 0.1%, scoring a fresh high of 48.26 intraday.In total, 13 ETFs focused on diversified exposure to technology stocks or targeted exposure to chipmakers posted 52-week highs. However, trading volume was lackluster and many of these funds closed flat to lower.Among them, iShares PHLX Semiconductor (SOXX) and SPDR S&P Semiconductor (XSD) saw their relative strength (RS) lines pierce new high ground.Retailers Amazon.com (AMZN), Best Buy (BBY), Macy's (M), Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT), Nordstrom (JWN) were in focus as some analysts lowered their holiday outlook on Monday.Tech giants Apple (AAPL) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — as well as their parts suppliers — may benefit from new product releases, including the iPhone 7, MacBook Pro and the Pixel phone.Many retailers, such as Best Buy, offer exceptional bargains on Apple products and other tech items on the Monday following Thanksgiving, known as Cyber Monday.Online retailers like Amazon saw better results than the traditional brick-and-mortar retailers this past holiday weekend, according to the National Retail Federation.IBD'S TAKE: Looking for stocks that are at or near proper buy points? Apple, Amazon, Best Buy, Ulta Beauty are stocks to watch. Some ETFs holding these stocks also are within buy range.Here's a look at the performance of major exchange traded funds across key asset classes on the stock market today.The RS (Relative Price Strength) rating measures a stock's price performance over the last 12 months vs. all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.5%, RS 54PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.2%, RS 54SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.3%, RS 59IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.7%, RS 65IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -1.3%, RS 71IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.5%, RS 31Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.5%, RS 49SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +1.1%, RS 28United States Oil (USO), +1.1%, RS 22IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.4%, RS 31PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.3%, RS 51IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +0.9%, RS 1

Stocks opened lower Monday, as an upgrade to DuPont buffered the Dow Jones industrial average's losses and small caps took some hits.The Dow fell 0.3% as the S&P 500 lost 0.5% and Nasdaq slid 0.6%. The  Russell 2000 was down 0.7%.A broad swath of stocks and industries were in motion on the stock market today in a volatile premarket session.In the Dow industrials, DuPont (DD) rose slightly. The stock received an upgrade from Jefferies to buy, from hold. The upgrade also lifted DuPont's price target to 96, from 83. Dow Chemical (DOW) also received an Jefferies upgrade and price hike — to buy, from hold, and to 75, from 65. Shares also rose a fraction. Dow and DuPont agreed to a merger in December 2015.Snap (SNAP) trekked higher at the open, but then reversed lower to trade down nearly 5%. The high-profile initial offering rose 59% in its first two days of trade last week. Fresh IPOs expected this week include apparel retailer J.Jill, trading as JILL, and tech services company Presidio, with the ticker PSDO.An early 4% jump in natural gas prices helped boost some gas producers. Range Resources (RRC) popped nearly 4%, and Southwestern Energy (SWN) climbed  more than 2%.Two drugmakers spiked in early action.TG Therapeutics (TGTX) nearly doubled in price after announcing positive trial results for its TG-1101 drug targeting high risk Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. The stock reached the highest level in more than a year.Concert Pharmaceuticals (CNCE) soared 78% on news that Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX) would buy Concert's CTP-656 cystic fibrosis treatment in a deal worth as much as $250 million. Concert is climbing from a 15-month correction. Vertex shares were little changed.IBD 50 stock Charles Schwab (SCHW) traded nearly 1% lower. Schwab has been a key player in a fee-price war broken out among brokerages this month. Schwab is consolidating along 10-week support and extended after a breakout in November.Armstrong Flooring (AFI) tumbled 10% at the open. The Lancaster, Pa.-based company reported a mixed fourth-quarter performance and announced a company restructuring.The economic calendar opens the week on a quiet note, with the Commerce Department releasing January factory orders data at 10 a.m. ET, and Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank President Neel Kashkari speaking at 3 p.m. ET.Oil rose 0.3% in early action, leaving West Texas Intermediate trading above $53 a barrel. Gold edged up 0.3% to above $1,233 an ounce. The dollar was mixed, down vs. the yen. The 10-year Treasury yield rose 1 basis point to 2.47%.Europe's markets traded lower in afternoon trade, with the FTSE 100 in London, Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC 40 in Paris each off 0.4%.China's markets gained on Monday: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index added 0.2% and the Shanghai Composite swung up 0.5%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 shed 0.5%.RELATED: Jobs, Oil Chiefs, IPOs, Ulta, Momo: Investing Action Plan

Major stock indexes rallied in the final minutes to close just above break-even, a reasonable performance after comments from Fed chief Janet Yellen reinforced the market's belief that a rate hike is coming at the March 14-15 meeting.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index were just a hair over neutral while the Nasdaq composite climbed nearly 0.2%. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks dipped 0.1%.Declining stocks outnumbered advancers by less than 2-to-1 on both exchanges.Airline and health care names, including biotechs, outperformed. Retailers lagged.United Continental (UAL) and American Airlines (AAL) were top gainers in the group with gains of around 3%.In the stock market today, Snap (SNAP) extended gains after Thursday's strong debut. The company priced at 17 Wednesday night and closed at 24.48 Thursday. Shares rose 10.7% Friday.In the fiber-optic space, Lumentum (LITE) added 2.1% to 46.70. The stock is just above a 44.80 buy point after retracing a double-digit gain from the buy point.IBD'S TAKE: Today's Sector Leaders column takes a look at Lumentum and some other top-performing names in the telecom sector.Meanwhile, one retailer rose and another fell on earnings. Big Lots (BIG) jumped 3.75% to 54.21, clearing a cup-with-handle base with 53.88 buy point.But Costco (COST) gapped down, falling more than 4%, on an earnings miss and disappointing same-store sales. Costco Wholesale (COST) missed fiscal second-quarter earnings and sales forecasts and increased its annual membership fees, which are a major contributor to the retailer's operating income.Estimates: Profit for the February-ended quarter up 10% to $1.36 a share on 6% revenue growth to $29.86 billion, according to Thomson Reuters.Results: EPS of $1.17 on revenue of $29.13 billion. Same-store sales rose 3% in Q2. U.S. comps in February, excluding gasoline, rose 2%, below the 3% gain predicted by Retail Metrics.Effective June 1, annual fees for individual and business memberships in U.S. and Canada will go up by $5. Fees for Executive memberships will go up by $10. Costco sees the changes affecting 35 million members, with about half of them Executive members.Membership fees contributed $2.65 billion to Costco's fiscal 2016 revenue, which totaled $118.7 billion for the year. Those fees accounted for the bulk of Costco's operating income.Stock: Costco sank 4.5% late. Shares closed up less than 0.1% at 177.98 in the stock market today. Costco stock is well out of buy range after clearing a 165.05 entry point from a cup-with-handle base.Why It Matters: For the same reason that TJX (TJX), Burlington Stores (BURL) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) matter — they're all retailers that aren't floundering.Last month, Costco reported 5% in comparable-sales gains for January, excluding currency impacts and gas-price changes, marking the biggest comp-sales gain in over two years. This comes at a time when big-box retailers like Target (TGT) are struggling amid a war with Amazon (AMZN) and other online players.Plus, some on Wall Street are speculating that Costco is mulling another increase to its membership fees. UBS analysts believe a fee hike is "still likely" in 2017, citing Costco's history of raising fees every five or six years.RELATED:Burlington Stores Stock Hits New High On Strong Earnings, OutlookCostco Soars On Biggest Comparable Sales Gain In Over 2 Years

U.S. stock indexes were down modestly Monday, but small caps took a harder hit.The small-cap S&P 600 stumbled 0.9%, which if it holds would be the sharpest loss in about four weeks. Small caps have been leading the current market uptrend. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 trimmed 0.3%, respectively. Volume was sharply higher vs. Friday's half-session pace.The Dow Jones utility average spurted 1.5% higher, while the KBW Nasdaq Bank Index dropped 1.1%. The day's action could be pointing to an adjustment after the Trump rally.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, utilities held most of the day's top spots. On the downside, retail, cement and steel — mostly Trump-tied plays — pulled back the most.Blue chips were mostly down. In the Dow, losers led winners by an 8-3 ratio. UnitedHealth Group (UNH) suffered the biggest loss, down 1.5%. Verizon Communications (VZ) had the biggest gain, up 0.5%. Verizon has mediocre stock ratings, but offers an annualized dividend yield of 4.6%.In the IBD 50, a list of some of the strongest stocks in fundamentals and technicals, small-cap Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP) leapt 6% in huge volume.  The biotech group has been riding high since early November.Sucampo is expected to show 29% earnings growth when final numbers for 2016 roll in. The Street expects earnings growth to accelerate to 40% in 2017. Sucampo is somewhat thinly traded. Average daily dollar volume is $7 million and average daily volume is about 350,000 shares.Under Armour Class C (UAC) shares popped more than 9% to 26.35 while the Class A (UA) shares gained nearly 3% to 31.47. Under Armour said it would change the class A ticker to UAA, while the class C stock would trade as UA, effective Dec. 7.Class C shares have been trading at a wide discount to Class A shares. This is unusual, and could be attracting value investors who regard the Class C shares as undervalued. The Class C shares have no voting rights. Class A shares have voting rights, but that has little to no meaning to growth investors. CEO Kevin Plank holds about 65% of the voting power, thanks to the B shares, which are all Plank's.Under Armour is struggling. The A shares are 34% off their high, and the C shares are 43% off their high.In economic news, the Dallas Fed's manufacturing gauge rose to 8.8 for November, up from 6.7. The general activity index smashed expectations. The Street expected 2.0, but the reading came in at 10.2.RELATED:Trump Factor, Earnings Drive Sucampo HigherWhat To Expect From Ulta Beauty On ThursdayDo These Two Winners Have Anything Left?

U.S. stock indexes tacked on small gains Tuesday, as the market lingered near recent all-time highs.The Nasdaq crept 0.3% higher, while the S&P 500 inched up 0.2%. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average added 0.4% as it crossed the 19,000 level. Volume in the stock market today was about 10% higher on the NYSE and about 7% higher on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.While the indexes haven't been rising in long strides, a number of stocks have been making aggressive moves up or down.In the S&P 500, apparel and accessories retailer Urban Outfitters (URBN) was one of the day's best performers only to undo it after hours. The stock sprinted almost 5% higher in twice its average volume in the regular session. Then the stock dropped about 9% after hours. Urban Outfitters reported quarterly results after the close. The Street's consensus estimate on earnings called for a 5% gain to 44 cents a share. Revenue was pegged at 5% to $869.07 million. The figures came in at 40 cents and $862 million, a double miss, according to preliminary data.On the chart, Urban Outfitters cleared a 37.32 buy point in a shallow double-bottom base a little more than a week ago. The double-bottom base is a pattern that is shaped like a W. The middle peak plus 10 cents becomes the buy point. Urban's 5% buy zone runs to 39.19, which was nearly reached in Tuesday's regular session.A stock should not be bought more than 5% beyond the ideal buy point.Urban Outfitters is recovering from a deep sell-off in 2015, but Tuesday's quarterly results are a setback. The stock's IBD Composite Rating is a respectable 82. The Composite Rating combines all five IBD ratings into a single number. A rating of 82 puts the stock in the top 18 percentile.In the IBD 50, a proxy for highly rated stocks, fast-food chain Jack In The Box (JACK) rose 6% in heavy volume. Jack fell 3% in after-hours trade Monday on quarterly results and weak guidance, but the bulls won Tuesday's battle. Jack retreated 4% in the first five minutes of trade and then reversed higher en route to its 6% gain. The low of the day nearly took Jack to its 50-day line, where it found support and then broke out. As Jack's case illustrates, after-hours trade is not always a reliable guide for a stock's action in the next regular session.Also, in the IBD 50, metal products maker Worthington Industries (WOR) surged 5%, but volume was only average. Meanwhile, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) advanced 3% in volume 30% above average.Blue chips were mostly up. Verizon Communications (VZ) and Home Depot (HD) held the day's biggest gains, 2.5% and 2%, respectively. Verizon is lowly rated, but Home Depot's 94 EPS Rating is the highest in the Dow. A rating of 94 means the stock is growing earnings faster than all but 6% of the stocks in IBD's database.RELATED:Existing Home Sales Strongest Since 2007Marvell Technology: What Is The Chart Really Saying?

Consumers hit the malls, PCs and phones over the holiday weekend for big discounts, but they spent less than a year earlier, the National Retail Federation said Sunday, with more people shopping online than in actual stores.Average spending per person fell 3% to $289.19 vs. 2015, according to a Friday-Saturday NRF survey conducted by Prosper Insights & Analytics."It was a strong weekend for retailers, but an even better weekend for consumers, who took advantage of some really incredible deals," NRF President and CEO Matthew Shay said. "In fact, over one third of shoppers said 100% of their purchases were on sale."The number of shoppers rose to 154 million from 151 million in 2015. That reflected a 4.2% rise in online shopping and a 3.7% drop in-store shopping.Analytics firm RetailNext found that in-store sales tumbled 10.4% on Black Friday.The NRF survey found that 44% shopped online and 40% went in-store.Thanksgiving and Black Friday online sales rose 18% to $5.27 billion, according to a separate survey by Adobe Digital Insights, higher than the $5.05 billion expected.Apple (AAPL) products, notably discounted Apple iPads and some Macbooks, were among the big Black Friday sellers online, Adobe said. While Apple did take part in Black Friday directly this year, Best Buy (BBY) and Target (TGT) were generally seen as having better online deals.IBD'S TAKE: Looking for stocks that are at or near proper buy points? Apple, Amazon, Best Buy, Ulta Beauty are stocks to watch.The continuing shift to online should be good news for Amazon, which has dominated e-commerce growth in recent years. Amazon said Thursday-Friday sales would top a year earlier, but that's not really a surprise. Eight of the 10 retailers that had the fastest e-commerce growth were brick-and-mortar locations.Target was bullish about Thursday-Friday sales generally.With deals more widely available throughout November and December, Thanksgiving weekend may be less important. That could explain why the average consumer said they reduced spending this year.Just 9% of consumers have finished holiday shopping, down from 11% a year ago, NRF said. And 23% have yet to do any gift buying, up from 19%."With mid-season shopping behind us, it's not too late for retailers to tweak their online and in-store strategies to help increase traffic and see a big payoff during the last few weeks of the holiday season," Shay said.Next up is Cyber Monday. But with online deals so omnipresent already, how much buzz can retailers generate for this traditional online shopping day? Wal-Mart (WMT) launched its "Cyber Monday" deals at the crack of midnight on Friday.

GrubHub (GRUB), Panera Bread (PNRA), Whole Foods Market (WFM), Cognizant Technology (CTSH) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) were flagged by analysts Thursday.Mizuho downgraded the stock to neutral from buy and trimmed its price target to 42 from 45. The online food delivery service provider fell short of fourth-quarter earnings estimates on Wednesday but beat revenue forecasts slightly.Shares fell 4.2% to 38.20 in the stock market today. But shares shot up nearly 9% Wednesday to 232.90, blasting out of a cup-with-handle base with a 218.10 buy point.Panera shares fell 0.7% to 231.18.RELATED:Panera Bread, Yum China, Pioneer Earnings Top, Buffalo Misses After HoursTelsey Advisory Group, which has a market perform rating on the upscale grocery store chain, trimmed its price goal to 28 from 30. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) said that it will form a new holding company, effective Sunday — the start of its new fiscal year — and that Ulta Beauty, Inc. will replace Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance, Inc. as the publicly traded entity. Outstanding shares of common stock will be automatically converted. The stock's ticker, directors and executive officers are all unchanged.The main goal of the reorganization is "to create a more efficient corporate structure," said the company in a release.Shares fell 0.4% to close at 271.44 on the stock market today. On Thursday, Ulta hit 273.99 intraday, matching its all-time high. The stock has a buy point at 274.09.Ulta is broadly regarded as a top-notch retail stock that has been able to weather an often challenging environment and rivals such as Amazon.com (AMZN). Last month, the company logged a beat-and-raise quarter that included 16.7% same-store sales growth, an exceptional figure among retailers.IBD'S TAKE: What's holding Amazon back from eating into Sephora and Ulta's market share? For an in-depth look, read: "Why Amazon Has Been Powerless Against Beauty Stores."RELATED:What's Driving The Success Of 'Un-Amazon-Able' Ulta Beauty?

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) stock gapped above its 50-day line Thursday after raising its third-quarter and fiscal 2016 earnings estimates and predicted growth in the low 20s percentage range for 2017, 2018 and 2019.The beauty retailer, which is also holding an analyst and investor day Thursday, now sees Q3 EPS of $1.35-$1.38, up from prior guidance of $1.25-$1.30. Analysts see $1.30.Ulta also lifted its forecast for Q3 comparable sales growth, including e-commerce sales, to 14%-15% from guidance of 11%-13%, and up from a year-ago gain of 12.8%.For 2016, the company now sees comp sales growth of 12%-14%, including e-commerce, compared with previous guidance of 11%-13%, and expects EPS growth in the mid-20s percentage range vs. previous guidance of low to mid-20s percentage. Analysts see 25% growth.In addition to guiding 2017-2019 EPS growth above 20%, Ulta sees comparable sales growth of 7%-9% for that period, up from prior guidance of 5%-7%.Ulta jumped 11.4% to 266.14 on the stock market today, retaking its 50-day line for the first time since giving earnings guidance in late August that was a little light.IBD'S TAKE: Ulta stock plunged in August on its Q3 guidance, but a bullish indicator on the company's shares could have been seen on insider purchases following the market dive.

Ulta also its raised outlook for U.S. store expansion to a range of 1,400-1,700 from 1,200 and said it plans to discuss its goal to double market share over the next several years.RELATED:This Slide Explains Why Amazon Hasn't Been Able To Knock Ulta BeautyE.l.f. Black Friday. Cyber Monday. Super Saturday. The annual retail running of the bulls is a treacherous terrain of sharpened elbows and trigger-happy mouse clicks for shoppers trying to get the best deal possible.The stakes are even higher for the stores themselves: The National Retail Federation has said that sales in November and December can account for anywhere from 20%-40% of a retailer's yearly sales. Perhaps fortunately for department stores like Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS) and others, there's nowhere to go but up this Christmas."Given the fact that last year was so horrible, the comps are easy," said Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar.As weather, inventory issues, heavy discounting and e-commerce giants like Amazon (AMZN) weighed, Macy's reported a 4.7% same-store sales decline in November and December of last year. Kohl's Q4 2015 comps edged up a mere 0.4%. Overall, last year's holiday retail sales disappointed with only 3% growth, said the NRF, less than expected.Holiday 2016 should prove to be a little less dire. The NRF predicts a 3.6% retail gain in November and December to $655.8 billion; online sales are seen rising 7%-10% to $117 billion. And retailers are feeling bullish. Target (TGT), Macy's and Nordstrom (JWN) all raised guidance going into the all-important shopping season.Predictably, online sales continue to eat into brick-and-mortar market share. Traditional stores are again gearing up to do battle with Amazon and friends.Wal-Mart (WMT) is pushing up its "Cyber Week" deals from Monday to Friday so that they start essentially the minute Thanksgiving Day is over. Target's "10 Days of Deals," which include both in-store and online promotions, already started on Saturday."If you look at the companies that reported earnings, it's e-commerce that's driving a significant amount of the growth," said Weishaar. "What's unique in it is mobile is becoming a higher penetration of the digital section, so that would be something new. I don't think a lot of the companies have figured out how to convert the sales on mobile."Shopping via smartphone is the next frontier. Thanksgiving Day and Christmas are projected to be the biggest mobile-shopping days of the year, said Adobe.One consequence of a ramp-up in retail digital wars, however, is that fewer people head into brick-and-mortar shops.Retail Metrics head Ken Perkins says the industry could see a "significant slowdown" in Black Friday foot traffic.Traffic fell in the mid-single to high-single-digits on Black Friday 2015, and retailers could see an equal or even greater decline this time around, he said, particularly as other shopping events during the year dilute the impact of the post-Thanksgiving sales day.Besides Cyber Monday and Super Saturday, the menu of existing shopping holidays has grown to include Amazon's Prime Day and even China-based Singles Day, among others.Foursquare's data are a little more optimistic; the company predicts a 3.5% year-over-year slide in Black Friday foot traffic, which would be "far less severe" than the prior year's figures."The importance of Black Friday from a traffic (perspective) to brick-and-mortar stores is going to continue to decelerate," said Weishaar. "With more people shopping online, the one specific day becomes less important."IBD'S TAKE: Adobe data indicate that Black Friday sales will be the "biggest ever," growing 11.3% from last year to $3.05 billion in sales. For a look at what else is happening this week, check out IBD's Investing Action Plan. Broadly speaking, inventory levels are cleaner in Q4, which translates to more targeted, strategic discounting instead of promotional wars, said Weishaar. But even in the absence of "everything must go"-type sales, that doesn't mean that consumers shouldn't expect to see a whole lot of deals floating around.Which retail names will be winners this year?Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel pointed out in a recent note that execs at various retailers have alluded to a challenging, promotional holiday season. But there are gems to be found."Although the election triggered a surprising sense of hope (and short squeezes), we believe much uncertainty remains and would rather buy quality companies that have lagged," he wrote, calling out Ulta Beauty (ULTA) as his top pick and noting that the recent Lululemon Athletica (LULU), HBI and Kate Spade (KATE) sell-offs look "interesting."Still shining is the off-price sector, as consumers remain hesitant about paying full retail for products and stores have a tough time escaping the "always-on-sale" cycle. Athletic wear also continues to dominate street fashion.Nike (NKE), TJX (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST) remain Siegel's long-term choices.Holiday shoppers, unconcerned about the fate of retail stores, will continue to like what they like.Millennials, who favor experiences over tangible goods, may not be retailers' favorite customers. But PwC research found that the teen set, Generation Z, likes "stuff — and shopping in stores.""To them, stuff matters," said the report. "Stuff like personal electronics, clothes, shoes, and toys. Which is what they're hoping to receive this holiday season."RELATED:Black Friday Is The New Cyber Monday: Wal-Mart Pushes Up Sale
