Stocks rallied into the close Friday, fueled by a strong November job report that seemed to clear the path for a Fed rate hike at the Dec. 15-16 meeting.

The major indexes recovered their Thursday losses and then some, as the Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average each rose 2.1% while the S&P 500 gained 2%. Volume was slightly lower on both main exchanges, according to preliminary data.
Winners topped losers by nearly 2-to-1 on both exchanges. The Dow was green across the board, with tech heavyweights Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) leading with gains of more than 3% each.
Specialty retail, airlines and builders were among the top gainers in the stock market today. The specialty retail group jumped 7%, primarily due to a 13% jump by Ulta Beauty (ULTA).

The beauty store and salon operator also led IBD 50 stocks as it gapped up and vaulted to a new high. Shares cleared a base after the beauty store operator reported quarterly results that topped views late Thursday.

Fellow IBD 50 stock Alaska Air (ALK) soared 5% in fast trade, marking a new high. The stock is still in buy range from the 82.88 buy point of a late-stage flat base initially cleared Wednesday. Hawaiian (HA) lifted 3%.

Among new issues, Fitbit (FIT) jumped into action with a 10% surge in twice the usual pace. It rallied 14% for the week as it continues to move off its Nov. 23 intraday low. Fitbit shipped 4.7 million units worldwide in Q3 to remain the top vendor of wearables, which includes smartwatches and fitness tracking devices, according to an IDC report released Thursday.
Energy stocks sagged as OPEC surprised at a meeting in Vienna by deciding to keep output at current near-record levels. West Texas intermediate crude prices fell more than 3% to $39.97 a barrel.
Railroads and shipping stocks also declined.

Investors were not in a buying mood Monday; instead, the market suffered a bout of moderate selling. The Nasdaq gave up 0.4%, closing near the lows of the day. But the index again found support near 5100 and continued the mostly sideways movement seen for more than a week. The S&P 500 fell 0.5% after giving up a 0.2%…

Stocks further weakened and were near session lows in early afternoon trading Monday.The Nasdaq was the worst off, down 0.4% after being up as much as 0.3% earlier. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 fell about 0.2% each. At just before 1 p.m. ET, trade was running sharply higher across the board from Friday's pace.Retail stocks were weak Monday following initial data from retail analytics provider ShopperTrak that showed sales at brick and mortar stores for Thanksgiving and black Friday slipped from a year ago.Shares of Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT) fell nearly 2% each. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reversed to a loss of more than 2%. It reports Q3 results after Thursday's close.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) gapped below its 50-day line and dropped 5% after FBR & Co. downgraded shares to underperform from market perform and cut its price target to 42 from 55.Four of the day's 10 worst-performing groups were from the retail space.Elsewhere, Cambrex (CBM) turned a gain of nearly 4% into a loss of more than 1%. It's now nearly back to a 52.68 buy point from a cup-with-handle base cleared Wednesday. The stock touched an all-time high earlier in the stock market today.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

The major indexes traded at session highs Wednesday afternoon, building on the week's rebound. The S&P 500 led with a 1% gain as the energy sector led and continued to bounce back. The Nasdaq climbed 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%.

Volume was tracking higher across the board. If that holds up, it would be the first advance in higher volume since last Wednesday's 1.5% gain in the S&P 500. Winners led losers by more than 6-to-1 on the NYSE and by 5-to-2 on the Nasdaq.
Bright Horizons Family Solutions (BFAM) rallied more than 5%. The stock rose back above its 50-day moving average and won back the 66.62 buy point of a breakout in November.

Walt Disney (DIS) fell to the lowest level since Oct. 9 as a downdraft continued. The media company is in talks to sell its 50% stake in the Fusion cable TV venture to its partner, Univision Communications, Bloomberg reported.
Despite a record box office for "Star Wars: The Force Awakens," the entertainment company's shares have been sinking since the weekend debut.

UPS (UPS) fell 1% in active trading and remained deep in a correction. News reports said Amazon.com (AMZN), the shipping company's largest account, is growing more frustrated with UPS and is looking for other shipment methods to reduce its reliance on UPS.

Thinly traded China Lodging Group (HTHT) broke out of a choppy base, rising past a 31.08 buy point in heavy volume. The fastest-growing hotel operator in China on Monday set a one-time dividend of 17 cents per ordinary share, or 68 cents per American Depositary Share.The major indexes traded at session highs Wednesday afternoon, building on the week's rebound. Stock futures rumbled higher ahead of Friday's open, rebounding from a tough session on Thursday and boosted by better-than-expected November payroll data.

Dow futures swept 112.3 points above fair market value, better than doubling their gains over the prior hour. Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 futures also doubled up, rising 21.3 points and 13.5 points, respectively.

The stock market today opens with the Nasdaq down 1.8% and the S&P 500 off 1.9% this week. The Nasdaq remains above its 200-day moving average. The S&P 500 broke that line of support on Thursday and tacked toward a possible test of support at its 50-day line.

Growth of U.S. nonfarm payrolls slowed less than expected in November, the Labor Department reported, as employers added 211,000 workers. That was down from an upwardly revised 298,000 new jobs in October, but comfortably above the 190,000 hirings forecast by economist consensus.

Private employers added 197,000 of those workers, above expectations for 185,000. The unemployment rate flew straight and level at 5%, the labor participation rate inched up a click to 62.5% and average hourly earnings showed a 0.2% gain — in line with expectations.

The Commerce Department noted that the trade deficit widened slightly in October to $43.9 billion. That was vs. an upwardly revised $42.5 billion gap in September and counter to analyst expectations for a slight improvement in the deficit to $40.6 billion.

Oil prices bumped up 1%, leaving West Texas Intermediate at $41 to $42 a barrel and Brent crude above $44 as the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries began its policy meeting in Vienna. No change in the group's production quota is expected. In addition, Baker-Hughes (BHI) releases its closely watched rig count, which tracks U.S. drilling activity, at 1 p.m. ET.
Dow stocks were nearly unanimously positive, but gains were slim. Exxon Mobil (XOM) topped the crew with a 0.7% gain.
Retailers buzzed in mixed early action.

Five Below (FIVE) bounced 9% after delivering solid Q3 results. IBD 50 stock Ulta Beauty (ULTA) teased up a 7% gain after topping analyst consensus sales and earnings expectations in a third-quarter report late Thursday. Premarket gains often disappear at the start of regular trade. If Ulta's gain holds after the starting bell, it would remain just below a 175.88 early buy point in a flat base.

Gap (GPS) dropped almost 5% ahead of the open after reporting same-store-sales at its Old Navy brand stores fell 9% in November vs. an 18% increase in Nov. 2014. Same-store-sales at the Banana Republic chain dropped 19% vs. last year's 2% increase.
Surf/skate-style sportswear chain Zumiez (ZUMZ) tumbled 14% after a solid Q3 earnings beat wasn't enough to counter weak Q4 guidance.

Beyond retail, feverishly volatile biotech KaloBios (KBIO) spiked 30% in premarket trade. The San Francisco-based developer of blood and tumor treatments announced it had raised $8.2 million in a private placement of stock, named an interim chief financial officer and said it would pay $2 million to acquire the benznidazole program for the treatment of Chagas Disease from privately held Savant Neglected Diseases.
KaloBios shares rose nearly 1,600% in December — from less than $2 per share. They are down 10% since the start of December.
Tire maker Cooper (COO) flattened 20% after its fiscal Q4 revenue and earnings came in below consensus forecasts, and management lowered its Q1 guidance.
Ulta Salon easily led the IBD 50 list of stocks in premarket trade. Gains and losses among other stocks on the IBD 50 and Your Weekly Review lists were mild, generally holding to less than 1%.

Overseas markets were predominately negative Friday. Leading indexes in Paris, Frankfurt and London were down less than 1% near midday. Markets across Asia fell hard in reaction to the monetary policy decision by the European Central Bank that sent markets in the U.S. and Europe lower on Thursday. The Shanghai Composite dropped 1.7%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index shed 0.8%. Shares of G-III Apparel (GIII) moved sharply higher Wednesday on better-than-expected quarterly earnings, even though the clothing manufacturer fell short on revenue and lowered its full-year profit guidance on the expectation that fourth-quarter spending and traffic will be weak. Reporting before the open, G-III posted adjusted earnings of $1.85 a share for its fiscal third quarter, which ended in October.…

Stocks rallied across much of the session Friday, as a strong November jobs report overpowered a sharp pullback in oil prices and many energy stocks. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 both popped 2.1%. Preliminary data showed those moves carrying in weak trade.The gains took back the losses from Thursday, triggered by a disappointing monetary policy decision from the European Central Bank.For the week, the results left the Nasdaq up 0.3%, while the S&P 500 was a fraction higher and back above its 200-day moving average.Before the open, the Labor Department's payroll report showed a bigger-than-expected jump in November payrolls, backing views that the economy is on an even and mending keel, appearing to clear the path for a Fed rate hike at the Dec. 15-16 meeting.The Dow ended Friday up 2.1%, unanimously positive. Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT) and Home Depot (HD) topped the index, each with 3% gains.Gold miner Newmont Mining (NEM) led the S&P 500, up more than 9%. Troubled utility NRG (NRG) staked out the index's low end with an 18% decline.Among leaders, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) easily topped the IBD 50 list, surging 13% after posting strong Q3 results late Thursday. The gap-up gain snapped shares past an early 175.88 buy point in a three-month base. The stock ended less than 5% above the entry.Fellow IBD 50 stock Alaska Air (ALK) soared 5% in fast trade, marking a new high. The stock is still in buy range from the 82.88 buy point of a late-stage flat base initially cleared Wednesday. Hawaiian (HA) lifted 3%.China-based NetEase (NTES) also rocketed 5%, seizing a fresh high and ending 16% past a 154.62 buy point.Among new issues, Fitbit (FIT) jumped into action with a 10% surge in twice the usual pace. It rallied 14% for the week as it continues to move off its Nov. 23 intraday low. Fitbit shipped 4.7 million units worldwide in Q3 to remain the top vendor of wearables, which include smartwatches and fitness tracking devices, according to an IDC report released Thursday.For next week, the earnings calendar continues to lighten, with United Natural Foods (UNFI), Mattress Firm (MFRM), H&R Block (HRB) and HealthEquity (HQY) scheduled to report Monday. The economic calendar also gets a quiet start, with a speech by St. Louis Fed President James Bullard marking the high point for day.

Sephora and Ulta (ULTA) are stealing market share from CVS (CVS) and other drugstores as teens gravitate toward "authentic indie" brands, according to Piper Jaffray's latest Taking Stock With Teens survey, out late Tuesday.Mass beauty brands are ceding share to indie brands and labels that get social media backing, said analysts. A quick peek on Facebook's (FB) Instagram yields about 885,000 results for #Revlon and fewer than 499,000 for #CoverGirl — both drugstore brands — but more than 2.5 million results for #UrbanDecay, a popular cosmetics label that can be purchased at both Ulta and Sephora.CoverGirl has steadily slipped down the rankings with upper-income female teens, falling to fourth place from second place, year over year, while Urban Decay's share has risen with all teen girls.Tied to that is the increased preference for specialty beauty retailers. Sephora nabbed a significant 38% chunk in Piper Jaffray's latest survey, climbing from 19% in the spring and up from 22% in fall 2014's poll among upper-income teenage girls. Sephora is owned by LVMH, which trades on the Paris exchange.While Target (TGT) took top honors in the spring, Ulta knocked it down to third place this fall, taking the No. 2 spot behind Sephora with 19% share of the vote, up from 13% last year. Target has 14% share.Drugstores that mostly carry mass beauty brands have also slipped down the rankings. CVS ceded about half its share, sliding to 6% at the No. 4 spot from 14% in the spring and 13% last fall. Wal-Mart (WMT) and Walgreens (WBA) have also slipped down the Top 10 list over the last 12 months.Ulta has a solid history of double-digit earnings and revenue gains, and has a strong IBD Composite Rating of 96. Piper Jaffray carries an overweight rating on the stock.Ulta shares closed down 2.8% to 159.26 in the stock market today. CVS fell 1.6% and Target fell 3.5%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Ulta Beauty Delivers Great-Looking Growth.

Since the S&P 500 put in a follow-through signal Oct. 2, there's been no shortage of buying opportunities. Many leading stocks have staged breakouts day after day. Many leaders such as Hawaiian Holdings (HA), Manhattan Associates (MANH) and Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) have already grabbed nice gains. Universal Holdings (UVE) is also in that boat, but it broke out…

The major indexes reversed lower for a second straight session Wednesday. And this time, neither the oil patch nor the commodities sector was to blame. The Nasdaq composite wasted a modest early gain and ended off 0.3%, adding to Tuesday's 0.9% decline. Big gains by biotechs and chip firms stunted the slide. The Philly SOX soared 3.8%. The S&P 500…
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) shares are looking for support at a key level.

The stock cleared a flat base buy point in late January and hit an 18% gain as well as an all-time high of 158.97 on April 24. Shares have been trading relatively tight for about two months and are now trying to find support at the 50-day line, a key area of support.
Ulta is expected to report fiscal first-quarter earnings next month. Analysts expect the beauty products supplier's bottom line to grow 21%.
Peer Sally Beauty (SBH) is working on a price consolidation with a 35.37 buy point. The stock was recently able to find support at the 200-day line.

European bourses ended with strong gains Wednesday and U.S. stocks followed suit on news Greece is nearing a debt deal.

In early afternoon trading, the Nasdaq rallied 1%, the S&P 500 added 0.7% and while the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.

Wednesday's gains came one day after the put/call volume ratio closed at 1.01. The reading indicated some fear in the market during Tuesday's decline. Excessive fear has been seen in the past just before market rallies.
Airlines, chipmakers and tobacco stocks outperformed Wednesday. Solar stocks lagged.

July crude oil was trading around $57.87 a barrel, down 16 cents. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note rose 2 basis points to 2.16%. On the NYSE, advancing stocks topped decliners by a 2-1 ratio. The ratio was less than 2-to-1 on the Nasdaq.
Among the day's gainers, fast growing Acadia Healthcare (ACHC) surged nearly 7% in strong volume. It's trying to clear a 74.19 buy point.

Market leader Palo Alto Networks (PANW) slipped just over 1% ahead of its earnings report after the close. Profit is seen rising 900% from a year ago to 20 cents a share. Palo Alto sells at a triple digit multiple but it's arguably justified because full-year earnings are seen rising 136% in fiscal 2015 and 99% in fiscal 2016.
Leaderboard name Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rallied 3% in strong volume ahead of its earnings report Thursday after the close. It's back above its 50-day moving average.
Epam Systems (EPAM) drew closer to a 70.59 buy point. Shares were volatile during the week ended May 22 when the company reported earnings, but the stock has recovered nicely since then.

Learning to recognize and read the correct stock chart patterns (IBD calls them "bases") is, among other things, a process of assessing risk. Many stock bases come with one or more flaws. This means their length, depth or some other element falls short of the rules that IBD research has shown characterize the bases that preceded many of the stock market's biggest winners.
Among the most important and easiest elements to gauge is the position of the handle within a cup-with-handle base.
The rule says the midpoint price of the handle must be above the midpoint of the left-side decline of the overall base.
This simply means that the mathematical halfway point between the highest and lowest marks of the handle must be higher than the halfway point between the base's left-side high and its lowest price.
Consider the recent base built by CyberArk Software (CYBR). Using a daily chart, you can see the stock marked the left-side high of the pattern at 70.48 on Feb. 20.
The Israel-based security software developer hit a low of 47.51 on March 16. Add these two numbers together, divide by two and you get a midpoint of 58.99.

The handle started with a left-side high of 62.98 on April 8 and ended with a low of 56.87 on April 14. Add them and divide by two. This tells you the handle midpoint is 59.92, above the overall base's 58.99.
This shows the handle is in a healthy position. The stock formed its handle after spending enough time building the right side of the base as institutional demand for the stock grew.
You can stack the numbers like this:
Plot your buy point by adding a dime to the handle's left-side high. In this case, that's 62.98, so the buy point is 63.08.

Ulta Beauty's (ULTA) recent yearlong base's left side high started at 132.72 in November 2013. It hit a low of 80.35 in January. The handle started with a 121.43 high in the week ended Sept. 26. It dipped 12% in four weeks, to a 106.87 low.

Adding the base's high and low and dividing by two gives you a midpoint of 106.53. Do the same for the handle and you get a midpoint of 114.15, plenty high enough to make the buy point valid at 121.53.
The number grid looks like this:
A handle or buy point that is slightly low can sometimes work. But the breakout will carry added risk of a breakdown.
In any case, you'd like your breakout to come with a big gain in strong volume.

Also, a correct midpoint for your handle does not assume the base's other characteristics are in order. The base's total decline, top to bottom, should generally be less than 35%. If it has a handle, the base itself should be at least seven weeks long from left-side high to breakout.

The handle itself should be no more than 8%-12% deep in a normal market uptrend, and you'd really like to see it drifting lower in dwindling trade. Rising or volatile trade in the handle, and a handle that wedges higher rather than lower, are potent flaws.Learning to recognize and read the correct stock chart patterns (IBD calls them "bases") is, among other things, a process of assessing risk. Many stock bases come with one or more flaws. Cosmetics retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) is holding tight near an all-time high despite the market's recent decline. It's also near a buy point. The stock has shaped a 3-weeks-tight pattern with an entry at 156.10. It was less than 5% below the buy point Wednesday. The 3-weeks-tight structure lets existing shareholders add a small number of shares to their positions,…

Canaccord Genuity sees continued growth for real estate investment trusts that own shopping centers housing big national retailers. "Based on anecdotes from retail executives and store growth plans for 2016 and beyond, we see leading tenants targeting growth averaging in the mid-single digits, providing support for higher portfolio occupancies and market rents in 2016, as well as generating selective opportunities…

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) lost ground Wednesday but ended well off its session low amid a volatile day in the market. The stock is still sitting pretty overall in a market that is experiencing wild swings. Wednesday's pullback in flat turnover puts the stock back in buying range from a 159.95 buy point in a flat base cleared on July 8.…

Stocks overcame an afternoon dip to finish near their highs of the day, putting the Nasdaq back in positive territory for the year. After the close, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) turned heads by reporting EPS of $1.15 a share vs. estimates of $1.12. Revenue came in at $877 million vs. estimates of $870.25. The stock was up sharply in after-hours trading.The Nasdaq rose 2.5%, the S&P 500 gained 2.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average ramped up 2.3% in the stock market today . Volume was lighter than Wednesday on both main exchanges, according to preliminary data.Among IBD 50 stocks, 43 were higher and seven were lower. The top performer was Sucampo Pharmaceuticals (SCMP), which galloped 14%. It announced that it would buy 58% of Japan's R-Tech Ueno for $278 million. Multiple analysts raised price targets.Oil rose 10% and rallied back above $40 after a global stock market rally and encouraging economic reports forced short sellers out of their positions.Overnight, the Chinese government bought shares late in the session, pushing the Shanghai Composite 5% higher for its first gain in five sessions.A bigger-than-expected upward revision to second-quarter GDP helped stocks get off to a strong start.Before the open Friday, the Bureau of Economic Analysis will release July figures for consumer spending and personal income. Both are expected to increase 0.4%.At 10 a.m. ET, the final University of Michigan consumer sentiment reading is expected to be 93.3, up from the 92.9 midmonth preliminary reading.Follow Ken Hoover on Twitter: @IBD_KHoover.
Looking ahead to the next bull market, Facebook (FB) and Apple (AAPL) chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) are among the highly rated stocks that are well placed to soar when conditions improve.
Not that they won't fall when the market corrects. That's why corrections are fine times to push money to the sidelines and create watch lists.

It's important to focus on newer companies like these because IBD research repeatedly shows that stocks tend to make their biggest price moves in the early stages of their lives, then plateau as they mature. The stocks listed below went public within the past 15 years.
Facebook Challenges Siri

Last week, the Menlo Park, Calif.-based social media titan unveiled M, a personal virtual assistant on its Messenger platform, which can help users with everything from restaurant reservations to buying gifts.
The new service puts Facebook in direct competition against Apple's virtual assistant, Siri. The service currently is only available to select customers in the San Francisco area.
Meanwhile, Mizuho analyst Neil Doshi wrote in a report last week that the current market downturn provides an excellent buying opportunity for quality Internet stocks such as Facebook.
Facebook has an "unmatched" audience on the Web, though it may be nearing saturation with ads on mobile, Doshi said.
The company's shares currently are trading between their 50- and 200-day moving averages and are up 11.8% so far in 2015. They survived Tuesday's sell-off, falling 2.5% to 87.23.
Facebook's current IBD Composite Rating is 97 out of 99, meaning it is outperforming 97% of all publicly traded companies.
Avago Earns Confidence

Avago Technologies reported record results from its third quarter, earning $2.24 a share excluding items, up 78% from a year earlier and beating views by 10 cents. Revenue rose 37% to $1.74 bil, roughly in line with analysts' expectations.
Avago, jointly headquartered in Singapore and San Jose, Calif., is a supplier for Apple, which has scheduled an event next week to unveil its iPhone 6s and iPhone 6s Plus models.

Although there has been some worry on Wall Street about possibly waning demand for the new Apple iPhone models, Avago CEO Hock Tan guided investors to double-digit sequential growth for the company's wireless business.
Wireless demand continues to be robust but is "curtailed by a lack of capacity," said RBC Capital Markets analyst Amit Daryanani in a report.
He rates Avago's stock as overweight and kept his price target at 150.

Meanwhile, Pacific Crest Securities analyst John Vinh said increased capacity of FBAR (filters used in cellphones to allow only specific frequencies to be transmitted) is a positive for Avago's participation in the upcoming Apple smartphones.
Avago shares are up 18.7% so far this year, though they fell 5.2% Tuesday to 119.37, just below their 200-day moving average. The company's IBD Composite Rating is 94.
The Decade Of Chipotle?

Though midterm growth drivers may be murky, the Denver-based fast-casual behemoth Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) has a long runway for growth, lasting at least 10 years, said Wedbush analyst Nick Setyan.
Unit opportunity is "far from saturated" and new-unit ROI is rising, Setyan noted in a report last week.
The company's shares have held steadily above their 50-day moving average since July, and have risen 3.2% so far this year. Shares fell 0.5% Tuesday to 706.71.
Chipotle has an IBD Composite Rating of 97.
Ulta Touches Up Guidance
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) disclosed second-quarter earnings last week, with EPS surging 22.3% to $1.15, beating forecasts by 3 cents. Sales jumped 19.4% to $877 million, topping estimates of $869.8 million.
The Bolingbrook, Ill.-based company raised full-year EPS growth guidance to the high teens, compared to its prior guidance at the high end of the range of 15% to 17%.
Ulta raised full-year same-store sales guidance to a growth range of 8% to 10%, up from the earlier 7% to 9%.
The company's shares have risen 20.3% so far this year, trading between their 50- and 200-day moving averages. But shares fell 2.7% Tuesday to 153.76.
Still, Ulta's IBD Composite Rating is a pretty 96.

Stocks turned mixed near midday Monday amid a round of similarly mixed earnings reports, as well as economic reports both foreign and domestic.

The Nasdaq turned a 0.4% loss into a 0.3% gain. Biotechs and software issues outperformed. The S&P 500 pared a 0.5% deficit to 0.1%, while the Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%. Volume was tracking sharply lower across the board in the stock market today compared to the same time Friday.

Among highly rated stocks,Globant (GLOB) rallied nearly 4% to an all-time high and cleared a 35.10 buy point in heavy trading. About two hours into the session, the thin stock already matched its 50-day average volume.

Nike (NKE) climbed more than 1% to another new high after being upgraded to buy from hold at BB&T. It's now 12% past a 117.82 buy point. The athletic apparel and footwear giant was recently mentioned in the New Highs column.

On the downside, Microsemi (MSCC) dropped 6% on news that it offered $2.2 billion to buy PMC-Sierra (PMCS). Its bid topped a $2 billion buyout offer by Apple (AAPL) supplier Skyworks Solutions (SWKS). Microsemi fell below a 37.51 buy point from a consolidation cleared Friday. PMC shares jumped 14%.

Valeant (VRX) slumped 6% despite beating views and raising guidance. Before the open, the Canadian drugmaker posted adjusted Q3 earnings of $2.74 a share, up from $2.11 a year ago. Sales grew 36%, the third straight period of acceleration, to almost $2.79 billion. It lifted its full-year sales forecast to $11 billion-$11.2 billion from $10.7 billion-$11.1 billion.

Profit is now expected at $11.67 to $11.87 a share, up from a prior outlook of $11.50 to $11.80. Last week, Valeant said it received subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Massachusetts and New York, requesting information about its patient-assistance programs and drug-pricing decisions.

U.S. stocks followed the lead of overseas markets Wednesday. European bourses rallied nicely on news that Greece is nearing a deal with international creditors.
The Nasdaq rallied 0.9%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each added 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Tuesday's levels.

The gains came one day after the put/call volume ratio hit 1.01. The reading indicated some fear in the market during Tuesday's decline. Excessive fear has been seen in the past just before market rallies.
In the stock market today, Ford (F) added 0.7% despite news the company is recalling more than 400,000 vehicles because of potential issues with power-assisted steering.
Meanwhile, technology names led the Dow higher about two hours into the session. Microsoft (MSFT), IBM (IBM), Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Apple (AAPL) all rose 1% or more.
Fast growing Acadia Healthcare (ACHC) surged nearly 7% in strong volume. It crossed a 74.19 buy point early but was just below it.
Leaderboard name Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rallied nearly 3% in strong volume ahead of its earnings report Thursday after the close. It's back above its 50-day moving average.
On the downside, Workday (WDAY) slumped 11% despite a narrower-than-expected loss and another quarter of strong sales growth.

Michael Kors (KORS), meanwhile, cratered 23% after the company reported another quarter of decelerating earnings and sales growth. The company's outlook also left much to be desired. Kors has been in a downtrend for about one year due to deteriorating fundamentals.U.S. stocks followed the lead of overseas markets Wednesday. Stocks powered to fresh highs going into the last hour of trading Thursday. Volume picked up with the S&P 500 near a new all-time high and the Nasdaq closing in on the mark it set March 10, 2000, the day the dot-com bubble burst.The Nasdaq was up 0.6%, trading near 5065, above its 5048.62 record close and just below the 5132.52 intraday high of 15 years ago.The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each rose 0.4%. The S&P 500 was trading near 2117, just below the 2119.59 all-time high set Feb. 25.Volume was higher on both exchanges in the stock market today.The market overcame a soft open, regrouped and moved higher on the back of solid earnings reports from leading growth companies. Those earnings reports helped investors overcome fears, at least temporarily, of poor results from big global companies hurt by a rising dollar.Among IBD 50 stocks, 32 were up and 18 were down. The top performer was Domino's Pizza (DPZ), which gapped out of a flat base, rising 8%. Q1 earnings and revenue, which were reported before the open, had beat estimates.Other IBD 50 names making significant gains were drugmaker Akorn (AKRX), up 3%, and Ulta Beauty (ULTA), up 2%. Ulta, a Leaderboard stock, moved past a 156.10 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern. Three- and four-week-tight patterns are secondary buy points where shares can be added to an existing position.Not every IBD 50 name had a good day. Cognex (CGNX) was off nearly 5%, gapping down after Oppenheimer downgraded shares to perform from outperform. But the stock found support at its 50-day moving average and was off its worst level of the day.

Stocks rebounded confidently Wednesday, with the indexes erasing all or part of the previous session's losses. The Nasdaq jumped 1.5%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average skipped higher to the tune of 0.9% and 0.7% respectively. The small-cap Russell 2000 gained 1.1%. Volume in the stock market today ran higher on the Nasdaq but lower on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Blue chips rallied, with about a dozen stocks in the 30-stock Dow gaining 1% or more. Microsoft (MSFT) and Intel (INTC) led with gains of 2.4% and 2.2% respectively. Both Microsoft and Intel have so-so fundamentals.
Top-rated stocks, though, also showed strength. Breakouts included chip designer Avago Technologies (AVGO) and drug developer AbbVie (ABBV).

New highs among top-rated stocks included Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK); chip designers Ambarella (AMBA), NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) and Silicon Motion Technology (SIMO); hospital chain Universal Health Services (UHS); drugmaker Zoetis (ZTS); aerospace play Spirit AeroSystems (SPR); TV station chain Gray Television (GTN); and pizza restaurant Papa John's International (PZZA).
Two other leaders showed positive action: retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) retook its 50-day line in strong volume, and Illumina (ILMN) climbed close to a buy point in a consolidation.
Overall, the abundance of top stocks showing good action was an encouraging development for the stock market uptrend.

Companies reporting quarterly results included apparel marketer Michael Kors (KORS), which gapped down 23% on an earnings miss and a weak outlook, and homebuilder Toll Bros. (TOL), which skidded 2% on a revenue miss combined with an earnings beat.

Stock futures spun to deep losses ahead of Friday's open, as further oil price declines continued to pressure global markets. Dow futures dived 172.8 points below fair market value and had held steady over the prior hour.

Nasdaq 100 futures dropped 36.5 points, slightly off their hour-earlier lows. S&P 500 futures were steady, down 18 points. Small caps were taking their share of the heat, with Russell 2000 futures down 14.1 points.

The stock market today took its early licks from oil prices, which backed down nearly 2% after the International Energy Agency confirmed prior forecasts that 2016 average demand growth for oil will slow to 1.2 million barrels a day from the estimated average of 1.8 million bpd this year.
West Texas Intermediate held just above $36 a barrel and Brent crude traded a tad above $39; both were down more than 9% for the week.

The news release and oil price drop hit after markets closed in Asia, but Europe's stocks pulled back sharply. The DAX in Frankfurt was down 1.9%, and the CAC-40 and FTSE 100 in London were down more than 1% each near midday. All are tracking toward losses of more than 3% this week. China's markets closed with moderate losses. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan gained 1%.

In U.S. economic news, producer prices rose 0.3% in November, the Labor Department reported. That was up from a 0.4% slip in October and well above expectations for no change. Core prices, minus food and energy, also rose 0.3%, above views for a 0.1% uptick.

November retail stopped just short of expectations, rising 0.2% — better than October's 0.1% gain but below views for 0.3%. Autos and gas were a negative for the month. Stripping out those categories, sales rose 0.5%, topping forecasts for a 0.3% gain.

At 10 a.m. ET, October business inventories numbers from the Commerce Department are due out, and the University of Michigan releases its December Consumer Sentiment Index. Oil prices might get a stir after 1 p.m., when Baker Hughes (BHI) is scheduled to report its weekly rig count.

Stocks listed on the Dow Jones industrial average were nearly unanimously negative before the open. DuPont (DD) again sank to the bottom, with a 4% decline, after announcing it formally agreed to merge with Dow Chemical (DOW), creating DowDuPont — a $130 billion chemical juggernaut. The companies expect the deal to close late next year.

A large share of downward pressure on the S&P 500 were energy-related stocks. But the contest for the index's worst premarket decline was among DuPont, Staples (SPLS) and Red Hat (RHT), all down in the 4% to 5% range.

At the top of the list, glass maker Corning (GLW) surged 8% on news of the Dow/DuPont deal, under which Dow Chemical will assume 100% ownership of Dow Corning, a 50/50 joint venture between Dow Chemical and Corning.

Adobe Systems (ADBE) popped 5% after delivering a solid fiscal fourth-quarter report late Thursday. Earnings were above expectations, revenue in line and Q1 guidance below consensus forecasts. But strong growth in the company's cloud-based business and a rise in recurring revenue, to 74% of Adobe's total take, pleased investors.
The stock ended Thursday in a test of support at its 10-week moving average, its first test since clearing a cup-with-handle base in October.
Fiber optic networking gear maker Finisar (FNSR) spiked 13% after a healthy fiscal Q2 report. The stock ended Thursday deep in a six-month consolidation.

The DAX in Frankfurt was down 1.9%, and the CAC-40 and FTSE 100 in London were down more than 1% each near midday. All are tracking toward losses of more than 3% this week. China's markets closed with moderate losses. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 in Japan gained 1%.In U.S. economic news, producer prices rose 0.3% in November, the Labor Department reported. That was up from a 0.4% slip in October and well above expectations for no change. Core prices, minus food and energy, also rose 0.3%, above views for a 0.1% uptick.November retail stopped just short of expectations, rising 0.2% — better than October's 0.1% gain but below views for 0.3%. Autos and gas were a negative for the month. Stripping out those categories, sales rose 0.5%, topping forecasts for a 0.3% gain.At 10 a.m. ET, October business inventories numbers from the Commerce Department are due out, and the University of Michigan releases its December Consumer Sentiment Index. Oil prices might get a stir after 1 p.m., when Baker Hughes (BHI) is scheduled to report its weekly rig count.Stocks listed on the Dow Jones industrial average were nearly unanimously negative before the open. DuPont (DD) again sank to the bottom, with a 4% decline, after announcing it formally agreed to merge with Dow Chemical (DOW), creating DowDuPont — a $130 billion chemical juggernaut. The companies expect the deal to close late next year.A large share of downward pressure on the S&P 500 were energy-related stocks. But the contest for the index's worst premarket decline was among DuPont, Staples (SPLS) and Red Hat (RHT), all down in the 4% to 5% range.At the top of the list, glass maker Corning (GLW) surged 8% on news of the Dow/DuPont deal, under which Dow Chemical will assume 100% ownership of Dow Corning, a 50/50 joint venture between Dow Chemical and Corning.Adobe Systems (ADBE) popped 5% after delivering a solid fiscal fourth-quarter report late Thursday. Earnings were above expectations, revenue in line and Q1 guidance below consensus forecasts. But strong growth in the company's cloud-based business and a rise in recurring revenue, to 74% of Adobe's total take, pleased investors.The stock ended Thursday in a test of support at its 10-week moving average, its first test since clearing a cup-with-handle base in October.Fiber optic networking gear maker Finisar (FNSR) spiked 13% after a healthy fiscal Q2 report. The stock ended Thursday deep in a six-month consolidation.Follow Alan Elliott on Twitter @IBD_AELliott and on Facebook.

The stock market closed lower Monday as retailers had a bumpy session. The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.4%, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.5%.Volume rose, which was no surprise after Friday's half session. Declining stocks led advancers by 9-to-7 on the NYSE and 9-to-8 on the Nasdaq in the stock market today.Transportation, medical and some retail industry groups were among the weakest Monday. Energy and mining stocks were some of the strongest.Lululemon Athletica (LULU) gapped down to a 9% loss, sinking right back below its 50-day moving average. An analyst at FBR Capital Markets downgraded Lululemon to underperform from market perform and cut the price target to 42 from 55.Investors grew pessimistic about the early holiday shopping indications. Other retailers that sold off in heavy trading included Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Urban Outfitters (URBN).Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) had the worst loss on the IBD 50, down about 3%. A breakout bid past a 588.15 buy point has unraveled.After the close, UnitedHealth Group (UNH) said that it is backing its forecast of earnings of about $6 a share in 2015 and $7.10 to $7.30 for 2016. Revenues for 2016 are projected to be $180 billion to $181 billion.The health insurer warned Nov. 19 of an earnings hit from its ObamaCare exchange-related business, citing higher medical costs from its individual market customers and a soft enrollment outlook.UnitedHealth shares rose slightly in extended trading.Several economic reports are due out Tuesday. Manufacturing reports from purchasing managers and the Institute for Supply Management are due out in the morning. Automakers will report their November sales.Earnings reports Tuesday include Fifth Street Finance (FSC) and Guidewire Software (GWRE).Follow Juan Carlos Arancibia on Twitter @IBD_JArancibia.

A wide array of retail and apparel stocks are due to report quarterly earnings next week just as the holiday shopping season begins in earnest, with Ulta Beauty (ULTA), American Eagle Outfitters (AEO), G-III Apparel (GIII) and Express (EXPR) leading the way.The reports come at a time when third-quarter retail sales have been so-so at best. Earlier this month the Commerce Department said retail sales edged up 0.1% in October after being unchanged in both September and August, according to Reuters. Economists had expected October sales to rise 0.3%.Among the bigger and better performing stocks due to report next week, clothing manufacturer G-III kicks things off when it posts fiscal third-quarter results before the open on Dec. 2.G-III — whose licensed brands include Calvin Klein, Levi's and Kenneth Cole — is expected to log earnings of $1.78 a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. That's up from $1.55 the prior year. Sales are seen rising 12% to $912.9 million.If those results hold up, it would mark the third straight quarter of double-digit or better sales and earnings growth at G-III. The company's stock price spent the first half of 2015 pushing upward — reaching a new high of 73.93 on July 13 — but has since trailed off and currently trades near 48.American Eagle is due to report after the close on Dec. 2. Analysts expect earnings of 34 cents a share, up 55% from a year earlier. Sales are expected to climb 8% to $925.8 million.Following a turnaround plan announced last year, the youth apparel chain has now reported four straight quarters of double-digit or better per-share earnings growth following a six-quarter string of double-digit declines.Ulta and Express are both due to report fiscal third-quarter results after the close on Dec. 3.Ulta has been one of the better performers in the retail sector. It boasts an IBD Composite Rating of 95 out of a possible 99 and a years-long streak of double-digit sales and earnings growth, helped by the introduction of high-end brands like Lancome and Clinique and a move to remodel stores and increase its marketing and technology spending.Analysts expect Ulta to post a 15% gain in fiscal Q3 earnings to $1.05 a share, with sales rising 18% to $880.3 million. Ulta's stock price sank 8.4% to 155.20 on Nov. 13 as part of a broader selloff of retail stocks, but it has since bounced back and currently trades near 170.Express, which operates more than 600 women's and men's apparel and accessories stores in the U.S., has produced strong per-share earnings growth in the past couple of quarters following a five-quarter streak of lower earnings.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Express to report third-quarter earnings of 29 cents a share, up 71% from the prior year. Sales are seen rising 9% to $541.4 million.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

Let's take a look at four highly rated stocks near buy points: Monster Beverage (MNST), LinkedIn (LNKD), D.R. Horton (DHI) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA). Monster Beverage has a 98 IBD Composite Rating. When it reported quarterly earnings earlier this month, Monster topped estimates for both the top and bottom lines. The energy drink maker is benefiting from its new global…

Stocks stabbed lower Friday as the Nasdaq joined the S&P 500 in falling under the 200-day moving average . The Nasdaq dropped 1.5%, its third loss of 1% or more during the week. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 lost 1.2% and 1.1%, respectively. The IBD 50 skidded 1.9%. Volume rose across the board. The Nasdaq punctured its…
Stocks stumbled in mixed trade for a second straight morning Wednesday, as global markets reacted to monetary policy actions by the European Central Bank.
The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average sat flat, while the S&P 500 and Russell 2000 each dipped 0.1%.
The stock market today again opened to mixed volume, with trade rising 9% on the NYSE and declining fractionally on the Nasdaq, vs. action at the same time Wednesday.

Before the open, U.S. stock futures had appeared to feel some premarket drag from Europe's bourses, which reversed sharply from moderate gains after the European Central Bank announced it would further reduce its overnight deposit rate to -0.3%, from -0.2%.
The move was less than what many had been led to expect by previous comments from ECB President Mario Draghi and other officials.

Europe's markets did not improve when, in a later press conference, Draghi said the bank would extend its current bond buying initiative to March 2017 or longer if necessary, vs. the prior endpoint of September 2016.
Frankfurt's DAX dropped 2.7%. The Cac-40 in Paris was down 2.9%, and outside the eurozone, the FTSE 100 in London slipped 1.9% in afternoon trade.
Layoffs fell to a 14-month low in November, consultant Challenger, Gray & Christmas reported, and weekly jobless claims rose, but in line with the consensus forecast.
Factory orders strengthened 1.5% in October, the Commerce Department said, up from a 0.8% slip in September and better than the 1.4% improvement expected by analysts.

The Institute for Supply Management said growth in the services portion of the economy slowed in November, with its ISM Services index falling to 55.9, down from October's 59.1 reading. Analysts had forecast a smaller pullback, to 58.2.

Dow stocks turned negative after the open, with more than two-thirds of the 30-stock index posting losses. Merck (MRK) and American Express (AXP) took the biggest bumps, down about 1% apiece. Gains were thin, led by Wal-Mart's (WMT) 1.6% advance.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) spiked more than 10% to the top of both the IBD 50 list and the S&P 500, following its fiscal-fourth-quarter results reported late Wednesday. Research firms Mizuho and Topeka Capital both raised their price targets on the stock Thursday morning.
The gain left Avago shares well up the right side of a five-month cup base, below a 150.60 buy point.

Biotech Dyax (DYAX) vaulted 12% higher, as the company announced the early termination of the anti-trust waiting period regarding its pending $5.9 billion acquisition by Ireland-based Shire (SHPG). Shire dipped 1.9% at the open.

Utilities were unusually active at the start of trade, with NRG (NRG) rising nearly 8% after President and Chief Executive David Crane tendered his immediate resignation, though the shares later lost most of the gain to trade almost flat. Chief Operating Officer Mauricio Gutierrez will step into the role.
The power producer on Tuesday announced plans to sell two power plants in Pennsylvania and Illinois for a total of $138 million. NRG has been in a deepening correction for 17 months.

Stocks were higher but falling off opening highs going into the lunch hour Wednesday as an analyst upgrade propelled Google above a key support level.The Nasdaq advanced 1.4% and the S&P 500 rose 1.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.4% in the stock market today. Volume was running heavier on the NYSE and lighter on the Nasdaq, compared with the same time Tuesday.The Shanghai Composite fell 1.3% overnight. For the week so far, it's down 16.6%. The People's Bank of China cut interest rates by 25 basis points to 4.6% on Tuesday.In a speech and Q&A Wednesday, New York Fed's William Dudley said the case for a September interest rate increase was "less compelling" because of a slowdown in China, falling commodity prices and gyrations in the financial markets.Among IBD 50 stocks, 39 were higher and 11 were lower. Google (GOOGL) was the top performer on the elite list, up more than 3%. Goldman Sachs upgraded the stock to conviction buy from neutral and boosted its price target to 800 from 660. It trades near 632. The move put Google back above its 10-week moving average.The analysts said Google is "in the early stages of a multiyear cycle to expand margins, which will drive earnings outperformance and multiple expansion."Universal Insurance (UVE) was the worst performer, down 6%. It was losing support at its 200-day moving average in above-average volume.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2%. It's found support at its 200-day line and trying to steady itself after a wild ride Monday that saw the stock range 36% from low to high. It still trades below its 50-day line.Homebuilder D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 1% in above-average volume as it struggled for support at its 50-day line and was trading near a 28.80 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Before the open, durable goods orders beat expectations, giving stock index futures a quick boost.

Whew. What a week. After falling as much as 9%, the Nasdaq notched a weekly gain of 2.6%. Upside reversals seen in both the Nasdaq and S&P 500 had the look of capitulation which is often seen at market bottoms, but the market remains in a correction until proven otherwise. After dropping as much 12%, the IBD 50 added 1.5%…
Stocks attempted a valiant comeback Monday morning with the major indexes trading in the upper half of their daily trading range. But it was accelerating going into the lunch hour.

The Nasdaq was down 0.9%; the S&P 500 was off 1.4%, and the Dow Jones industrial average was 1.2% off in the stock market today. Volume was running higher than Friday's already swollen volume on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq exchanges.
On the NYSE, 95% of stocks were down. Nearly 88% were lower on the Nasdaq. There were more than 1,200 new lows on the NYSE and more than 650 on the Nasdaq.
Bonds soared, bringing the yield on the 10-year Treasury note to just over 2%.
Oil dropped nearly 4% to a new six-year low. The dollar was down sharply, and the euro rose in a corresponding fashion.
The put-call ratio was 1.38. Readings above 1.15 indicate high levels of fear. It closed Friday at 1.48.
Overnight, the Shanghai Composite dropped 8.5%, setting off a chain reaction in global markets. The Chinese index is now 38% off a high set June 12.
Among IBD 50 stocks, one was higher and 49 were lower. United Therapeutics (UTHR) was the lone gainer amid the carnage, up nearly 3%. It might be building a late-stage base.
Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) also braved the selling to trade 4% higher.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) was down just 3% after being down 26% near the open. It reports Q2 results after the close Thursday. Analysts forecast EPS of $1.12, a 19% increase from a year earlier.Stocks attempted a valiant comeback Monday morning with the major indexes trading in the upper half of their daily trading range. Did spending on cosmetics and skin-care products heat up along with the weather the past few months? Investors will get an idea when Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reports second-quarter results on Thursday after the closing bell.

Ulta, an IBD Leaderboard stock, has logged 19 straight quarters of double-digit sales and earnings growth. The bets are in it kept up its winning streak in the second quarter, but at a slower pace than the prior quarter. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect second-quarter earnings to rise 19% to $1.12 a share. Though the growth would be less than the 35% increase it saw in the first quarter, it's still a healthy gain. They see sales rising 18.4% to $869.33 million, which would be slightly less than the 22% gain in the prior quarter.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) Sales | FindTheCompany
Ulta is a one-stop shop for beauty and salon products at a variety of prices.

The company offers more than 20,000 products, from high-priced so-called prestige brands sold in department stores and specialty stores to lower-priced labels sold via the mass channel, including drugstores and discounters. It has a full service hair salon in stores.

Ulta has stayed on top of its game by regularly rolling out new products and brands while enhancing its service and shopping experience. It also boasts an attractive customer loyalty program that keeps drawing new members.
Utlta Beauty shares hit a record high on Tuesday, but pulled back as the market retreated.

Ulta is part of IBD's Retail-Specialty industry group. The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 97. Other highly rated members of the group include Ritchie Bros. With earnings season nearing the end, the following IBD 50 stocks have seen the biggest leaps forward in earnings per share on an annual basis.PaycomPaycom Software (PAYC) provides human resource and payroll applications to companies looking to take advantage of cloud computing.The Oklahoma City-based company notched 150% EPS growth during the second quarter compared to a year earlier — 67% higher than analysts forecast. Revenue jumped 47% to $49 million.Mostly small and midsize companies use Paycom's software to manage payroll and human resources activity. It covers everything from hiring to retirement.The Affordable Care Act has added more complexity, especially to health benefits processing. That's put Paycom on a fast growth path as its cloud-based products help companies manage the changes under the health law.Third-quarter revenue guidance was given in the range of $51 million to $52 million with full-year revenue range raised to $210 million to $212 million, up from the previous range of $203 million to $205 million.Paycom shares have surged more than 40% so far this calendar year and the company has a Composite Rating of 97. Its record high of 41.58 was reached on Tuesday.TesoroThe collapse in crude oil prices has helped lower input costs for refiners like Tesoro (TSO), which grew its EPS by 172% compared to a year earlier.According to a Barclays research note on Aug. 7, U.S. and global refining margins continued to march higher in Q2, significantly topping market expectations and building on an already impressive Q1.And in the U.S. market, July margins were higher than even May, which is typically the strongest month.Until Friday, San Antonio-based Tesoro had been trading above its 50-day average since July 1, and it has a Composite Rating of 83. The stock reached a record high of 110.74 on Aug. 13.WisdomTreeWisdomTree Investments (WETF) is a New York-based exchange-traded fund with more than $60 billion in assets under management. It posted a 100% EPS gain in Q2 compared with Q2 of 2014.Earlier this month, WisdomTree had its price target raised to 31 from 23 at Jefferies, which cited organic growth and operating profitability, with an expected interest rate hike and a strong macroeconomic background also contributing.Its shares are up by roughly one-third so far this year and WisdomTree has a Composite Rating of 94. It fell below its 50-day average on Thursday, though still trades above its 200-day moving average. The fund hit a record high of 26.23 on Aug. 5.One of the few remaining IBD 50 stocks that has yet to report is Ulta Beauty (ULTA). When results come out Thursday, analysts expect EPS to climb 19% to $1.12 with sales up 18% to $869.3 million.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter: @IBD_CMcEvoy.

Two Sector Leaders cleared buy points Wednesday, but backed off by the close. Fleetmatics Group (FLTX) jumped as much as 7% early before trimming gains. Volume was heavy early as well, but trailed off. It was the second time in recent weeks that the stock traded above a 45.72 three-weeks-tight entry point. Fleetmatics also found support in a trip to…

Hollywood has its A-list of top actors. This week's Weekly Review list features its own cast of A-list stocks — those with strong fundamentals and technicals — that are building bases despite a market uptrend that remains under pressure. Akorn (AKRX) is nearing the top of a seven-week base with a 55.96 buy point, which began forming after a 19%…
The Nasdaq reached an all-time closing high Thursday, while Google (GOOG) and Amazon.com (AMZN) were higher after hours after issuing Q1 reports.
The Nasdaq closed at 5056.06, a 0.4% gain. That edged above the 5048.62 closing high marked 15 years ago. It's still below the 5132.52 intraday record.
The S&P 500 was up 0.2%, a smidgen below its all-time high, and the Dow Jones industrial average was up 0.1%. Volume was higher across the board, according to preliminary data.
Amazon reported a 12-cent-per-share loss, a penny better than expected. Revenue was $22.72 billion vs. the consensus estimate of $22.43 billion.
Google missed analyst estimates of $6.61 a share with a report of $6.57. Revenue was below estimates of $17.49 coming in at $17.27.
Among IBD 50 stocks in the stock market today, 31 were up and 18 were down with one unchanged.
Domino's Pizza (DPZ) gapped out of a flat base, rising 9%. Q1 earnings and revenue, which were reported before the open, beat estimates.

Drugmaker Akorn (AKRX) was up 4% and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) up 2%. Ulta, a Leaderboard stock, moved past a 156.10 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern. Three- and four-week-tight patterns are secondary buy points where shares can be added to an existing position.

Cognex (CGNX) was off nearly 5%, gapping down after Oppenheimer downgraded shares to perform from outperform. But the stock found support at its 50-day moving average and closed off its worst level of the day.
Before the open Friday, the Census Bureau releases durable goods orders for March. Economists forecast a 0.5% increase vs. a 1.4% drop in February.

Also before the open, Biogen (BIIB) reports earnings. The biotech leader is expected to report EPS of $3.91 a share, 58% above a year ago. Fast selling clobbered the major stock indexes Friday, ratcheting up the pressure on the uptrend. The Nasdaq and the Dow Jones industrial average each careened 1.5% lower, while the S&P 500 lost 1.1%. The IBD 50 fell 1.3%. Volume rose across the board, fueled in part by options expirations. The Nasdaq gapped down to its 50-day average, where it's now…

After sputtering in 2014, AB Discovery Growth Fund has resumed firing on all cylinders. The small- to midcap growth fund was up 7.61% for the year going into Tuesday vs. 6.67% for its midcap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Inc. and the S&P 500's 2.22% return. Last year, the mutual fund lagged well behind the broad market, returning just 2.76%,…

Express (EXPR) shares opened higher but quickly reversed in spite of strong third-quarter earnings and guidance driven by restrained promotional activity and inventory management. Other retail stocks also slumped. Retail Metrics' Ken Perkins attributed the sector weakness to broader concerns about consumer spending in the apparel space amid a highly promotional season. "While we expect the holiday season to remain…
A sell-off in retail stocks weighed on the major averages near midday Friday after October retail sales data missed expectations. Another big drop in oil prices didn't help matters.

The Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq each lost 0.8%. The S&P 500 gave up 0.7%. Small caps held up relatively well, with the Russell 2000 down only 0.3%. Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Thursday's levels in the stock market today. Volume on the NYSE was tracking close to Thursday's level.

Retail sales rose 0.1% in October, below the consensus estimate of 0.3%. Excluding autos, sales rose 0.2%, also below expectations of 0.4%. Of the 10 worst-performing groups in the market Friday, eight hailed from the retail sector.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, December crude oil futures slumped 2.4% to $40.77 a barrel. On Thursday, the U.S. government reported the seventh straight weekly increase in crude supplies.
On the downside, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) was in need of a makeover as shares slumped 6% in heavy volume. Earnings are due Dec. 3.
Other leading retail stocks were pressured, including Signet Jewelers (SIG), down 3% and Restoration Hardware (RH), down 4%.

On the heels of the terrorist attacks in Paris, the general thinking was that Monday would be a rough day for the stock market. But that wasn't the case, as stocks strengthened in early-afternoon trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 added around 0.7% each. The Nasdaq rose 0.4%. Volume on both exchanges was tracking well below Friday's levels in the stock market today.
In economic news, the New York Fed's Empire State Manufacturing Index registered a reading of -10.74 in November, below the consensus estimate of -5. New orders fell for the sixth straight month.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note was down 2 basis points to 2.25%.
Online travel firms, department stores, biotechs and airline stocks lagged badly.
Priceline (PCLN) slumped nearly 5%, bringing its seven-day decline to 15%. Shares fell hard on Nov. 9 after the company's earnings report included disappointing guidance

Urban Outfitters (URBN) cratered 9% after the company announced plans to acquire the Vetri Family restaurant group. The deal isn't a huge surprise because Urban has been making a big push in recent years to integrate food and dining into its stores.

Among the day's gainers, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) bounced back after Friday's retail sell-off. Shares rose 2% in strong volume, but last week's 10% decline in higher volume caused technical damage that will most likely take some time to repair.

Inside the IBD 50, China-based Noah Holdings (NOAH) looked poised to halt a five-session slide ahead of its earnings report after the close. Shares rose 5%. Fellow China name TAL Education (XRS) also gained ground in the IBD 50, as shares rose 1%. It cleared a 38.75 cup-with-handle buy point last week.

Sector Leader Regeneron (REGN) held up well despite softness in the biotech group Monday. Shares rose 1%. After a low-volume breakout, it's added a handle area to its double-bottom base, giving a new entry of 588.15.
In M&A news, Marriott (MAR) agreed to buy Starwood Hotels (HOT) for $12.2 billion Shares of Starwood shed more than 5%. Marriott eased 0.4%.

Friday the 13th was shaping up to be a bad day for stocks, which extended their losses going into the final hour of the regular trading session. The Nasdaq sank 1.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average shed 0.9% and the S&P 500 fell 0.8%.
Volume was tracking higher across the board vs. the same time Friday. Losers outpaced winners by 3-to-2 on the NYSE and the Nasdaq.
A wide range of retailers topped the losers list in the stock market today, while biotechs, generic drug makers and other medical stocks outperformed.

Big-cap techs weighed on the Dow, as Cisco Systems (CSCO) gapped down and sank 6%, breaking below its 50-day moving average in heavy trade. The networking gear giant late Thursday reported fiscal Q1 results that topped views, but its Q2 guidance disappointed. RBC Capital cut its price target to 30 from 33.
Apple (AAPL) fell 2%, slicing its 50-day line for the first time since regaining it Oct. 20. The iPhone maker's Apple Watch hasn't been a big hit, and related concerns sent other stocks down.

Watchmaker Fossil (FOSL) gapped down and plunged 35% to a five-year low after reporting mixed Q3 results and lowering its 2015 earnings outlook. Fossil said it's buying Misfit, a rival to Apple Watch and Fitbit (FIT), for $260 million, marking its entry into the wearable tech market.

Fitbit, the leading fitness tracking device maker, was having a bad day too. Shares of the new issue gapped down and slumped 14% in fast trade to a record low. The company priced a follow-on stock offering at 29 a share. It downsized the number of shares it's selling to 3 million from 7 million.

Another new issue, Planet Fitness (PLNT), gapped up and leapt 9% in big volume after reporting Q3 earnings that topped views Thursday after the close. The stock made an early run after its Aug. 6 IPO, but is 21% off its high.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Paycom Software (PAYC) were the biggest decliners on the IBD 50 , down 8% and 6%, respectively. Paycom late Thursday priced a 4.5 million share offering at 42.15.

Hoping to simultaneously bolster online sales and foot traffic in their brick-and-mortar locations, prominent department store chains and other retailers are aggressively shifting to omnichannel commerce. This form of retailing blends in-store and online shopping in a way that — if done successfully — taps into consumers' increasing penchant to check out new products online, particularly apparel, while capitalizing on…
The term "fast casual" conjures up a certain image in the restaurant industry — eateries that serve fresh food at affordable prices but without full table service.
Beyond that, there are vast differences.
At one end of the spectrum are "burger in a bag" restaurants, as Kevin Miles calls them. These places specialize in fresh-made burgers, hand-cut fries and soft drinks.
At the other end are restaurants that focus on wholesome fare that is free of additives and preservatives, and offer choices for customers on vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free diets.
That's the end occupied by Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES), where Miles serves as CEO.

Zoe's specializes in healthy, freshly prepared Mediterranean food such as chicken pita sandwiches, hummus, kabobs, salads and tabouli. Although it occupies a place in the fast-casual universe, several things set Zoe's apart from the usual crowd.
For one thing, much of its competition comes from outside the traditional fast-casual sector.

Although Miles sees Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Panera Bread (PNRA) as his rivals, "there are a few in the space that we don't see as direct competitors, such as burger or pizza restaurants. When our customers aren't eating at Zoe's, they are eating at Whole Foods (WFM) or at 'better-for-you' grocers."

Another thing that sets Zoe's apart is the fact that it serves beer and wine. Most of the large fast casual chains don't. And unlike most chains, customers at Zoe's have food brought to their tables after they order at the cash register.
Upscale Appeal

Zoe's clientele also sets it apart. Women make up about 70% of customers, according to a recent note from analyst Stephen Anderson of Miller Tabak. Its core customer base is composed of college-educated women in the 25-to-54 age group who come from households with at least $100,000 in annual income.
"Women are our predominant consumer because most of the dining decisions are made by women," CEO Miles told IBD.
Because Zoe's gets most of its business from women, it tends to locate restaurants where the women are.

Analyst Anderson notes that the company "seeks co-tenancy with retail chains catering to more affluent women with active lifestyles, such as Lululemon (LULU), Ulta (ULTA) and Ann Taylor (ANN) . Zoe's also seeks properties with high concentrations of offices nearby to sustain daytime traffic."
Finally, the way Zoe's picks its markets is also different from the industry norm.

The company uses a "hub and spoke" strategy whereby it locates a major U.S. market — the hub — and then "spokes out" new locations from there. Most restaurant chains base their locations on local population density metrics.
Where Zoe's Goes
Miles points to the Dallas metro area as an example of its hub and spoke strategy. The company has 14 locations in the Dallas metro area and can probably expand to as many as 50 locations, he says.

"That's a huge concentration of locations, so from there we could spoke out to locations an hour or so from Dallas," Miles said. "We could manage it from Dallas and be able to penetrate a lot of surrounding markets and bring a lot of efficiencies. We've done that in a lot of markets, including Atlanta, Charlotte (N.C.) and Jacksonville (Fla.)."

As of March 12, Zoe's had 140 restaurants in 15 states, including three franchises. Most are located in Southern states such as Texas, Georgia, Alabama, North Carolina and Virginia, though it will soon move into the Kansas City metro area, which will put it in both Kansas and Missouri.
The vast majority of its restaurants — about 90%, according to Anderson — are located in shopping centers rather than as stand-alone locations.
The company has delivered robust overall sales growth through the years thanks to an aggressive expansion plan. It opened 30 company-owned restaurants last year and acquired five franchise units.
Anderson looks for management "to ease back to a high-teens to low-20% unit growth rate through the end of this decade, followed by 15% unit growth thereafter."
Most of its near-term growth will take place in or near existing markets, Miles says.
Food And Finance

During its fourth quarter, Zoe's opened six company-owned restaurants and acquired three franchises. It logged overall Q4 sales of $40 million, up 40% from a year earlier and slightly above consensus views. Comparable-restaurant sales increased 7.8%.
The company posted a loss of 3 cents a share on an adjusted basis, better than the 5-cent shortfall that analysts had expected and vs. a 6-cent loss a year earlier.
For 2015, Zoe's expects revenue of $215 million to $220 million. The company guided 2015 comparable-restaurant sales growth to a range of between 4% and 6%, down from 2014's 6.7% gain.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year EPS of 6 cents in 2015 and 16 cents in 2016.

Like many restaurant chains, Zoe's got hit last year by rising costs of chicken and other food items, Miles says. He expects the company's cost of goods to decline "ever so slightly" this year as it gets bigger and as the company gains more buying power.

"A few years ago, we were too small to have much purchasing power, but that's not the case anymore," Miles said. "We will continue to leverage our size with manufacturers and distributors" to lower food costs.
Progress Since IPO
The restaurant chain had its initial public offering last April, priced at 15 a share. Zoe's stock rose as high as 38.42 on Oct. 31 and currently trades near 33.

The company has an IBD Composite Rating of 82. It belongs to IBD's Retail-Restaurants group, which ranks No. 9 out of 197 industries tracked. Top-rated stocks in the group include Fiesta Restaurant Group (FRGI), Denny's (DENN) and Nathan's Famous (NATH).The term "fast casual" conjures up a certain image in the restaurant industry — eateries that serve fresh food at affordable prices but without full table service.Beyond that, there are vast differences.At one end of the spectrum are "burger in a bag" restaurants, as Kevin Miles calls them. These places specialize in fresh-made burgers, hand-cut fries and soft drinks.At the other end are restaurants that focus on wholesome fare that is free of additives and preservatives, and offer choices for customers on vegetarian, vegan and gluten-free diets.That's the end occupied by Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES), where Miles serves as CEO.Zoe's specializes in healthy, freshly prepared Mediterranean food such as chicken pita sandwiches, hummus, kabobs, salads and tabouli. Although it occupies a place in the fast-casual universe, several things set Zoe's apart from the usual crowd.For one thing, much of its competition comes from outside the traditional fast-casual sector.Although Miles sees Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) and Panera Bread (PNRA) as his rivals, "there are a few in the space that we don't see as direct competitors, such as burger or pizza restaurants. When our customers aren't eating at Zoe's, they are eating at Whole Foods (WFM) or at 'better-for-you' grocers."Another thing that sets Zoe's apart is the fact that it serves beer and wine. Most of the large fast casual chains don't. And unlike most chains, customers at Zoe's have food brought to their tables after they order at the cash register.Upscale AppealZoe's clientele also sets it apart. Women make up about 70% of customers, according to a recent note from analyst Stephen Anderson of Miller Tabak. Its core customer base is composed of college-educated women in the 25-to-54 age group who come from households with at least $100,000 in annual income."Women are our predominant consumer because most of the dining decisions are made by women," CEO Miles told IBD.Because Zoe's gets most of its business from women, it tends to locate restaurants where the women are.Analyst Anderson notes that the company "seeks co-tenancy with retail chains catering to more affluent women with active lifestyles, such as Lululemon (LULU), Ulta (ULTA) and Ann Taylor (ANN) . Most restaurant chains base their locations on local population density metrics.Where Zoe's GoesMiles points to the Dallas metro area as an example of its hub and spoke strategy. The company has 14 locations in the Dallas metro area and can probably expand to as many as 50 locations, he says."That's a huge concentration of locations, so from there we could spoke out to locations an hour or so from Dallas," Miles said. We've done that in a lot of markets, including Atlanta, Charlotte (N.C.) and Jacksonville (Fla.)."As of March 12, Zoe's had 140 restaurants in 15 states, including three franchises. Stocks drifted into a Friday the 13th trading session in weak volume, opening lower after disappointing economic news.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.7%. The S&P 500 fell 0.5% and the Nasdaq shed 0.3%.

The stock market today steered lower just after the release of February producer price data. The data showed a fourth straight pullback in prices received by businesses, surprising consensus views for a modest gain. That is good for consumers but shows weak pricing power for sellers. It is a data point that could potentially ease pressure on the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates.

Consumer sentiment was also below par, as the University of Michigan's initial Consumer Sentiment Index reading for March dropped to 91.2. That was a giant step down from February's 95.4 tally and even further below consensus expectations for a step up to 96.
Trade was generally modest among S&P 500 stocks.GameStop (GME) posted the index's largest gain, up nearly 3%. Allegheny Technologies (ATI) marked the list's worst decline, with a 5% loss.

Chip stocks continued what has been a wild week, with NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) jumping nearly 4%. Needham & Co. initiated coverage with a strong buy rating and a 140 price target. The Netherlands-based chip developer is now 30% past a 78.44 flat base buy point from an early January breakout.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) surged 6% to the head of the IBD 50 list after healthier-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings, revenue and same-store sales.Stocks drifted into a Friday the 13th trading session in weak volume, opening lower after disappointing economic news.The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.7%. The stock market lost ground Friday, but a late-afternoon rally attempt cut losses. Volume rose, according to preliminary data. Crude oil dropped 4%, sending energy stocks lower. Energy-related industry groups were among the day's worst performers. The dollar rose sharply, and the euro fell below $1.05, which hurt global companies.
The Nasdaq dropped 0.4%; the S&P 500 lost 0.6% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.8% in the stock market today.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) was one of the day's winners, gapping up and finishing nearly 4% higher after reporting better-than-expected earnings.
Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), both Dow components, fell less than 1% but were well off session lows.

Before the market opens Monday, the Federal Reserve will release the Empire State Manufacturing Index and the Industrial Production and Capacity Utilization numbers for February. At 10 a.m. the housing market index is released.

Stocks ended firmly in the red Friday. On the plus side, buyers came in late and lifted major averages off session lows.

The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.8%, the S&P 500 gave up 0.6% and the Nasdaq eased 0.4%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume coming in higher than Thursday's levels. For the week, the Dow lost 0.6%; the S&P 500 fell 0.9% and the Nasdaq gave up 1.1%.

Life above the 50-day moving average was short-lived for the two NYSE-related indexes. The S&P 500 and the Dow retook their 50-day lines Thursday and then promptly sliced back under them Friday. The Nasdaq so far has stayed above its 50-day line.
The 50-day line is often an area where funds step in to offer support in bullish environments. In bearish climates, the same line turns into resistance as funds lighten up near the line.

April crude oil slumped again, falling $2.21 to $44.84 a barrel. It cratered 9.6% for the week. Earlier today, the International Energy Agency said that a glut of oil could cause prices to weaken further.

In the IBD 50, a proxy for top-rated stocks, the biggest percentage winner was retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA), up nearly 4% in torrid turnover. It reported strong earnings late Thursday. The biggest loser was mobile fleet management software firm Fleetmatics (FLTX), which fell just over 3% in soft volume.
In the stock market today, NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) bucked the trend, rising 6% after Needham & Co. upgraded the chip company and set a 140 price target.

Biogen Idec (BIIB) added 1% as the biotech group extended gains for a fifth straight session. Biogen is expected to show "best in class" data for its BIIB037 Alzheimer's drug next week at the International Conference on Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases in Nice, France.
