Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. For the week, the FTSE 100 tracked toward a 1.9% gain, the Cac-40 was up 1.5% and the DAX showed a 3% gain.Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Generac Holdings (GNRC), Winnebago Industries (WGO) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) headline lower-profile IBD 50 leaders that tend to slip under the radar amidst the hoopla over what's hot now on Wall Street. Internet, 3D printer, pharmaceutical and foreign stocks get attention most of the year, even though all the leaders boast strong fundamentals. But the holiday-induced lull gives these sleeper…

Will beauty retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) impress investors again when it reports third-quarter results on Thursday? It'll be hard to top Q2 results, which saw earnings jump 30%, revenue rise 25% and same-store sales increase 8.4%, boosting shares 17% on Sept. 13. But analysts expect Q3 earnings to come in at the high end of the company's forecast for 71-74…

Stocks ended lower Thursday ahead of a key jobs report that could determine when the Federal Reserve will start scaling back its massive stimulus program. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each slipped 0.4% and the Nasdaq edged down 0.1%. Volume fell 15% on the NYSE and was down a fraction on the Nasdaq compared to Wednesday,…
Stocks reversed early losses Friday and turned mixed, perhaps cheered by a better-than-expected reading on consumer sentiment.

The Nasdaq fell more than 1% early but recovered for a fractional gain. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3% and the S&P 500 eased 0.1%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking higher than Thursday.

In economic news, consumer confidence hit a nine-month high according to a preliminary April reading from the University of Michigan. The index came in at 82.6, above the consensus estimate of 81 and also above March's final reading of 80.

In the stock market today, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) weighed on the Dow. It gapped below its 200-day moving average, falling 3% on disappointing earnings. Wells Fargo (WFC), meanwhile, found support at its 50-day moving average after reporting earnings. Shares rose 2% after early weakness.
In IPO news, Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) soared in its debut. The fast-casual, Mediterranean-inspired restaurant chain priced last night at 15. Shares opened at 25.65 and were recently trading around 25.75.

Meanwhile, several IBD 50 names bounced back, including Facebook (FB), Under Armour (UA) and Keurig Green Mountain (GMCR) . All three have pulled back with the market in recent weeks but the declines have been relatively tame compared to other highfliers that have corrected 30% or more off recent highs.

On the downside, retail-related industry groups were among the day's worst performers. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) weighed on the Retail-Specialty group. Shares fell 3%. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sells all kinds of products to enhance one's looks, but its recent stock track record reveals sharp fissures. Still, the once-ugly chart is starting to look prettier.
Shares of the Bolingbrook, Ill.-based chain gapped up 17% at the open after reporting second-quarter results late Thursday that blew away Wall Street views.
In its first quarter under CEO Mary Dillon, who took the helm July 1, Ulta earned 70 cents a share, up 30% from last year and 3 cents above views. Sales grew 25% to $601 mil, also beating.
Its third-quarter outlook, though, fell below analysts forecasts. The market seemed to ignore that, as Ulta was 18% higher at 117.92 in late-afternoon trading on the stock market today.
But that's not a new trend for the beauty store operator. The stock has a history of gapping up or down when it reports quarterly results, then consolidating for a few months.
Shares leapt 15% June 12, the day after Ulta topped Q1 profit and sales forecasts. It also guided lower for Q3.
The prior quarter, the stock sank an unsightly 16% March 13 despite Ulta's better-than-expected results for Q4 2012. Its ultra-weak Q1 outlook apparently spooked investors.
Shares tanked 12% Feb. 14 on news of CEO Chuck Rubin's resignation, which prompted analysts to downgrade Ulta.
An 8% pop Nov. 30 followed its Q3 2012 earnings beat, and a 7% jump Sept. 7 after its Q2 topped views.
Following a big multiyear run-up, the stock traded sideways from April 2012 to February 2013, with several failed breakout attempts.
Since then it's been consolidating again, and could be ripe for a makeover.

The former highflier's fundamentals remain attractive, with 17 straight quarters of double-digit earnings and sales growth. That helps it win a 98 Earnings Per Share and A for its Sales + Margins + ROE Rating. One blemish, its 47 Relative Strength Rating, could clear up after today's stock action.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sells all kinds of products to enhance one's looks, but its recent stock track record reveals sharp fissures. Salon and beauty products retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) slammed past analyst views, with boosts from new stores, customer a loyalty program and new in-store boutiques for its upscale brands.
Second-quarter earnings per share climbed 42.1% to 54 cents, over analysts' consensus estimates for 51 cents.
Total sales climbed 22.1% to $481.7 million, beating forecasts for $473.8 million. Sales at stores open at last 14 months climbed 9.3%.
Ulta's shares soared more than 8% after hours to 103, a new record high. During the regular session the stock climbed 2.5% to 95.26.
"Our rich pipeline of new products and brands continues to drive traffic and market share gains," CEO Chuck Rubin said in a statement.
The company said its loyalty program reached 10 million active customers, with half of its stores now participating.
It added 50 boutiques selling Lancome cosmetics and 35 selling Clinique products.
Ulta guided for full-year EPS of $2.58 to $2.60, including charges of 7 to 8 cents for accelerating store openings, the opening of a distribution center in Pennsylvania and other issues.
Analysts, who typically back out such one-time issues, were expecting full-year EPS of $2.55.
For Q3 it's guiding 6% to 8% same-store sales, with EPS of 54 to 56 cents including about 4 cents in charges related to store openings. Analysts forecast 54 cents, without one-time items.

The company added 22 stores in the quarter for a total of 489. Analysts forecast 54 cents, without one-time items.The company added 22 stores in the quarter for a total of 489. It plans to add 52 more in Q3.

While the cup with handle is the most common stock chart pattern among great winners, the double bottom also pops up frequently — and has a similar look.It initially resembles a cup with handle, but then the handle slants way, way down. So far down that it no longer is a proper handle, and the overall structure instead takes on a W-like shape.The second part of the W actually undercuts the first. Look at the double-bottom base that Ulta Beauty (ULTA) formed in 2010 1, as shown in the chart accompanying this column.In early August 2010 2, it might have appeared as though Ulta was en route to etching a cup with handle. But the specialty retailer of cosmetics, beauty products and hair salon services made another move down, touching a fresh six-month low at 20.67 on Sept. 1, 2010.So when do double bottoms generally occur?As with any base, they often begin to take shape when the general market itself experiences an intermediate correction.You frequently get the second half of the pattern for a leading stock when the market tries to rally, then falls back into correction mode.That's exactly what happened with Ulta. The market was in an uptrend from early July through early August, as noted at that time in IBD's The Big Picture column and Market Pulse graphic.But the uptrend came under pressure in mid-August, and then the market fell into a brief correction in late August. Ulta etched the second half of its double-bottom structure during this period.The next confirmed uptrend began with a follow-through day on Sept. 1, 2010. This turned into a strong uptrend that helped unleash plenty of big advances by highly rated stocks, including Ulta.Ulta broke out on Sept. 3, a couple of sessions after the follow-through day. It cleared a buy point at 25.99. With any double bottom, the entry comes from the middle peak in the W-like pattern.For Ulta, the middle peak was at 25.89, so you just add a dime to get the buy point at 25.99.The breakout on Sept. 3 drew strong turnover 3 , just like you want to see. On a weekly basis, turnover was the strongest it had ever been for Ulta, which went public in 2007.

"Pay no attention to the man behind the curtain," were the famous words of the Wizard of Oz, the unremarkable-looking character in the film of the same name, who quietly orchestrated all the comings and goings in the Emerald City.Institutional investors are the stock market's rough equivalent: They're quietly gathering large quantities of their targeted stocks, determining chart patterns and tightening floats until the imbalance of supply and demand squeezes a stock into a breakout and, if all goes well, a winning run.IBD provides two specific tools to help glimpse behind the curtain and gauge institutional activity. These are most useful when a stock is basing and near a buy point.The up/down volume ratio helps gauge whether or not a stock is under accumulation, a state in which the supply of shares is contracting due to rising demand. This indicates large institutions are at work buying the stock. IBD's Accumulation/Distribution Rating is another tool to help gauge such supply and demand.The up/down gauge covers 50 days of action. It's calculated by dividing total volume on days a stock's price ended higher by the total volume on days when it closed lower. The ratio should generally be above 1.0 in a stock that is about to break out.You can see the up/down volume ratio at IBD Stock Checkup on investors.com and on Leaderboard.Use the Accumulation/Distribution Rating as a corroborating indicator. You'd like to see a grade of C+ or better in a stock approaching a buy point. An A or B? Even better.Both indicators were on target when Ulta Beauty (ULTA) started its 525% advance in September 2009.The stock had built a flattish cup-with-handle base. Tight weekly closes and closes high in the range through the second half of the base suggested accumulation. 1 So did the skyscrapers of buying volume across the bottom of the base. 2In the week just prior to Ulta's breakout, its EPS and RS Ratings were both an 86 — not stellar, but still solid. But its Accumulation/Distribution Grade was an A.Its up/down volume ratio showed a potent 1.9 and had climbed above 2.0 in five of the eight previous weeks.Ulta broke out Sept. 4 in huge volume. 3 Investors who missed that day's gap-up eruption would have needed to wait two months for another buy opportunity, until the stock pulled back to test support at its 10-week moving average. 4

Stocks climbed well off session lows after a rough start Monday.
Major averages fell by 1% or more early in the session, rattled by news that the Bank of Japan held their monetary policy unchanged after a much-awaited meeting.
The S&P 500 fell 0.4%; the Nasdaq lost 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average eased 0.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume tracking 17% higher than Monday. Nasdaq volume fell 1%.
Volume on the NYSE was skewed somewhat by big volume in Sprint (S). Earlier today, Japan's Softbank raised its bid for Sprint by $1.5 billion to $21.6 billion.

In the stock market today, small-cap Chipmos Technologies (IMOS) cleared a three-weeks-tight pattern, rising 2% in fast trade. The stock has been in an accumulation phase for several weeks now. The Taiwan-based firm is a provider of chip-testing services.
Video game maker Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) added 4% in strong turnover. The stock is now 6% above a flat-base buy point of 16.26.

Mortgage servicer Ocwen Financial (OCN) is flying 6% higher in fast trade. The stock recently broke out over 42.17 from a cup but had a hard time getting going. It fell 5.5% below the buy point but never triggered IBD's 8% sell rule. Group peer Home Loan Servicing Solutions (HLSS) gained 2% and reclaimed its 24.19 flat-base buy point. But volume is running below its average pace.

On the downside, SolarCity (SCTY) is diving 5% in heavy volume. The stock is holding its 10-week moving average for now. Shares hit an intraday low of 33.11. Its 10-week line is at 32.94. SolarCity has been a standout performer since its December IPO at 8. The company provides solar energy systems to residential and commercial customers.

After the close, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) will be out with quarterly results. After a huge price run that saw the stock gain nearly 1,100% between 2009-2012, new highs for the beauty retailer could be a tall order even though annual profit margin and return on equity hit peak levels in fiscal 2013. The consensus estimate calls for profit of 62 cents a share, up 15% from a year ago with sales up 22% to $576.3 million. Shares fell 0.6% ahead of the results.

Update: Ulta Beauty said third-quarter earnings rose 83% to 42 cents a share, accelerating for a third straight quarter. Sales rose 22% to $413.1 million. That topped forecasts for a 38-cent profit and sales of $406.1 million. The 10.5% EPS beat was strong, but not surprising. Ulta had topped profit estimates by 10% or more in each of the prior 11 quarters, including by 19% in Q2.Sales at stores open at least 14 months grew 9.6% vs. a year earlier.The salon and cosmetics retailer expects fourth-quarter EPS of 62-64 cents vs. views of 61 cents. Ulta sees revenue of $552 million-$562 million, with the $567 million midpoint slightly below analyst forecasts of $558.7 million.Ulta's shares fell 4% in early after-hours trading after sinking 1.6% in the regular session.(Original earnings preview follows).***Ulta Beauty (ULTA), the salon chain and cosmetics retailer reports after the close today, with investors looking to see whether consumers are still spending pretty on beauty products.Analysts think they are.Consensus estimates call for 38 cents per share in the third quarter, vs. Ulta's earlier guidance of 36-38 cents. They expect a 20% surge in sales to $406.1 million, near the high end of the retailer's earlier guidance for $400 million-$407 million.Analysts say spending on beauty products seem to have held up, despite the week economy. Ulta has been adding stores and stocking shelves with new popular brands and products. It now has about 415, each with a full-service salon inside."We believe ULTA will continue to outperform and gain market share in an attractive category (positive demographics, secular trends), supported by substantial newness (new products and brands) and enhanced marketing," Robert Baird analyst Erika Maschmeyer wrote in an earnings preview note.But some worry about slowing growth against strong comparable months and a sluggish economy.Sales at stores open more than a year climbed 11.2% over the first two quarters of fiscal 2011, but the company has guided a slower back-half. Analysts are forecasting a still-strong 9.5% Q3 same-store pop."With strong returns from the loyalty card and merchandising efforts, the business is humming along and we believe that trends will remain strong in 3Q and into the holiday season," Jason Gere, an RBC Capital Markets analyst, said in a research note.Ulta is on this week's IBD 50 list of the best stocks based on fundamentals and technicals. Another IBD 50 company, yoga retailer Lululemon Athletica (LULU), reported third-quarter profit before the open that beat Wall Street forecasts. But sales growth fell a little short.Also this morning, major retailers, including Macy's (M), Target (TGT) and J.C. Penney (JCP) reported November same-store sales figures, giving clues on early holiday spending.

A good engineer knows and follows the technical rules of the trade, but also leans upon intuition in problem solving. Finding buy points depends upon a similar mix of education and imagination.
Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) initially offered a black-and-white buy point in March 2010.

The stock had formed an eight-week cup. It started to shape a handle, but moved fast after it reported a jump in sales during its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report on March 11. It broke out above the buy point, up 8% in huge trade, but then things got murky.

Investors looking for follow-on buy opportunities may have seen a square box form from mid-March to early April 1. The base, part of a base-on-base pattern, was less than perfect. The price barely topped the left-side high in the second week of April. The weekly closes wedged higher across the base. Neither problem is a deal killer, but the stock was just not behaving properly.
Still, the stock shot above the 24.20 buy point in heavy trade April 22 2. But it soon pulled back in frantic trade. By May 6, it had fallen 14% below the buy point, negating the breakout 3.

The stock then swung into two months of erratic trade. Shares sawed back and forth through the 10-week moving average line. The cuts were too deep to qualify as normal rebounds and the stock's behavior did little to encourage investors to move more cash onto Ulta's table.
The company reported a blowout fiscal first quarter on June 3. Still, shares fell 9% for the week to end below the 10-week line.

The stock continued lower the following week, ended June 11, but reversed by gaining 7% and ending at the absolute top of the week's trading range 4. This was the turning point. The back-and-forth trade continued, but in a more settled fashion as the stock dipped into a two month correction.

Trading within that correction was tight and contained. The pattern became a crystal-clear double-bottom base with a 25.99 buy point. Shares broke above that mark in heavy trade on Sept. 3 5, just after Ulta announced its fiscal second-quarter results.

The stock has rallied 165% above that buy mark.A good engineer knows and follows the technical rules of the trade, but also leans upon intuition in problem solving. A weak March consumer sentiment reading swayed stocks lower Friday, despite on-target February retail sales numbers and falling oil prices.The NYSE and Nasdaq composites were both down 0.2%. The S&P 500 traded fractionally lower. Volume was down 10% on the NYSE and 24% lower on the Nasdaq compared with the same time Thursday.Rising gasoline prices appeared to be the key culprit as consumer sentiment tumbled to a reading of 68.2 for March, far below February's 77.5 reading and expectations for 76.5. The University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index fell back to September levels.Crude oil prices slumped again, to near $100 a barrel, trading at $99 and to $103. Traders expect lower demand as the major earthquake and tsunami in Japan Friday dents that country's economy.Ulta Salon Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) popped 7% after reporting fourth-quarter EPS rose 38% to 47 cents, above views for 44 cents. Revenue gained 20% to $473.7 million vs. expectations for $467.3 million. The company offered first-quarter earnings guidance above expectations, but its revenue outlook was below current forecasts.Ulta carries a Composite Rating of 95 from IBD. The rebound from its 10-week moving average is its second since clearing a square box base in January.Emergency air transport operation Air Methods  (AIRM) lifted off 8% in heavy trade. Its fourth-quarter earnings soared 350% to 99 cents a share, 30% above expectations. Sales rose 24% to $150.4 million vs. views for $136.7 million.The move lifted the thinly traded stock 6% past a 59.48 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Air Methods holds a Composite Rating of 89.

The major indexes skidded in pre-market action Friday, as the closely-watched monthly jobs report showed employers adding fewer jobs than expected.
Nasdaq 100, S&P 500 and Dow futures all deepened earlier losses ahead of the opening bell.

Employers added 431,000 non-farm jobs in May. That was well below the 500,000 projected by economists, who expected a huge surge due to government hiring of census workers. Meanwhile, the unemployment rate fell to 9.7% in May, lower than the projected rate of 9.8% and April's 9.9% figure.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury retreated to less than 3.27% on the disappointing jobs news.
Law enforcement training firm DynCorp (DCP) reported fiscal fourth-quarter earnings that topped Wall Street expectations by 2 cents.

The company projected Q2 earnings of 19 to 21 cents a share, well above analysts' consensus of 15 cents.

Futures traded in sharply mixed territory ahead of Friday's open, as investors navigated a spate of earnings reports and a surprise drop in December's trade deficit. Nasdaq 100 futures traded up 4.5 points, while Dow futures were down 13 points. S&P 500 futures dipped a fraction. The stock market today looks a lot like it did just ahead of last…
Stocks thrashed out of the starting gate in mixed trade Friday, with retailers under some pressure, as three economic reports delivered a beat, a miss and a match.
The S&P 500 added 0.2%, the Dow Jones industrial average inched up 0.1%. The Nasdaq slipped 0.1%, hamstrung by Apple's (AAPL) 2% decline.
Volume rose a fraction on the Nasdaq and slipped 15% on the NYSE, compared with Thursday morning's trade.

A Labor Department report released prior to the market open showed payrolls jumped 155,000 in December — matching expectations, according to Econoday — while the overall unemployment rate came in at 7.8%, also in line with the consensus view.
Factory orders in November were as flat as a lunch-truck pancake, the Commerce Department reported, down from October's 0.8% gain and below consensus expectations for a 0.3% rise.

The services segment of the economy expanded more than expected in December, however, lifting the Institute for Supply Management's services index to 56.1 for the month. The 36th straight month of expansion showed some acceleration, and was above consensus forecasts for 54.5.

In stocks, Bonanza Creek Energy (BCEI) bolted 6% higher in initial trade to seize a new high. The Denver-based oil and gas producer updated its Q4 results late Thursday, reporting strong oil production from new wells in its Niobrara field assets in northeast Colorado. The IBD 50 stock cleared a 26.70 buy point in a six week cup Dec. 18, and is now 13% above that buy point.

Riverbed Technology (RVBD) popped 3% at the open. The maker of network applications products is climbing the right side of a possible base, after correcting 33% since October. The stock unraveled for 16 months before bottoming in July. It is now 52% below its March, 2011 high.

On the downside, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) gapped down more than 3% after reporting holiday season same-store-sales rose 7.4%, vs. last year's 12.6 gain. The company reiterated Q4 sales and earnings guidance at the low end of analyst expectations.

Stocks held near their session highs and were on pace to end a two-day decline. But the major averages also were on track to end the short trading week with losses. The Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were up 0.7% each. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 was up 0.6%. Despite the comeback, volume was tracking sharply lower across the…

Stocks were holding near their highs in late afternoon trading Friday, bolstered by a stronger-than-expected jobs reports and other economic numbers out before the open. The market confounded some investors who were certain a good jobs report would send it down on the theory that the Federal Reserve will move to a tighter monetary policy if the economy improves. The…

Stocks opened higher, but quickly began to trim gains on Friday, as the dollar edged higher and oil prices held steady. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% apiece. The Nasdaq held on to its 0.5% advance.
Volume was soft, down 14% on the Nasdaq and 90% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Thursday.

The stock market today is rebounding, but still correcting, with both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 deep in the hole for the week. The market received an early assist today from China, where some rule changes and federally engineered buying helped lift markets to their first healthy close of the week.
December hiring in the U.S. was also a factor, as the Labor Department reported payrolls jumped by 292,000 during the month — far above expectations.
Wholesale inventories dropped 0.3% in November, the Commerce Department said. That was even with October's slip and below expectations for no change.

The market will have an ear out for post-payroll comments from San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams, who speaks at 11:30 a.m. ET, and from Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Jeffrey Lacker, on the docket for a 1 p.m. speech.
Apple (AAPL) and DuPont (DD) raced to the head of the Dow, up nearly 2% each. Wynn Resorts (WYNN)headed the S&P 500 with a 4% gain.
Gap (GPS) cratered 7% after announcing late Thursday its December same-store sales slipped 5% vs. consensus views for a 3.5% decline.

Chipmaker and Apple supplier Qorvo (QRVO) dropped 4%. The Greensboro, N.C. company late Thursday lowered its Q3 revenue guidance to well below consensus expectations. The company also said it repurchased $250 million in shares during the quarter, leaving $750 million in its share repurchase program and a cash balance of more than $1 billion. Shares traded down 14% for the week and 50% below a June high.

On the IBD 50 list, Universal Display (OLED) flashed ahead nearly 5% at the open. The maker of organic light emitting diode chips used in high definition TV and computer screens is trading below a 55.93 buy point in a cup base. It triggered an automatic sell signal by diving more than 8% below that mark.

Hawaiian (HA) jumped more than 3% after reporting its total numbers of passengers rose 4.1% and its load factor crept up to 82.9% in the fourth quarter. The stock remains well below its 50-day moving average and is attempting to build the right side of a 22% deep consolidation.

Aircraft carrier mechanic Huntington Ingalls Industries (HII) sailed ahead nearly 4%. Cowen & Co. upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. A strong quarterly report and bullish analysts helped lift Ulta Beauty (ULTA) to an all-time high Wednesday. The salon and beauty products chain gapped up in huge volume, scoring a big gain and climbing back above its 50-day moving average. Late Tuesday, the Bolingbrook, Ill., company said first-quarter EPS increased 46% to 54 cents, a penny above forecasts. Revenue grew…
Stocks ended a solid winning streak Friday with modest losses as investors coped with a disheartening survey of consumer attitudes.
The Nasdaq fell 0.3%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 each eased 0.2%. With its modest decline, the Dow industrials snapped a 10-day winning streak.
Volume in the stock market today rose 15% on the Nasdaq and soared more than 100% on the NYSE, with a huge boost coming from a triple-witching session, preliminary data show.
The University of Michigan preliminary consumer confidence index fell to 71.8 in March from February's 77.6. March's reading fell way short of an Econoday survey that predicted a 77.5 reading.

In other economic news, industrial production rose 0.7% in February, a bit better than expected. CPI also rose 0.7%, and also was a bit more than expected. But the core rate, which excludes wide-swinging food and energy prices, rose an as-expected 0.2%.
A good number of leaders started Friday's session strong but ceded some of those gains by day's end.

DirecTV (DTV) rose 5% in 2-1/2 times its usual volume, but had climbed as much as 7% — an all-time high — before backing off. The move triggered a breakout from a double-bottom base with a 54.06 buy point. The satellite TV provider is the subject of merger talk with its rival Dish Network (DISH).

Arizona-based homebuilder Meritage Homes (MTH) rose 3% in heavy turnover, but had climbed as much as 5% and hit a new 52-week high. Meritage triggered its 44.95 flat-base buy point and ended 2% above that entry.

Hibbett Sports (HIBB) rose 4% in 3-1/2 times its average volume. But the somewhat-thinly traded stock had climbed as much as 7% before scaling back. The sporting-goods retailer reported slightly better-than-expected earnings for its Q4, while sales met estimates. Two days of gains have lifted the stock above its 50-day moving average and near it 200-day line. It continues to work on a consolidation begun in August.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) slid 16% after delivering fourth-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings and revenue were better than expected. But same-store sales growth slowed and the company offered a disappointing outlook for Q1. Stocks showed modest losses at midafternoon Friday, nearing session lows after a disappointing consumer confidence report.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3% and was on pace to end a 10-day winning streak that's taken it to record highs. The S&P 500 also shed 0.3% and traded about 1% off its all-time peak of 1576 hit intraday Oct. 11, 2007. The Nasdaq fared worst, slipping 0.4%.
Volume in the stock market today remained sharply higher across the board, boosted by quadruple witching expirations of options and futures contracts.

For the week, the main indexes are on pace to deliver moderate gains of 0.7% or less. They reached multiyear or record highs Thursday before catching their breath today. A decent number of stocks have broken out to new highs this week as the market has enjoyed a slow, steady uptrend.

Meritage Homes (MTH) was up 4% Friday in heavy turnover, hitting a new multiyear high and clearing a flat base with a buy point at 44.95. The Arizona-based homebuilder has an IBD Composite Rating of 89 out of a best-possible 99.

DirecTV (DTV) jumped 6% in fast trade, reaching an all-time high and topping a 54.06 entry from a double-bottom pattern. The satellite TV provider is getting a lift from analysts seeing a potential merger with rival Dish Network (DISH).
Dish gained 3%, but remained below its 50-day moving average and 7% off its mid-February high. Note that DirecTV has a middling IBD Composite Rating of 54, while Dish's is a poor 22.

On the earnings front, Hibbett Sports (HIBB) jumped 5% after its fourth-quarter earnings beat forecasts, while revenue matched views. The sporting goods chain's full-year guidance was in line with estimates. Two days of gains have lifted the stock above both its 50- and 200-day moving averages. It continues to work on a consolidation begun in August.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) dived 17% after delivering fourth-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings and revenue were better than expected, but same-store sales growth slowed. Plus the specialty retailer offered a disappointing outlook for Q1. The stock is well below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

Stocks remained up sharply but off their session highs in early-afternoon action Wednesday, as investors cheered a federal budget deal that has averted the fiscal cliff.
The Nasdaq rose 2.3% after being up nearly 2.9%. The S&P 500 gained 1.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 1.7%. Volume continued to track up significantly across the board.
In the IBD 50 lineup, Ellie Mae (ELLI), PolyOne (POL), Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) were among the stocks that were trying to break out.

But Ellie Mae has erased most of its gain from the session, leaving it up just 2% after it climbed 10% out of the gate. The provider of on-demand software to the mortgage industry surged past a 28.96 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern, but it's now back below that level. Ellie Mae is No. 39 in Wednesday's IBD 50.

PolyOne jumped 9% in big turnover, clearing a 21.10 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern. The plastics maker, No. 14 in Wednesday's IBD 50, is also rebounding off support at its 10-week moving average.

Taiwan Semiconductor rose 5%, clearing a buy point at 17.57 from a four-weeks-tight pattern. It continued to trade tightly after forming the pattern. Volume in the early afternoon was coming in above average, but slightly below the level that you prefer to see with a breakout. The stock is No. 50 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup.

Ulta, No. 40 in the IBD 50, gained 3% in fast trade, moving past a 101.71 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern. But note the specialty retailer's most recent base is a riskier, later-stage structure.

On the downside, Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) slumped 1.5% in heavy turnover, dropping further below its 10-week moving average. The stock, No. 25 in the IBD 50, also has dropped as much as 7% below its recent buy point at 89.55, tripping a key IBD sell rule.

Some economic reports have missed expectations Wednesday, but the market is focused on Washington's fiscal cliff deal. "The bill does permanently fix the Alternative Minimum Tax issue and taxes for the middle class," Bruce Bittles, Baird's chief investment strategist, wrote in a note this morning.

"This is significant because it allows households and small businesses to plan longer term. The next hurdle for the market and economy is the debt-limit issue, which is likely to create another opportunity for political hero making," Bittles added.Stocks remained up sharply but off their session highs in early-afternoon action Wednesday, as investors cheered a federal budget deal that has averted the fiscal cliff.The Nasdaq rose 2.3% after being up nearly 2.9%. A good engineer knows and follows the technical rules of the trade, but also leans upon intuition in problem solving. Finding buy points depends upon a similar mix of education and imagination.
Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) initially offered a black-and-white buy point in March 2010.

The stock had formed an eight-week cup. It started to shape a handle, but moved fast after it reported a jump in sales during its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings report on March 11. It broke out above the buy point, up 8% in huge trade, but then things got murky.

Investors looking for follow-on buy opportunities may have seen a square box form from mid-March to early April 1. The base, part of a base-on-base pattern, was less than perfect. The price barely topped the left-side high in the second week of April. The weekly closes wedged higher across the base. Neither problem is a deal killer, but the stock was just not behaving properly.
Still, the stock shot above the 24.20 buy point in heavy trade April 22 2. But it soon pulled back in frantic trade. By May 6, it had fallen 14% below the buy point, negating the breakout 3.

The stock then swung into two months of erratic trade. Shares sawed back and forth through the 10-week moving average line. The cuts were too deep to qualify as normal rebounds and the stock's behavior did little to encourage investors to move more cash onto Ulta's table.
The company reported a blowout fiscal first quarter on June 3. Still, shares fell 9% for the week to end below the 10-week line.

The stock continued lower the following week, ended June 11, but reversed by gaining 7% and ending at the absolute top of the week's trading range 4. This was the turning point. The back-and-forth trade continued, but in a more settled fashion as the stock dipped into a two month correction.

Trading within that correction was tight and contained. The pattern became a crystal-clear double-bottom base with a 25.99 buy point. Shares broke above that mark in heavy trade on Sept. 3 5, just after Ulta announced its fiscal second-quarter results.

The stock has rallied 165% above that buy mark.A good engineer knows and follows the technical rules of the trade, but also leans upon intuition in problem solving. Sector Leaders ended mixed Tuesday even though the major market indexes scored gains. While most issues had minor moves, a few staged more notable action. Polaris Industries (PII) was the best-performing Sector Leader. It powered further into a four-month high, adding 1.65, or 2%, to 82.41. That puts the stock nearly 6% past a 78.04 buy point from a second…

Stocks continued to show modest losses in early afternoon trading Friday, putting them mostly on pace to score their second weekly gains in a row. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both shed 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%. Volume was down from Thursday's levels across the board. For the week, the Nasdaq is set to gain 1.3%…

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reported third-quarter earnings and sales above estimates and raised its outlook, sending shares up after hours on Thursday. The hair care, makeup and beauty supply store said earnings jumped 41% to 59 cents per share, topping analyst estimates by 3 cents, though it was the fourth straight quarter of decelerating EPS growth. Sales rose 22% to $505.6…
Stocks reversed higher at the closing bell Monday, ending a four-session skid despite another rout in China's stock market and a further drop in oil prices.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.3% and the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%, while the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today rose 10% on the Nasdaq and 6% on the NYSE compared with Friday, according to preliminary data.
Energy, mining and biotech stocks lagged, while department store, hospital and tobacco stocks led the upside.
Aluminum producer Alcoa (AA) rose after hours following its Q4 earnings report. The stock ended the regular session down nearly 1%, declining for the eighth straight session.

Macy's (M) led the S&P 500, rising 8% in strong volume after investment advisory firm Starboard Value reportedly said Monday it supports the department store's recent joint ventures for its mall-based and real estate properties. Other department store stocks also rallied, with Kohl's (KSS) rising 5% and Dillard's (DDS) 2%.

On a sour note, IBD 50 stock Celgene (CELG) dropped nearly 6% to its lowest level in over four months. The biotech offered 2016 guidance and named COO Mark Alles as its new CEO starting March 1. Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.
Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).

Current chief Bob Hugin will become executive chairman.Companies due to report quarterly results Tuesday include CSX (CSX) and IHS (IHS).The Labor Department is due to release its closely watched job openings and labor turnover survey (JOLTS) on Tuesday.
Stocks limped to a mixed close in decreased volume Friday as mixed economic news came up against a raft of hostile remarks from the "fiscal cliff" negotiators.

The Nasdaq fell a fraction, while the S&P 500 the Dow Jones industrial average each logged a minuscule rise. Some last-hour short-covering and bargain-hunting pushed the averages into the green — barely — from what were modest losses.
At their worst, the major indexes had dipped just 0.3% to 0.4%.
But the hard positions over the fiscal cliff lent a negative tone to most of the session. Consider these remarks from key budget negotiators the past few days:
"If Congress does nothing, every family in America will see their taxes automatically go up on Jan. 1. That's a Scrooge Christmas." President Barack Obama, speaking at a Philadelphia toy factory.
"(I) burst into laughter." Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell, describing his reaction to the Obama plan as outlined by Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner.
"(T)here's a stalemate. Let's not kid ourselves." House Speaker John Boehner, adding, "It (Obama's plan) was not a serious proposal."
"I don't understand his brain." Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid, speaking of John Boehner.

A Chicago-area purchasing managers index gained 50.4 for November, just barely above forecasts and signaling expansion. But personal income was flat in October, missing expectations for a 0.3% climb. Personal spending dipped 0.2% in October, falling short of forecasts for a 0.1% increase.
Some good news was heard from abroad: German lawmakers passed the next round of financial support for Greece. The deal should buy some time for the beleaguered nation but falls well short of a cure.
Family Dollar (FDO) climbed 1% in robust trade. The rally can be viewed as a breakout past a base within a larger pattern. It's clearing resistance around 70 in that shorter structure.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) shot up 8% in huge turnover. The specialty retailer said Q3 earnings jumped 41% to 59 cents per share, topping estimates, though it was the fourth straight quarter of modestly decelerating EPS growth. Sales rose 22% to $505.6 million, just above views. The stock has lifted above its 50-day moving average as it continues to work on a base that began in early September.
Sturm Ruger (RGR) slid 2% in above-average action, killing the stock's eight-day winning streak. The firearms maker, No. 4 in the IBD 50, is well extended from its last buying range.

Yum Brands (YUM) dived 10% in frantic trade after its warning late Thursday. The operator of KFC, Pizza Hut and Taco Bell said it expects a 4% decline in fourth-quarter same-store sales in China, its largest market. Yum also backed its 2012 EPS target of $3.24, implying Q4 EPS of 82 cents, below forecasts for 85 cents.

Earlier this month, Yum moved past a cup-with-handle pattern with a 77.25 entry, but it's now fallen 14% below that level, tripping IBD's 8% sell rule. The fast-food giant also has undercut its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Stocks limped to a mixed close in decreased volume Friday as mixed economic news came up against a raft of hostile remarks from the "fiscal cliff" negotiators.The Nasdaq fell a fraction, while the S&P 500 the Dow Jones industrial average each logged a minuscule rise. Stocks mustered small gains in a choppy session Monday. Despite the gains, the day still belonged to the bears. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2%, closing at a record high. The Nasdaq also climbed 0.2% after touching a fresh 13-year high. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 were up as much as 0.5% and 0.4%, respectively. The small-cap Russell 2000…

Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq were each up 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume on the Nasdaq and the NYSE were tracking below Tuesday's levels.
Fed policymakers are expected to raise interest rates by 25 basis points, marking the first increase since the central bank dropped rates to near zero in 2008 amid the financial crisis.
In the stock market today, drugmaker Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) jumped 7% in heavy volume despite issuing a weaker-than-expected 2016 earnings forecast.

The stock jumped 16% Tuesday after announcing a distribution agreement with Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA), which the Canada-based drugmaker said would help rebuild its business after it cut ties with Philidor Rx Services amid allegations of wrongdoing. However, Valeant's forecast for a 30% jump in 2016 profit fell short of analysts' expectations.
Solar stocks were among the day's best performers, led by First Solar (FSLR), which jumped 8% to a new high in heavy volume.

Makers of solar panels and components have gotten a lift after negotiators from the U.S. and nearly 200 other countries reached a deal last weekend to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The agreement could lead to greater investment in energy efficient solar technologies like solar.

On the downside, Global Payments (GPN) plunged 10% in heavy volume, slicing through its 50-day line, after the credit card payments processor said it would buy rival Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.

Meanwhile, homebuiders rose after housing starts and building permits rose much more than expected in November, according to data from the Commerce Department. That sent homebuilders Pulte Group (PHM) and Toll Bros. (TOL) each up 2%, while D.R. Horton (DHI) and Lennar (LEN) both rose about 1%.Stocks pared gains at midday Wednesday amid expectations the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates later in the day. A quiet day for the major averages Wednesday resulted in an equally quiet session for most Sector Leaders.

U.K.-based ARM Holdings (ARMH) gained 44 cents to 48.34. It hasn't made much headway after a recent breakout from a cup-with-handle pattern in mediocre volume. The buy point was 48.21. (See charts on Page B3.)

The sluggish breakout notwithstanding, ARM is well positioned for growth in the mobile space. Its chip designs are found in smartphones and tablets, including the new iPhone 5S. Fundamentals are compelling. Full-year profit is seen rising 45% this year and 29% in 2014.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) eased 37 cents to 116.78. The beauty retailer continues to show constructive price action after its earnings-inspired move during the week ended Sept. 13. Tight, weekly closes after a breakout are good to see, and Ulta Beauty is showing that so far.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) underperformed, falling 1.39 to 102.34. The drugmaker's growth-through-acquisition strategy has fueled strong share performance in recent years. Its $8.7 billion acquisition of Bausch & Lomb Holdings closed last month.

After a breakout from a cup-with-handle base in early August, Valeant recently paid a visit to its 10-week moving average for the first time, where it found support. The stock appeared to form a flat base, but on the weekly chart it looks too short.
Finally, gun maker Sturm Ruger (RGR) continued its rapid ascent, rising 23 cents to 64.58. Volume was one-third lighter than usual.

It cleared a late-stage cup-with-handle pattern earlier this month but is now extended 13% past a buy point of 56.98.A quiet day for the major averages Wednesday resulted in an equally quiet session for most Sector Leaders.U.K.-based ARM Holdings (ARMH) gained 44 cents to 48.34. Late in the session, IBD 50 constituent Ulta Beauty (ULTA) is in the top spot for unusual option volume on a seven-fold increase over its daily average with volume topping 6,700 contracts in front of tonight's earnings report. Calls and puts are evenly matched with a put/call ratio of 1.09.

Most active on the board and not entirely surprising, September is seeing most all of today's interest. With 15 calendar days left there's a bit more than two trading weeks for those calls and puts to play out before they're either stock equivalents or fully worthless.

Also keeping September the only game in town for most of today's traders is Ulta's existing blemish of less-than-hot option liquidity. The unfortunate reality is individual quoted markets of about $0.30 in the surrounding money September calls and puts doesn't get any more attractive in further out maturities. As much, spread orders, even simple ones with just two legs such as verticals or straddles become all the more dicey due to likely slippage in opening and possibly the closing of positions.

Implied volatility is bid and continuing its spike toward the high 60's. That type of demand for protective premium is very much on par with recent past quarterly reports as illustrated above and denoted by the "E" wedged inside the green triangle on the chart.

Related, the expected move based on the at-the-money straddle market's implied volatility of about 67% suggests traders see a one standard deviation or 68% chance shares will be contained within 13.5% of Thursday's price near 95.50 through expiration.

At the same time, with statistical or underlying stock volatility mostly in the lower quartile of its yearly range (not shown) and tonight's uncertainty to be reflected in the share price tomorrow, for better or worse, we'd estimate September premiums could get cut down by about 50% towards 35% to 40% IV. Hmm, I guess you could say there are some crazy option highlights in which customers of ULTA's calls and puts, hopefully considered ahead of time.

What do you think? Sector Leaders took some punishment Thursday, falling with the general market. But a few made gains. Ulta Beauty (ULTA) rose 2.62, closing at 124.04. Citigroup upgraded the stock. Ulta gapped up out of base Sept. 13 in huge volume after reporting better-than-expected earnings. It formed a three-weeks-tight pattern, then rose above it. It followed-through from the short-term pattern Thursday. Because…
If anyone knows how to make heads turn for another glimpse, it's the folks at Ulta stores.
Makeup, anti-aging creams, hair styling tools — name a type of product that ups a person's beauty quotient and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sells it.
Recently, the one-stop salon and beauty products retailer has been upping its own beauty quotient — on Wall Street and with customers.

Ulta stock surged 17% on Sept. 13, after it reported second-quarter financials that sailed past views as it wowed customers with trendy new products, added more Clinique and Lancome branded boutiques to its stores, and lured more members into its generous loyalty program. Earnings climbed 30% to 70 cents a share, 3 cents ahead of forecasts.
Revenue popped 25% to $601 million, ahead of analyst views for $588.37 million.

Sales for stores open at least 14 months grew 8.4% vs. a year earlier, including the impact of e-commerce. That's a faster pace than the 6.7% gain it saw in the first quarter. E-commerce sales grew 72%, representing 130 basis points of the total company same-store sales increase.

Ulta has seen its profits grow by double digit percentages or better for the past 17 quarters. And if Wall Street is on target, that trend will continue. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters see full-year 2013 earnings rising 25% to $3.34 a share. They expect a 26% rise in 2014 and a 25% gain in 2015.

The impressive report was the first financial showing announced by CEO Mary Dillon, who took the helm July 1. Dillon had been CEO of U.S. Cellular (USM). She replaced Chuck Rubin, who left Ulta in February to become CEO of arts and crafts retailer Michaels Stores.
Middleman At Both Ends

Ulta has carved a niche in the specialty retail space as a one-stop shop for hair salon services and beauty and salon products at a variety of prices. It features more than 20,000 products, ranging from high-priced so-called prestige brands sold in department and specialty stores to lower-priced labels sold via the mass channel, including drugstores and discounters. It also offers a full-service hair salon in its stores.

"The key to Ulta's success is providing customers with convenience as a one-stop shop for beauty across all price segments and categories as well as an exciting shopping environment with a continual flow of new products and brands," said Telsey Advisory Group analyst David Wu. "Most recently we've seen a solid comp acceleration driven primarily by a higher ticket as the prestige skin care and color cosmetics continue to outperform all other categories."

Ulta has seen a nice run-up in its stock, which has traded at several fresh highs since the earnings report. Wu attributes the stock lift to the fact that Ulta saw an improving comp trend in the second quarter.

"It also saw a better-than-expected operating margin improvement," he added. "And the company continues to take significant market share in the U.S. beauty market from department stores, which continue to lose share."

Ulta's expansion of prestige brand boutiques for major flagship lines such as Clinique and Lancome, says Wu, has "strongly resonated" with customers and helped drive a higher ticket during the quarter.

Ulta added 39 Clinique boutiques in the second quarter; so it now has 90 stores featuring this Estee Lauder (EL)-owned brand. It expects to add 10 more Clinique boutiques during 2013. Five Lancome boutiques were added, bringing the total stores offering Lancome products to 85, with 20 additional Lancome boutiques underway.
Wu says the prestige segment continues to outperform all other segments in the beauty industry, a lot of which has been driven by strong innovation and solid demand, particularly in skin care.
From September 2012 to August 2013, the prestige beauty market grew 6% from a year earlier to $10.7 billion in sales, tallies Karen Grant, vice president and global industry analyst at the NPD Group.
Skin care sales grew 8% over that time, and makeup sales 7%.
Grant says while the growth in prestige beauty sales is still "steady and positive," it's not quite as accelerated as it had been last year or the prior year, as the industry faces tough comparisons.
Ulta has been cashing in on the segment's growth.

"Part of what's going on with stores like Ulta is we continue to see the specialty-store channel as the top channel for the prestige shopper," Grant told IBD. "One of the things consumers tell us is they love the format, which offers the freedom to choose from multiple brands. They also love the low pressure of the sales associates."
Department Store Rival
Wu calls Ulta, Sephora and other specialty beauty product stores "the future of U.S. beauty retailing."

"I expect these specialty beauty retailers to continue to take a significant share from department stores as consumers opt for convenience, a wide range of product options and a less intimidating environment," he said.
Ulta has drawn a loyal customer base. In the second quarter, its loyalty program membership grew to 12 million active members, up 19% from a year earlier.
On the new product front, Ulta is launching several new brands in the current quarter that have a strong following and unique brand personalities.

The names include Jamie Kern Lima's It Cosmetics line of color cosmetics that uses recently developed anti-aging ingredients along with appearance enhancers such as brightening pigments. Another brand is former supermodel Cindy Crawford's Meaningful Beauty anti-aging skin care system lineup.
Wu expects Dillon will be an "effective leader," given her experience in managing high-growth consumer companies.
"I think she's a great cultural fit," he said.
He sees Dillon continuing to pursue the company's existing growth strategy.

"Her top priority is to support store growth plans, address the business needs in supply chain management and omnichannel, and add an emotional point of view to the Ulta brand," adds Citi Research analyst Oliver Chen. "She's very highly energized."
Ulta ended the second quarter with 609 stores in 46 states. It expects to have 675 stores by year-end. The company's long-term guidance is to grow its square footage by 15% to 20% a year.
Chen says that long-term goal translates to "extremely attractive" square footage growth. He says the sector average in the companies he follows is between 3% and 5%.

Wu expects Ulta's sales to rise at around a 20% compound annual growth rate over the next five years as it benefits from mid-single-digit comp growth and "robust" store expansion. He says it has the ability to double its store base to about 1,200 locations over time.
Chen expects Ulta to keep its momentum as it benefits from strong traffic and pricing growth and new product innovations. It has the opportunity to keep gaining share from department stores, he adds.

Ulta is the third-largest company in IBD's Retail-Specialty industry group, after eyewear maker Luxottica Group (LUX) and PetSmart (PETM), and just ahead of GNC Holdings (GNC) and beauty products seller Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH).If anyone knows how to make heads turn for another glimpse, it's the folks at Ulta stores.Makeup, anti-aging creams, hair styling tools — name a type of product that ups a person's beauty quotient and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) sells it.Recently, the one-stop salon and beauty products retailer has been upping its own beauty quotient — on Wall Street and with customers.Ulta stock surged 17% on Sept. 13, after it reported second-quarter financials that sailed past views as it wowed customers with trendy new products, added more Clinique and Lancome branded boutiques to its stores, and lured more members into its generous loyalty program. Major averages ended the week on a down note Friday but that wasn't the case for many Sector Leaders. More than half the names in the screen rose, bucking the market's trend. (See charts on Page B9.)Ulta Beauty (ULTA) outperformed, rising 1.79 to 119.11 in soft turnover. The stock completed a three-weeks-tight pattern.Ulta has been stubborn about giving back gains after its bullish earnings-driven move during the week ended Sept. 13. Tight weekly closes are good to see after a breakout because it's a sign of strength and support. After a shakeout earlier this year, Ulta recently reset its base count. That means its latest breakout was from a first-stage structure.Elsewhere, Actavis' (ACT) breakout from a flat base in July took a while to get going, but the drugmaker extended gains for the second straight session in heavy volume. Shares hit an all-time high, rising 1.63 to 144.30. The company's $8.5 billion acquisition of Warner Chilcott is expected to close by the end of the year.Meanwhile, SS&C Technologies (SSNC) eased 5 cents to 38.50 in light trade. The mid-cap firm provides software that helps financial services firms automate and integrate front-office functions. A three-year earnings growth rate of 26% and sales growth of 30% point toward strong demand for the company's products.SS&C cleared a buy point of 38.90 on Sept. 17. Volume was strong but the stock closed barely above the entry. Shares gapped down on Sept. 19 after Carlyle Group sold its remaining 7.5 million-share stake in the company, but SS&C closed near its session high after early weakness. SS&C's breakout hasn't gained traction, yet its chart is still sound. The stock continues to hold above its 10-week moving average.

Stock futures surrendered thin, early gains and turned mixed ahead of Friday's open. Dow futures slipped 18 points but continued to trade above fair market value. S&P 500 futures dimmed 2 points, also trading above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 2.25 points. The stock market today opens Friday with a solid performance under its belt for the…

Stocks ended near session lows Wednesday, erasing early gains. The Nasdaq lost 1.1% while the Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.8% each. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume was slightly higher than Tuesday's levels. Technology licensing company Rambus (RMBS) bucked the sell-off, jumping 6% to a new 52-week high after settling a lawsuit with computer memory supplier SK Hynix.…
Stocks were still in the red, but have worked off some losses Monday afternoon.

The Nasdaq trimmed an earlier 0.5% loss to 0.2%. Apple (AAPL), which makes up about 11% of the index, was still up 2% in big volume. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2% and 0.1%, respectively. Turnover continued to track sharply lower on both major exchanges.

Michael Kors (KORS) reversed from a new high and fell 2% in below-average volume. It's now 4% past a 49.60 trigger in a cup-without-handle base cleared Aug. 14 on stellar Q2 results. On that day, the luxury-goods maker and retailer smashed expectations with earnings that surged 162% and sales that climbed 71%.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) gave up early gains, lost 2% and breached its 50-day line in fast trade. The stock is consolidating in a new base, but it's a late-stage pattern. Ulta Beauty reports Q2 results Sept. 6. Analysts see profit rising 34% to 51 cents a share, which would mark the third straight period of deceleration.

On the upside, Stratasys (SSYS) rallied nearly 3% to an all-time high in brisk trade. That puts it 29% past a 54.47 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. The stock broke out July 18 and climbed more than 20% in less than three weeks, triggering a key IBD rule. The rule states that stocks that gain 20% or more in three weeks or less should be held for at least eight weeks, unless sell signals appear.

Francesca's Holdings (FRAN) trimmed an earlier 5% gain to less than 1%. Despite this, it's still 5% past a 32.69 buy point in a cup-with-handle base. Francesca's, which operates women's boutiques, has delivered accelerating earnings growth for three straight quarters. Analysts see its profit rising 60% for the year.

Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI) was also off its session peak, but still up 2% in fast trade. Earlier, the stock cleared a 44.70 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. Texas Capital broke out from a flat base in June. Texas Capital provides financial services to businesses and private clients. It specializes in loans in the $10 million to $250 million range. It has posted triple-digit profit growth in four of the past five quarters.Stocks were still in the red, but have worked off some losses Monday afternoon.The Nasdaq trimmed an earlier 0.5% loss to 0.2%. Stocks with accelerating growth in earnings, sales and profit margins are worth a closer review. Here are three that have shown some acceleration recently: Maidenform Brands (MFB) saw declining or flat quarterly earnings in late 2008 to mid-2009. But in the past two quarters, earnings jumped from -6% to 17% and 113%. Revenue growth accelerated from 6% to 14% and…

Major averages ended mixed and mostly unchanged Monday in a dull session. At the close, the Nasdaq edged higher by 0.1%. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.1% and the S&P 500 fell a fraction. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume coming in 13% lower than Friday. Nasdaq volume fell 2%. In the stock market today, new issue Infoblox (BLOX) added…

Most of the major stock indexes continued to hold their best levels near Monday's halftime. But techs were again lagging. Stocks had rallied from the start on news that former Treasury Secretary Lawrence Summers withdrew from contention to be the next Federal Reserve chairman. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 1.1% to its best levels in more than a month.…
Stock futures stumbled onto mixed terrain ahead of Friday's open.

Dow futures were a relatively steady 42.6 points above fair market value. S&P 500 futures kept to a narrow 2.6-point gain. Nasdaq 100 futures backed out of early gains and were down a fraction, possibly hurt by Micron Technology's (MU) 15% premarket slide following a weak fiscal third-quarter report delivered late Thursday.
But it's clear that the stock market today has a lot to chew on.

An accord between the eurozone and Greece appeared to be off the table for Friday, with analysts projecting either a last-ditch deal would be reached over the weekend or all parties would start the week resigned to a Greek default on the $1.8 billion payment owed Tuesday to the International Monetary Fund. Global markets reflected investors positioning themselves for the eventualities.

That pushed Europe's leading indexes to modest losses near midday Friday, but the benchmark indexes in Paris and Frankfurt were still tracking toward gains in the 4% range for the week. The euro edged up against the dollar.

China's mainland markets dug into a serious correction, with the Shanghai Composite diving 7.4% and the tech-heavy Shenzhen Composite down 7.9% on Friday. The markets were hit by liquidity concerns triggered by a wave of IPOs last week, which led to fear that the frothy markets were set to unwind. The second week of steep declines left the indexes down 18.8% and 20.3%, respectively, from their June 13 peaks.
Hong Kong's larger and more internationally exposed Hang Seng Index fell 1.8% Friday, ending the week effectively flat.

In the U.S. markets have remained in their holding pattern this week. The S&P 500 ended Thursday down 0.4% and even with its 50-day line. The Nasdaq is down 0.1%, drifting 1% above its 50-day moving average.
The only real data point on Friday's economic front is the University of Michigan's final June consumer sentiment estimate, due out at 10 a.m. ET.

In stocks, Nike (NKE) muscled up nearly 4% ahead of the open after reporting solid fiscal fourth-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings jumped 25% in a fourth straight double-digit gain. Revenue gained a better-than-expected 5%. Analysts attributed the surprise to tight cost controls. The stock has been in a lilting uptrend, gaining only 1% above a 103.89 buy point after a mid-May breakout.

Athletic shoe retailer Finish Line (FINL) soared 7% after healthy Q1 results. A 7% earnings gain foiled consensus expectations for a 13% decline. A 9% revenue gain also topped expectations. The stock has been in a steady uptrend off a December low, routing out of a nine-month consolidation.

Chipmaker Micron slumped 15% ahead of the open. It reported late Thursday its fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings declined more than expected. The stock has been in a declining correction below a December peak.

Agricultural commodities were in motion Friday as continued rain in the Midwest raised concerns of lost production. Wheat futures jumped 2.5% to $5.51 a bushel and were up $12 for the week. Corn rose more than 1% Friday to $3.88, up nearly 10% over last Friday's settle.

Other commodities were mixed, with U.S. West Texas Intermediate crude oil down, Brent crude up a fraction each. Gold added a few pennies, rising to $1,173 an ounce. For the week, WTI oil and natural gas were essentially unchanged. Sluggish economic data couldn't keep buyers away Friday as major averages turned in another resilient performance. The Dow Jones industrial average outperformed, thanks to a strong showing from Intel (INTC).
The Dow rose 0.4%; the S&P 500 added 0.3% and the Nasdaq inched up 0.1%. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking lower than Thursday.

It was another decent performance for the indexes amid disappointing economic data. August retail sales rose 0.2%, below the consensus estimate of 0.5%. Excluding autos, sales rose 0.1%, below expectations of 0.3%.

Separately, the University of Michigan came out with its first reading on consumer confidence for September. The index slumped to 76.8 from 82.1 in August. Economists expected a mostly unchanged reading.
Inside the Dow, chipmaker Intel jumped 3%. Jefferies upgraded it to buy from hold and raised its price target to 30 from 27.

In the stock market today, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) was the star of the day as shares soared 18%. The stock gapped out of lengthy consolidation in heavy volume after the beauty retailer reported strong earnings late Thursday.

Elsewhere, Dunkin' Brands (DNKN) cleared a flat base, rising 3%. It was still within buying range, only 2% above the buy point. The company operates more than 10,500 restaurants in 31 countries but it still has big expansion plans. Yesterday, Dunkin' announced plans to expand into the U.K. with as many as 150 stores over the next five years.

The Fed meets next week on Tuesday and Wednesday and the market is widely expecting the Fed to start scaling back its $85 billion in monthly bond purchases. Not that long ago, it wasn't uncommon for taper talk to spark waves of selling in the market, but the market seems OK with it now.Sluggish economic data couldn't keep buyers away Friday as major averages turned in another resilient performance. Stocks trimmed gains late Monday on talk of the Federal Reserve tapering its bond purchases. The S&P 500 rose 0.2%, down from 0.4% at Monday's peak. Meanwhile, the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq rose 0.1% each. Volume was again tracking lower across the board in the stock market today. The major averages eased as Richmond Fed President Jeffrey…

With household budgets constrained, many are stretching the time between visits to the hair salon. Some are doing some quick colorings or other touch-ups themselves at home, or splurging on some pricey shampoo or makeup. Those affordable indulgences are seen as key to Ulta Beauty's  (ULTA) second-quarter results, due after the close today. Analysts expect the one-stop salon and…
Stocks held slight losses in early-afternoon action Friday, but had climbed off session lows hit after the latest consumer confidence report.

The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.3% and was on pace to end a 10-day winning streak, while the Nasdaq shed 0.2%. The S&P 500 fell 0.1% and traded less than 1% off its all-time peak of 1576 hit intraday Oct. 11, 2007.

For the week, the main indexes are on pace to deliver gains of 0.3% to 0.8%. Volume in the stock market today remained sharply higher across the board, boosted by quadruple witching expirations of options and futures contracts.

A raft of economic reports has come out Friday, most notably a weaker-than-expected figure for the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index. The March reading was 71.8, well below forecasts for 77.5, according to Econoday.

A reading on New York state manufacturing also missed expectations, but industrial production data beat forecasts. In addition, the consumer price index rose more than expected, while core prices matched forecasts.

Among highly rated stocks, Meritage Homes (MTH) jumped 4% in heavy turnover, hitting a new multiyear high and clearing a flat base with a buy point at 44.95. The Arizona-based company has an IBD Composite Rating of 89 out of a best-possible 99.

On the earnings front, Hibbett Sports (HIBB) jumped 5% after its fourth-quarter earnings squeaked by forecasts, while revenue met analyst views. The sporting goods chain provided full-year guidance in line with expectations. Two days of gains have lifted the thinly traded stock above both its 50- and 200-day lines of support. It continues to work on a consolidation begun in August.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) dived 16% after delivering fourth-quarter results late Thursday. Earnings and revenue were better than expected, but same-store sales growth slowed, and management gave disappointing sales and earnings guidance for Q1. CEO Chuck Rubin resigned in mid-February, sending shares tumbling far below key levels of support.

Also on the downside, Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) tumbled 5%. A handful of analysts have ramped up their ratings on the stock, but at the same time, a company response Thursday did little to ease concerns over a federal review of Intuitive's robotic surgical equipment. Wealth-Making Patterns: Third In A SeriesBaseball star Ted Williams noted in "The Science of Hitting" that the top hitters "work from a frame of reference, you learn what you might expect in certain instances."Exceptional investors do the same. They learn what to expect in certain kinds of markets.Take a look at the chart above. It's a weekly chart of the Nasdaq in 2010 and 2011. Pay attention to the action through August 2010. It shows a jagged decline.What would you expect from such a market when a new uptrend is confirmed?If you said you'd expect this market to create a fair number of double-bottom bases, you'd be right. The jagged action in the Nasdaq shared the general shape of a double-bottom pattern (1).That doesn't mean that some stocks didn't form cups or flat bases during this period. But a smooth cup or tight flat base had some choppy head winds to fight to complete its shape well.The double-bottom base didn't have that problem. The market was helping the double bottom conform to its classic form.The double-bottom base involves a W shape, with the second low undercutting the first low and a middle peak in the upper half of the pattern. The buy point is the middle peak plus 10 cents, unless a handle is formed.After the spring and summer market of 2010 was through with its jagged ways, a follow-through day came on Sept. 1 (2).Savvy investors were looking at the uptrend with a "frame of reference." They expected double-bottoms. And they were ready to jump on them.Panera Bread (PNRA) cleared an 85.23 buy point in a double-bottom base in the week-ended Sept. 3, 2010 (3). The restaurant's shares advanced 25% in about three months.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) broke out of a double bottom the same week, jumping over a 25.99 buy point. The specialty retailer gained 43% in three months. Apple (AAPL) popped above a 266.09 buy point in a double bottom the week ended Sept. 17 (4). It notched a 37% gain in five months.Lululemon (LULU) broke out the same week as Apple. After clearing a 43.47 buy point in a double bottom, the apparel retailer rose 96% in less than five months.

Stocks continued to show respectable gains at midafternoon Tuesday, as the Nasdaq fared best with a 1.1% advance. The S&P 500 rose 0.9%, while the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 0.8%. Volume was up from Monday's levels on both main exchanges. Among leading stocks, Michael Kors (KORS) jumped 4% in above-average volume, rallying off support at its 10-week moving…

If the U.S. health care system were run like PetSmart (PETM), people probably wouldn't be arguing about it. The company touts Total Lifetime Care for pets. PetSmart has full-service veterinary hospitals in roughly two of every three stores. PetSmart offers a wide variety of additional services and products: supplies, styling salons, training, PetsHotels with temperature controlled rooms, day camp for…
Stock futures pointed to a sharply higher open Thursday on European Central Bank President Mario Draghi's announcement of a new bond buying program and better-than-expected economic data.
Nasdaq 100 futures jumped 15 points vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures rallied 8 points and Dow futures climbed 80 points.

The European Central Bank left its key interest rate unchanged at 0.75%. ECB President Mario Draghi unveiled a new bond buying program dubbed "Monetary Outright Transactions" or MOT. The program would focus on buying sovereign bonds in the secondary market. Purchases will be sterilized and have no limits.
In economic news, planned layoffs fell to a 20-month low in August, noted outplacement firm Challenger, Gray & Christmas. Employers planned to cut 32,239 workers in August, down 12.5% from July.
The ADP employment survey said that private employers added 201,000 jobs in August or well above forecast for 149,000 jobs.
First-time jobless claims slipped by 12,000 to 365,000 or better than expectations for 370,000. Claims from the prior week were revised to 377,000 from 374,000.
The U.S. government's jobs report will be out Friday morning.
Data on the services sector will be out at 10 a.m. EDT. The ISM services index for August is slated to climb to 53 from 52.4 in July.

On the corporate front, Smith & Wesson Holding (SWHC) climbed 3% in premarket trading ahead of its fiscal Q1 results after the close. Analysts see the gun maker's earnings shooting up 350% to 18 cents a share. That would mark the second straight quarter of triple-digit growth. Sales are expected to grow 40% to $128.74 million.

Warner Chilcott (WCRX) tumbled 10% in preopen trading after announcing late Wednesday that major shareholders are planning to sell nearly 43 million shares. Selling shareholders include funds affiliated with Bain Capital Partners, J.P. Morgan Partners and Thomas H. Lee Partners.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) was little changed in premarket trade ahead of its Q2 report after the close. The retailer's earnings are expected to rise 34% to 51 cents a share. But that would mark the third straight period of deceleration. Sales are expected at $473.8 million, up 20% from a year ago.
