There's nothing like a bright new lipstick shade or a moisturizer that smooths and brightens the skin to lift a woman's spirits. The folks at Estee Lauder Cos. (EL) know all about it. The beauty products powerhouse has seen profits rise by at least double digits in all but two of the past 12 quarters. In the most recent fourth…
Stocks remained up sharply but a little off their session highs at midafternoon Wednesday, as investors cheered a federal budget deal that has averted the fiscal cliff.
The Nasdaq was up 2.4% after jumping nearly 2.9%. The S&P 500 gained 1.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 1.7%. Volume continued to track up significantly across the board.

On Assignment (ASGN) climbed 8% in big turnover, breaking out from a flat base with an early buy point at 20.84. The stock sports a best-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99, but it's somewhat thinly traded. On Assignment, which went public in 1992, provides permanent and temporary IT, health-care and lab staffing.
In the IBD 50 lineup, Ellie Mae (ELLI), PolyOne (POL), Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) were among the stocks that were trying to break out.

Ellie Mae has turned slightly negative after it climbed 10% out of the gate. The provider of on-demand software to the mortgage industry surged past a 28.96 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern, but it's now back below that level. Ellie Mae is No. 39 in Wednesday's IBD 50.

PolyOne jumped 9% in big turnover, clearing a 21.10 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern. The plastics maker, No. 14 in Wednesday's IBD 50, is also rebounding off support at its 10-week moving average.

Taiwan Semiconductor rose 5%, clearing a buy point at 17.57 from a four-weeks-tight pattern. It continued to trade tightly after forming the pattern. Volume at midafternoon was coming in above average, but below the level that you prefer to see with a breakout. The stock is No. 50 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup.

Ulta, No. 40 in the IBD 50, gained 3% in fast trade. Earlier in the session, the stock moved past a 101.71 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern. It's now just below that level. In addition, note the specialty retailer's most recent base is a riskier, later-stage structure.

Some economic reports missed expectations Wednesday, but the market is focused on Washington's fiscal cliff deal. "The bill does permanently fix the Alternative Minimum Tax issue and taxes for the middle class," Bruce Bittles, Baird's chief investment strategist, wrote in a note Wednesday morning.

"This is significant because it allows households and small businesses to plan longer term. The next hurdle for the market and economy is the debt-limit issue, which is likely to create another opportunity for political hero making," Bittles added.Stocks remained up sharply but a little off their session highs at midafternoon Wednesday, as investors cheered a federal budget deal that has averted the fiscal cliff.The Nasdaq was up 2.4% after jumping nearly 2.9%. Stocks remained up sharply but off their session highs in early-afternoon action Wednesday, as investors cheered a federal budget deal that has averted the fiscal cliff.
The Nasdaq rose 2.3% after being up nearly 2.9%. The S&P 500 gained 1.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average tacked on 1.7%. Volume continued to track up significantly across the board.
In the IBD 50 lineup, Ellie Mae (ELLI), PolyOne (POL), Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) were among the stocks that were trying to break out.

But Ellie Mae has erased most of its gain from the session, leaving it up just 2% after it climbed 10% out of the gate. The provider of on-demand software to the mortgage industry surged past a 28.96 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern, but it's now back below that level. Ellie Mae is No. 39 in Wednesday's IBD 50.

PolyOne jumped 9% in big turnover, clearing a 21.10 buy point from a four-weeks-tight pattern. The plastics maker, No. 14 in Wednesday's IBD 50, is also rebounding off support at its 10-week moving average.

Taiwan Semiconductor rose 5%, clearing a buy point at 17.57 from a four-weeks-tight pattern. It continued to trade tightly after forming the pattern. Volume in the early afternoon was coming in above average, but slightly below the level that you prefer to see with a breakout. The stock is No. 50 in Wednesday's IBD 50 lineup.

Ulta, No. 40 in the IBD 50, gained 3% in fast trade, moving past a 101.71 buy point from a cup-with-handle pattern. But note the specialty retailer's most recent base is a riskier, later-stage structure.

On the downside, Watson Pharmaceuticals (WPI) slumped 1.5% in heavy turnover, dropping further below its 10-week moving average. The stock, No. 25 in the IBD 50, also has dropped as much as 7% below its recent buy point at 89.55, tripping a key IBD sell rule.

Stock futures winked in and out of mixed trade ahead of Thursday's open, as weak economic data counter-balanced a rebound among many commodities-related stocks.
Dow futures shed 8.3 points. Nasdaq 100 futures showed a 4.5-point gain. S&P 500 futures traded less than 1% below fair market value.

The Nasdaq and S&P 500 have both slipped in five of the past six sessions. The Nasdaq remains above its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages, a positive. The S&P 500 on Wednesday stabbed straight through both lines of support in above-average trade — not good. Distribution days continue to climb, signaling selling by large investors and placing yet more pressure on the market.
So far for the week, the Nasdaq starts the session down 2.3%. The S&P 500 opens 2.1% in the hole. Small caps are clearly lagging, with the Russell 2000 and the S&P Small Cap 600 each off 3.2%.
The stock market today gets the week's first real dose of economic news.

The Labor Department reported unemployment claims veered sharply higher, to 282,000 claims, in the week ended Dec. 5. That was nearly 5% above the prior week's tally and far above economists' consensus projections for 270,000 claims. The four-week moving average edged up to 270,750, its second straight gain.

Prices of exports slipped more than expected in November, down 0.6% vs. forecasts for a 0.3% slip. That means U.S. producers are being paid less for their goods. Import prices also slipped less than expected, down 0.4% vs. estimates for a 0.8% decline.
The Treasury is due to report its November budget at 2 p.m.
In stocks, the Dow was flat to positive with advancing stocks holding to gains of less than 0.5%. DuPont (DD) trailed the group with a 1.1% slip.
Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) topped the S&P 500, up about 3% each.

At the bottom of the index, First Solar (FSLR) dropped 9% after the company released 2016 guidance late Wednesday. The midpoint of revenue projections of between $3.9 billion and $4.1 billion missed analyst expectations.
Gold miners mustered a premarket rally, with Anglogold Ashanti (AU) and Sibanye Gold (SBGL) ahead around 6% before the bell.

Fiber optic gear maker Ciena (CIEN) crumbled 10%. The Hanover, Md.-based operation reported better-than-expected fiscal fourth quarter sales and earnings, but management's Q1 and full-year revenue guidance stopped short of analyst projections.

Men'S Wearhouse (MW) tanked 20% after reporting weak Q3 revenue late Wednesday. Comparable sales at Jos. A. Bank stores fell 14.1%. in the quarter, and management said Q4-to-date comparable sales were down 35.1% at Jos. A. Bank stores, but up 5.5% across the rest of the company.
Most leaders on the IBD 50 list were flat ahead of the open. Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY) and ARM Holdings (ARMH) topped the group, up slightly more than 1% each.
On Wednesday, Dave & Buster's aggressively trimmed a 9% early gain to a 0.3% advance at the close. The backtrack pulled shares back below a 40.90 buy point in a double-bottom base.
At the other end of the IBD 50 list, Tesoro (TSO) dropped 0.7% — the worst premarket loss in the group.

Markets overseas moved generally lower. The main indexes in Hong Kong and Shanghai fell 0.5% each. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo gave up 1.3%, putting it down 2.3% so far for the week. In Europe, leading indexes in Paris, London and Frankfurt were down less than 0.5% at midday. Options sellers take note! With CBOE's Volatility Index close to its five-year low, popular option-selling strategies such as covered calls and credit spreads have lower income potential and greater risk potential. Positions have to be monitored more closely, and stop-loss points might have to be tighter than when volatility levels are higher. Maybe it's time to try buying options! "Tight stops," means that the point at which a stock position is closed (frequently at a loss) is closer to the current stock price. The risk of being stopped out, therefore, increases. But with volatility at low levels, the cost of buying call options as a stock substitute is greatly reduced. This article first discusses the cost of buying in-the-money calls as a stock substitute. Second, some examples using current Leaderboard stocks are reviewed. An in-the-money call is a call with a strike price that is below the current stock price. With a stock price of 55.00, for example, the 50 call is in the money by five points. CALL OPTIONS and THE EFFECTIVE STOCK PRICE A call option gives it owner the right to buy 100 shares of the underlying stock at the strike price of the call until the expiration date. Stock investors, however, should think ahead to the full cost of the stock if a call is exercised. For example, with XYZ stock trading at $74, consider an XYZ January 70 Call that is trading at $5 per share. For a cost of $500 per share plus commissions, this call, gives its owner the right to buy 100 shares of XYZ stock at $70 per share at any time until the expiration date in January. If the call is exercised, then the former call owner becomes a stockholder. The full cost of the stock is the strike price of the call plus the cost of the call plus commissions. In this example, the full cost of the stock — or the effective price — is 70.00 + 5.00 = 75 plus commissions. The buyer of XYZ stock at 75 who follows the CANSLIM guideline of limiting losses to 8% would likely have a stop-loss at approximately 68.00 for a potential loss of 6.00 per share. But the call cost only 5.00 per share. In this case, if the stock price drops sharply, the maximum loss of owning the call is less than the loss of 6.00 if the stock were purchased at 74 and sold at 68. Also, it is possible for the stock price to dip to 68 or below, thus triggering the stop-loss, and then rebound higher. Whereas a stockholder could easily be stopped out with such price action, it is possible that the call owner could stay in the trade. So, the next time you are considering buying a stock, look at the option prices to see if the effective price of buying the stock with an in-the-money call offers you an attractive alternative. Leaderboard Examples On Tuesday, October 22, ARM Holdings (ARMH) was trading at 49.66, 8% of which is about 4. The ARMH January 49 call was offered at 3.60 per share. The buyer of this call has the right to buy ARMH at 49.00 until January expiration in 87 days. The maximum risk, if the call expires worthless at expiration, is 3.60, or 7.2% of 49.66. So the call owner could hold for 87 days and not lose more that the 8% CANSLIM loss-limiting guideline. On the upside, the call buyer is paying an effective price for the stock of 52.60 versus the current price of 49.66.  Also on Tuesday Oceaneering International (OII) was trading at 86.03. The OII January 80 call was offered at 8.10 per share, which translates into an effective purchase price for the stock of 88.10. The option also costs 1.20 more that the CANSLIM guideline of 6.90, or 8%.  A third example is Ulta Salon Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA), which closed at 126.11 on Tuesday, and the ULTA January 120 call was offered at 12.10. This is 2.00 more that the CANSLIM guideline of 10.10, or 8%. Should investors buy any of these calls instead of the stock? Is the higher breakeven point worth the lower absolute risk and the near-certain ability to stay in the trade for 87 days? There is no "right" or "wrong" answer to these questions. Every investor must make a personal decision.
Major averages scored solid gains just over two hours into Thursday's session, helped in part by weakness in the U.S. dollar.
The Dow Jones industrial average added 1.2%, the S&P 500 gained 1% and the Nasdaq rose 0.6%. NYSE and Nasdaq volume was tracking a touch higher than Wednesday's levels.

The Dow held up pretty well considering that Intel (INTC) slumped 4%. Earlier today, the chip giant lowered its first-quarter sales outlook, citing soft demand for business desktop computers. Other Dow components picked up the slack, including Walt Disney (DIS) and American Express (AXP).

In the stock market today, a couple of restaurant stocks garnered attention. Zoe's Kitchen (ZOES) jumped 4% but Shake Shack (SHAK) slumped more than 3% after both fast-casual chains announced fourth-quarter results after Wednesday's close.

Abiomed (ABMD) outperformed, rising 4%. It's been trading tightly and holding on to gains after a bullish move during the week ended Jan. 30. It makes medical devices to assist or replace the pumping function of the heart. In its latest reported quarter, earnings per share jumped 173% from a year ago. Sales growth accelerated for the second straight quarter, rising 34% to $62 million.

Buyers were in Ulta Beauty (ULTA) again ahead of its earnings report after the close. Shares rose 1%. A recent base breakout over 134.60 was slow to materialize, but the stock is now 6.5% past the buy point.

In economic news, weekly jobless claims fell 19% to 289,000 in the week ended March 7, the Labor Department reported. That sharply undercut expectations for a mild decline to 309,000. Meanwhile, the Commerce Department reported that retail sales slipped 0.6% in February, well below forecasts for a 0.3% gain. Minus auto sales, sales were down 0.1%. Minus auto sales, sales were down 0.1%. Economists projected a 0.5% gain.
Major averages were sharply lower about three-and-a-half hours into Thursday's session as jitters about the government shutdown and the looming debt-ceiling deadline took center stage again.
Leading growth stocks were hit particularly hard, a potentially worrisome sign. Nearly half the stocks in the IBD 50 lost 2% or more.

The Nasdaq led the way, falling 1.2%; the S&P 500 lost 1% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.9%. Preliminary data showed NYSE volume tracking 7% lower than Wednesday. Nasdaq volume rose 8%. Headed into today, the S&P 500 showed five distribution days and the Nasdaq showed three.

In the stock market today, sellers were in Tesla Motors (TSLA) again. Shares fell 5% on the heels of Wednesday's 6% loss. Despite recent price weakness, the stock continues to hold above its 50-day moving average around 160, a key support level for now. Tesla got double-whammied Wednesday by an analyst downgrade and news that a Tesla Model S sedan caught fire after hitting some metal debris in the road.

On the downside, Biogen Idec (BIIB) slumped 4% despite positive news surrounding Tysabri, a drug it acquired earlier this year from Elan (ELN). New data revealed that Tysabri showed efficacy in reducing multiple sclerosis (MS) disease activity.
Biogen's potential blockbuster drug is Tecfidera, an oral treatment for MS.

Meanwhile, buyers came into Cree (CREE) again as shares rose 4%. The move comes two days after Canaccord Genuity upgraded the maker of LED lighting products to buy from hold and its price target to 80 from 65.
Cree showed bearish price action during the week ended Aug. 16 but the stock has recovered nicely. It's been consolidating gains for eight weeks and is closing in quickly on a 52-week high of 76.

Fast-growing retailer Ulta Beauty (ULTA) bucked the trend, rising 2%. On Tuesday, Ulta poked above a three-weeks-tight buy point of 121.60 but volume was light. Sector Leaders had a strong day Tuesday as the general market soared, even after Congress failed to resolve budget disagreements and a partial government shutdown took effect.Sixteen of the 18 Sector Leaders rose, and the two that fell, NetEase (NTES) and Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), were down less than 1% each.Four Sector Leaders pushed to new highs.Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) moved to a new high in average volume. It was up nearly 4% and cleared a 105.50 buy point from a five-week flat base. Leading drugmakers are starting to show some strength. The Medical-Ethical Drugs industry group, of which Valeant is a member, is ranked No. 22 out of 197 groups tracked by IBD. It was ranked No. 33 just eight weeks ago.The Canadian company makes drugs in the areas of dermatology and oral health and over-the-counter products. It has stable earnings growth. Its five-year Earnings Stability Factor is 15 on a scale of 0 to 99, where low numbers correspond to stable earnings.Its return on equity is 37%. Anything over 17% is good.Priceline.com (PCLN) was up nearly 3%, trading at an all-time high of 1,038.27. It's 4% past a flat base. Priceline has an Earnings Stability Factor of 7. In the most recent quarter, EPS was up 24%. Analysts are looking for a 31% increase in earnings in the next report.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) moved up out of a three-weeks tight pattern in volume that was slightly above average. Ulta gapped up and finished 17% above a long consolidation Sept. 13 following an earnings report. It held its gains, moving in a tight range for three weeks. It has a Composite Rating of 95.

Sector Leaders were, for the most part, unfazed by Monday's government-shutdown-inspired selloff.Eleven of the 18 stocks on the elite list changed 1% or less.Only two, Ocwen Financial (OCN) and  Evercore Partners (EVR), lost 2%. Ocwen pierced its 10-day moving average, but remained near a high well above its 50-day line. Evercore was also trading below its 10-day and above its 50-day.There were two winners for the day. Chinese real estate website SouFun Holdings (SFUN) rose 4% in heavy volume. It's trading near a high and 85% extended from a long base, from which it broke out July 16.SouFun earnings grew 61%, 135% and 56% over the past three quarters. Analysts are forecasting EPS growth of 31% this year and 20% next year. The stock has an EPS Rating of 99 and a Relative Price Strength Rating of 98.Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) also rose 2%, hitting a new high in heavy volume. Jazz broke out of a cup-with-handle base at 60.30 on May 22 and has shot up 53% without even touching its 50-day line.The developer of specialty drugs has a five-year growth rate of 101%. Earnings last quarter rose 31% and sales were up 68%.Analysts expect another 31% increase in earnings in the next report.Jazz's return on equity, a measure of how efficiently management turns a profit, was 44% last year. Anything above 17% is good.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) has been trading in a tight range since it gapped up out of a base following a bullish earnings report Sept. 13. It completed a three-weeks-tight pattern at the end of last week.Ulta operates more than 500 beauty stores in 45 states. Its Composite Rating is 96.
Stocks remained near intraday lows Wednesday afternoon as a fresh drop in oil prices fanned concerns about global economic growth.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Nasdaq 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and the Nasdaq was running well below Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.

Oil prices sank 5%, dragging down energy stocks, as the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries pared its 2015 oil demand forecast to the lowest level since 2012. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and and Chevron (CVX) each lost 3%.

Yum Brands (YUM), the owner of Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, dropped 5% and sliced through its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in heavy volume after lowering its profit outlook for the year on weaker-than-expected sales in China.

Fellow fast-food retailerBurger King Worldwide (BKW) fared better, reversing higher and rising more than 2% after RBC Capital Markets upgraded the stock to outperform from sector perform. RBC raised its price target on the stock to 38 from 30 on expectations that Burger King's takeover of Canadian coffee and doughnut chain Tim Hortons will yield cost savings.

Burger King rebounded off support at its 50-day line and was trying to retake a 33.44 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. Volume was heavy, but the latest base was a late-stage structure, which makes it riskier than those that form earlier in a stock's run.

Meanwhile, warehouse club operator Costco (COST) slipped 1% despite reporting better-than-expected quarterly profit. The stock is well extended from a pullback to the 50-day moving average in October.Stocks remained near intraday lows Wednesday afternoon as a fresh drop in oil prices fanned concerns about global economic growth.The Dow Jones industrial average was down 0.8%, the S&P 500 0.7% and the Nasdaq 0.6%. Volume on the NYSE and the Nasdaq was running well below Tuesday's levels in the stock market today.Oil prices sank 5%, dragging down energy stocks, as the Organization for Petroleum Exporting Countries pared its 2015 oil demand forecast to the lowest level since 2012. Exxon Mobil (XOM) and and Chevron (CVX) each lost 3%.Yum Brands (YUM), the owner of Taco Bell, Pizza Hut and KFC, dropped 5% and sliced through its 50-day and 200-day moving averages in heavy volume after lowering its profit outlook for the year on weaker-than-expected sales in China.Fellow fast-food retailerBurger King Worldwide (BKW) fared better, reversing higher and rising more than 2% after RBC Capital Markets upgraded the stock to outperform from sector perform. RBC raised its price target on the stock to 38 from 30 on expectations that Burger King's takeover of Canadian coffee and doughnut chain Tim Hortons will yield cost savings.Burger King rebounded off support at its 50-day line and was trying to retake a 33.44 buy point of a cup-with-handle base. Volume was heavy, but the latest base was a late-stage structure, which makes it riskier than those that form earlier in a stock's run.Meanwhile, warehouse club operator Costco (COST) slipped 1% despite reporting better-than-expected quarterly profit. The stock is well extended from a pullback to the 50-day moving average in October.

Stocks ebbed back into narrow losses near midday, following the morning's confused jobs report and weak export price data. The Nasdaq, the Dow Jones industrial average backed out of early gains and were down 0.2%. The S&P 500 also inched lower to a 0.2% loss. Volume remained soft across the stock market today, down 4% on the Nasdaq and 3%…
Stocks logged a stead-as-she-goes open, notching modest gains after a burst of mixed economic news.

The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average all held 0.4% gains. Volume opened higher, then turned mixed as NYSE trade slipped a fraction compared with the same time Wednesday. Nasdaq volume was up 9%.
The stock market today opened to an early boost from positive weekly jobless claims data, as well as a healthy producer price report for February.

The deficit in the U.S. current account balance narrowed slightly in the fourth quarter to $110.4 billion vs. an upwardly revised $112.4 billion in Q3. Analysts had expected the measure of import vs. export trade to expand to $111.9 billion, based on the Commerce Department's initial $107.5 billion estimate for the third quarter. Lower exports of soybeans and civilian aircraft accounted for a large portion of the shift.
In stocks, data-management software provider CommVault Systems (CVLT) popped more than 5% in strong trade. The IBD 50 stock broke out of a flat base as it surged past a 79.63 buy point.

EBay (EBAY) climbed 3% in eight times its average trade. That moved the online retail and auction site to the top of the week's price range. The stock has been pulling back in mixed trade for about four weeks as it works on a flat base.

Ebix (EBIX) gapped up to an 11% gain in massive trade at the open. That hoisted the software-as-a-service provider back above its 50-day moving average, but still well below the 200-day line. The stock has been consolidating since a sharp sell-off in November.

Looking good and investing well at the same time is getting easier. Companies that help people look their best are reporting hot earnings, with several in this week's elite IBD 50 list. Those stocks include Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA), Lululemon Athletica (LULU), Herbalife (HLF) and Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS). The companies are listed by their IBD 50 ranking.
1. Ulta Salon

The retailer provides full salon services as well as a wide variety of health and beauty products at a wide range of price points. Ulta Salon also has been testing in-store boutiques with upscale cosmetics maker Lancome.

In its fiscal Q2 ended July 30, Ulta Salon reported a 73% EPS gain to 38 cents a share, the second straight quarter of acceleration and 19% above views. Revenue climbed 23% to $394.8 million, the fourth straight quarter of gradual acceleration.
For the just-ended Q3, analysts expected Ulta to report a 68% EPS gain on a 20% sales gain.

Ulta Salon shares shot up after the latest earnings report, then consolidated for several weeks. They found support last week at the 50-day line even as the major averages sold off, then broke out to new highs Friday.
Ulta is an aging beauty. Its late-stage breakout makes it more vulnerable to failure, but it could still work.
Cosmetics are a hot sector generally, with Elizabeth Arden (RDEN) and especially Estee Lauder (EL) climbing on strong quarterly results out last week.
2. Lululemon Athletica

The yoga-inspired apparel maker definitely benefits from women seeking to look stylish as they work out. Lululemon has enjoyed pricing power among its affluent customers despite a generally sluggish economy. Part of that reflects a lack of inventory. Demand has been so strong that the company has had trouble keeping up. It's a problem, but about the best problem a retailer could have.

Earnings in the latest quarter rose 73% vs. a year earlier. Revenue climbed 39%. Both were modestly stronger gains than in the prior quarter. At the time, Lululemon gave cautious guidance — EPS of 22-24 cents and revenue of $225 million-$230 million.
Still, Wall Street is expecting 25 cents, up 39%, with sales climbing 34% to $234.7 million.

Lululemon shares rebounded from a brief plunge below their 200-day average a month ago, and have recently found support above their 50-day line. The stock, consolidating since late July, is near key resistance levels around 59.50 and 62.
8. Herbalife

The company markets low-calorie nutritious shakes as well other weight-loss and nutrition products. As emerging markets catch up to America's wealth, they are catching up with America's obesity woes. Both factors fuel a growing market.
Herbalife reported a 47% EPS gain last week, better than expected. Revenue climbed 30%, the best gain in several years and also far above forecasts. Asia and Latin America led the way.
But the company sees Q4 profit and sales below forecasts.
Herbalife shares, which were breaking out of a 2-month base early last week, pulled back. They may be forming a handle.
21. Nu Skin Enterprises

Nu Skin specializes in direct sales of anti-aging products and nutritional supplements. Like Herbalife and other direct-selling firms, Nu Skin is enjoying strong growth in Asia and other emerging markets — 86% of its 2010 revenue hailed from overseas.
On Oct. 25, Nu Skin reported quarterly profit of 68 cents a share, up 24% vs. a year earlier and above forecasts. Revenue climbed 12% to $428.4 million, the best in a year.
Sales growth is expected to keep accelerating this quarter, to 18%.
Nu Skin shares have been on a tear, surging 37% from their Oct. 4 intraday low to Nov. 4, when it hit yet another record high.

Stocks fell modestly Thursday, content to hold on to the majority of recent gains.
Earlier today, weekly jobless claims fell more than expected to 292,000 but the Labor Department acknowledged that the drop was a result of computer glitches in two unnamed states.
The S&P 500 fell 0.2% while the Dow Jones industrial average and Nasdaq eased 0.1% each. Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking very close to Wednesday's level.

In the stock market today, Lululemon Athletica (LULU) took a beating as shares fell 4.5%. Earlier today, the yoga retailer reported better-than-expected earnings and sales growth but the company lowered its full-year earnings outlook.

Kroger (KR), however, was a bright spot on the earnings front. Shares rose 3% and the stock reclaimed its 50-day moving average. Kroger forecast full-year same-store sales growth of 3% to 3.5%, above its previous projection of 2.5% to 3.5%.
Also on the upside, Herbalife (HLF) gained more ground after a recent bounce off its 10-week moving average. Shares rose 2.5%. It's only 1% off a 52-week high.
Elsewhere, 3D printing firms and a couple of mortgage servicers took heat.
3D Systems (DDD) dropped 3% while Stratasys (SSYS) surrendered 4%. In the mortgage servicing space, Nationstar Mortgage Holdings (NSM) gave up 3% and Ocwen Financial (OCN) lost 1.5%.
After the close, watch for earnings from Ulta Beauty (ULTA). After a huge price run, a shakeout in March caused Ulta to reset its base count, but its current technical health is so-so at best.

It's only 5% off a high and trading tightly, but the stock has been trading at its 10-week moving average for several weeks now. The stock hasn't exactly been showing relative price strength, either, with a middling Relative Strength Rating of 51.

The leading stocks ended mixed Tuesday. SodaStream's (SODA) hot streak continued while Michael Kors (KORS) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) continued their struggles at their 50-day lines. SodaStream, which makes machines that can turn tap water into soft drinks, climbed 0.79, or 2%, to 41.98 in above-average volume. The stock has risen for six straight sessions as it nears new highs.…

Stocks continued to show modest losses in early afternoon trading Friday, putting them mostly on pace to score their second weekly gains in a row. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 both shed 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.1%. Volume was down from Thursday's levels across the board. For the week, the Nasdaq is set to gain 1.3%…

Early gains faded fast Wednesday, one day after the market entered a correction. Stocks are near session lows, with the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 threatening fresh breaks below their 50-day lines.
The Nasdaq lost 0.6% while the Dow and S&P 500 fell 0.4% each. Preliminary data shows NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking very close to Tuesday's levels.

In the stock market today, oil and gas producer Oasis Petroleum (OAS) gave back early gains but still rose 1% in strong trade. The company controls about 335,000 acres in the Montana and North Dakota regions of the Williston Basin. Oasis recently cleared a 39.78 cup-with-handle buy point and is now 3% above the buy point.

Meanwhile, two names continued work on handle areas in cup-with-handle patterns. IAC/Interactive (IACI) is off a fraction. The company is featured in today's New America. A potential buy point is 52.37, but buying breakouts when the market is in correction mode is generally a losing proposition. Meanwhile, railroad operator Genesee & Wyoming (GWR) is rising 1%. Its current handle area is almost four weeks old.

In IPO news, Gigamon (GIMO) soared 36% in its debut. It priced last night at 19, at the midpoint of a proposed range of 18 to 20. Shares opened at 23.08. The company makes software-based appliances that help manage data traffic.

In earnings news, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) jumped 16% and held near highs after the retailer reported a solid quarter. Earnings and sales topped expectations, while investors shrugged off lukewarm guidance for the current quarter. With a Relative Price Strength Rating of 17, Ulta is far from a market leader. That said, Ulta recently reset its base count and staged a technical breakout today, clearing a recent high of 96.30. It's still about 4% off its all-time high.

On the downside, Biogen-Idec (BIIB) plunged 7% in fast turnover after Citigroup downgraded shares to neutral from buy, saying that European Union regulators are unlikely to protect Biogen's blockbuster multiple sclerosis drug Tecfidera from generic competition. Big sellers were in the stock early last week. After a brief bounce off the 50-day moving average, Biogen-Idec is back below the key suppport level.

Also in the biotech space, Celgene (CELG) was turned away at its 50-day moving average after early strength. Shares show a fractional gain after being up by as much as 4%. Earlier today, the company reported positive Phase III data for its oral psoriatic arthritis drug Apremilast. And it announced a stock buyback program worth up to $3 billion.
At the New York Mercantile Exchange, August gold was recently trading around $1,391.20 an ounce, up $14.10. July crude oil added 70 cents to $96.08 a barrel.

The S&P 500 was steady, up 0.1%. The Nasdaq hung a fraction into the red. Volume was above the stock market today's early lows, but still down 33% on the…

Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. The S&P 500 fell 0.8%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq were each down 0.7%.
Volume was running higher on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq compared to the same time Wednesday.

Economic news was mixed, with unemployment claims falling a little less than expected in the week ended Dec. 12, while manufacturing in the mid-Atlantic region fell much more than expected in December. The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose 0.4% in November, down from the prior month's 0.6% increase but ahead of analysts' forecasts.
Mining and energy stocks were hit hardest in the stock market today on declines in oil and metals prices.
Newmont Mining (NEM), a Colorado-based miner of gold and silver, lost 8%, leading the S&P 500 lower. Oil transportation stock Oneok (OKE) also dropped about 8%.

Most IBD 50 stocks were lower, led by Global Payments (GPN), which fell more than 2% in heavy volume. The stock plunged 8% on Wednesday, slicing through its 50-day line, after agreeing to buy rival credit card payments processor Heartland Payment Systems (HPY) for $4.3 billion.
Total System Services (TSS), another credit card payments processor in the IBD 50, fell 2.7% but remains well above a 48.18 buy point of a cup-with-handle base that it cleared in October.
But Chinese social media stock Weibo (WB) was a bright spot. It jumped more than 4% in heavy volume, closing in on a 20.80 buy point of a deep, cup-shaped base.

The stock boasts a rising Relative Strength line and an Accumulation/Distribution Rating of A, indicating strong demand for the shares. The stock has more than doubled since falling to a low of 8.78 on Aug. 24.Stocks extended losses midday Thursday, a day after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. Stocks achieved big gains Wednesday, ending near their session highs for the third day in a row.
The Nasdaq and Dow Jones industrial average both jumped 2.4%, while the S&P 500 climbed 2.3%. Volume increased on both main exchanges, according to early data.
The Dow and S&P 500 both scored their largest up days of 2012. Each index also closed back above its 200-day moving average for the first time since May 31.

After the market's close, Men's Wearhouse (MW) plunged in extended trading after reporting first-quarter earnings that fell short of forecasts. The clothing retailer, which sports an 80 IBD Composite Rating out of a best-possible 99, has been consolidating below its 50-day moving average in recent weeks.

Headlines provided a lift Wednesday. The Fed's beige book report indicated the U.S. economy has continued to expand at a moderate pace. In the eurozone, officials reportedly discussed rescuing Spain's teetering banks. European Central Bank President Mario Draghi also made reassuring comments.

During the regular session, Coinstar (CSTR), the operator of Redbox DVD rental kiosks, added 6% in active turnover on news of its partnership with Starbucks (SBUX) to sell coffee in "Rubi" kiosks at grocery chains, drugstores and elsewhere starting this summer. Coinstar topped its 50-day moving average, where it had been meeting resistance.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) soared 8% in big volume after the company issued an upbeat Q1 report late Tuesday. The highly rated stock tried to break out of a consolidation Wednesday, but the pattern formed mainly below Ulta's 50-day moving average.

On Thursday, Cooper Cos. (COO) and Titan Machinery (TITN) are among the companies expected to report quarterly earnings. (COO) and Titan Machinery (TITN) are among the companies expected to report quarterly earnings. The session's economic data will include the weekly reading on new jobless claims.

Stocks improved but remained mixed in late-afternoon action Thursday, as the Nasdaq fared best with a 0.3% gain.
The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 both pulled back 0.1% below their prior close. Volume continued to track lower across the board.
Lululemon Athletica (LULU) was still down sharply in fast trade, but it had cut its loss to 6% after falling as much as 16% out of the gate.
Before the opening bell, the seller of high-end yoga-themed exercise apparel posted third-quarter earnings that beat views, but sales that missed forecasts.
Lululemon said it sees Q4 EPS of 40 to 42 cents on sales of $327 million to $332 million. Analysts were expecting 41 cents and $327.3 million.
Before Thursday's tumble, the stock had been bumping up against its 200-day moving average as it worked on a riskier, late-stage base. It's No. 6 in this week's IBD 50.

Meanwhile, Ulta Beauty (ULTA) slipped 1% in big trade ahead of its Q3 earnings report, due after the market's close today. Wall Street sees EPS rising 65% to 38 cents as revenue increases 20% to $406.5 million.
The stock, No. 2 in the IBD 50, has been dancing above and below its 50-day moving average this week. It recently had a failed breakout from a late-stage base.

Another retailer, Kohl's (KSS) dropped 7% in heavy volume, slicing below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages. The department store chain said November same-store sales decreased 6.2%, missing forecasts for a 2% increase.

Ulta Salon (ULTA) expects third-quarter results to exceed Wall Street views as accelerating sales growth also helped lift the second quarter above expectations.
The beauty products retailer sees third-quarter earnings of 36-38 cents a share, above analysts' estimates of 34 cents, on sales of $400 million to $407 million, better than views of $395.5 million.
In after-hours trading, shares edged up 1%, adding to a 5% gain in the regular session. Rival Sally Beauty  (SBH) was unchanged late, but closed down 0.8%.
Ulta Salon is No. 4 on this week's IBD 50 list of top companies and is just above its 50-day moving average. Yoga apparel chain Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which reports earnings Friday, is No. 1.

Second-quarter profit jumped 73% to 38 cents a share, beating expectations by 6 cents. Sales rose 23% to $394.6 million, above views of $384.2 million, marking the fourth straight quarter of accelerating sales gains.
Same-store sales leapt 11.3%, compared with an increase of 10.8% a year earlier. Analysts expected slowing same-store sales growth, which last year benefited from the post-recession rebound.

Ulta credited sales growth to new products and marketing efforts that boosted traffic. All glammed up with trendy new brands, Ulta Beauty is sitting pretty.
The one-stop salon and beauty products retailer upped its first-quarter outlook last week as it lured customers into stores with new offerings and attractive promotions.

Ulta (ULTA) expects first-quarter earnings of 52 to 53 cents a share vs. its prior forecast of 46 cents to 48 cents a share. It now sees sales of $474 million, up from its previous guidance of $452 million to $460 million, and a 22.8% increase over the prior year. It expects same-store sales to rise a hefty 10.1% vs. a year earlier compared with a prior estimate of a 6% to 8% gain.

Ulta and other beauty product retailers like Sally Beauty (SBH) are cashing in on the biggest surge in spending on skin care, makeup and fragrances in years. U.S. sales of so-called prestige beauty products, which are sold in department and specialty stores, rose 11% to $9.5 billion in 2011, according to market research firm NPD Group.
Unprecedented Growth

"In the 15 years that NPD has been tracking the prestige beauty industry, we have never seen growth like this, especially across all categories," said Karen Grant, vice president and senior global industry analyst.
The pace has picked up. Sales popped 14% to $2.3 billion in the first quarter, according to NPD.

Ulta, says Grant, is among the beauty products retailers that are helping to drive the category overall. "Stores like Ulta have been invigorating the retail environment, making beauty products more accessible and exciting with more events, social networking and relationship building with consumers," she said.
Ulta has carved a niche in the specialty retail space as a one-stop shop for hair salon services and beauty and salon products at a variety of prices.

It features more than 20,000 products, ranging from high-priced prestige brands to lower-priced labels sold via the mass channel, including drugstores and discounters. It also offers a full-service hair salon in its stores.
Grant says Ulta's model "plays extremely well" with consumers who shop across both the prestige and mass channels.

The jump in spending on beauty products sold in department stores and specialty stores reflects a renewed interest in grooming and the desire to have a more polished appearance on the part of men and women, Grant says.
Also, she adds, beauty products are a "pragmatic luxury." The average price point for these items is under $50 and these products typically last a long time, roughly a few months.

"The No. 1 reason people say they buy beauty products is to make them feel better about themselves and more confident," Grant said. "Beauty products become a little retail therapy, an ego boost at great prices."
Ulta's bright first-quarter forecast follows a stunning end to 2011. Fourth-quarter earnings rose 52% to 73 cents a share, topping views. Sales grew 23% to $582.5 million, also ahead of forecasts.
Wells Fargo Securities analyst Evren Kopelman concurs Ulta has reaped the benefits of women increasing their spending on cosmetics.

But Ulta's strong showing has been driven by new product introductions over the past 18 to 24 months in skin care, hair care and nail care, says Kopelman. Among them is the Clarisonic Mia 2 Sonic Skin Cleansing System, equipped with facial and skin scrubbers introduced at Ulta stores during last year's third quarter.

That effort has been ongoing. On the fourth-quarter conference call, Chief Executive Chuck Rubin said the company planned to introduce several new brands in the first quarter, including The Body Shop and Carol's Daughter.

Also on tap were new products and services such as eyelashes from Katy Perry, an exclusive launch of Ojon super sleek hair treatment, and Chromatics, a new hair-coloring service from Redken that Ulta says provides more vibrant color and healthier hair benefits than other color services.
New Stores
Kopelman says new brand and services attract new customers. It has been opening new stores, including 18 added in the first quarter. As of April 28, it had 467 stores in 44 states.
"The more stores they open, the more brand recognition," she said.
Rubin took Ulta's helm in September 2010, replacing long-time chief executive Lyn Kirby.
"He's done a great job," said Kopelman.
She says that since Rubin became CEO, same-store sales have grown by double digits and Ulta's earnings growth has been "stellar."
Watchers expect that strong growth to continue. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters forecast full-year earnings to rise 31% to $2.49 a share. They expect a 25% increase in 2013.
As long as industry growth remains robust, they're benefiting because they're executing well and adding new brands and services, said Kopelman.
Grant is upbeat about the industry's prospects.

"The environment is ripe for continuing growth," she said. "We're not seeing anything slowing down at this time."All glammed up with trendy new brands, Ulta Beauty is sitting pretty.The one-stop salon and beauty products retailer upped its first-quarter outlook last week as it lured customers into stores with new offerings and attractive promotions.Ulta (ULTA) expects first-quarter earnings of 52 to 53 cents a share vs. its prior forecast of 46 cents to 48 cents a share. Stocks opened lower, but quickly reversed to make narrow gains Wednesday as investors took in a broad array of economic news.
The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average all erased early losses and rose 0.1%. Volume was narrowly mixed, a fraction lower on the Nasdaq and up 5% on the NYSE.

The stock market today opened to healthy employment news, with ADP reporting private-sector employers added an above-forecast 215,000 jobs in November. Mortgage applications dived for a fifth straight week, however, the Mortgage Banker's Association said, sending activity to its lowest level in 15 months.

New-home sales data were mixed, down in September and up in October as the Commerce Department catches up due to weeks lost during the federal shutdown. September sales slipped 7% (from an upwardly revised 379,000 sales in August) to an annualized rate of 354,000 homes sold. October sales rebounded sharply, to a pace of 444,000, up 25% over September's action. Economists had forecast a rate of 420,000 sales in September and 425,000 in October.
The service sector missed expectations in November, sending the Institute for Supply Management's service index to 53.9 vs. a 55.4 showing in October. Analysts had projected an increased to 55.5.
Also on the economic calendar this afternoon, the Federal Reserve is expected to release its December beige book report at 2 p.m. EST.

Refinery stocks were being hit as oil prices held near $97 a barrel, up 5% this week and at their highest level since the start of November. Valero (VLO) dropped 3%. Tesoro (TSO) and Marathon Petroleum (MPC) sank more than 4% each. Marathon and Valero fell in heavy trade.
First Solar (FSLR) bucked up 3%. The Tempe, Ariz.-based maker of solar electrical components and systems continues to consolidate gently.

Among leaders, a third of the IBD 50 list opened to early gains Wednesday. Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) stepped out to an early lead, up more than 2%. The Ireland-based drugmaker has been taking a breather just below its Oct. 25 high after a four-week sprint left it extended above a rebound from the 10-week moving average.

Stocks rose for a second day Thursday, closing near session highs, after Greece neared a debt swap deal with private investors to avoid a default that would have roiled global financial markets.

The Nasdaq rallied 1.2% and the S&P 500 1%. Both have almost wiped out losses earlier in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 0.6%. Volume was a touch higher on the Nasdaq but a bit lower on the NYSE.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) was little changed in after-hours trading Thursday following a better-than-expected Q4 earnings report. But it gave a cautious Q1 sales outlook. The stock had hit a record high during the regular session, closing up 1.5% at 89.27. It's extended from a cup base.
Rival Sally Beauty (SBH) climbed 2% to a new high. It's now 14% past a 21.95 buy point from a flat base. Last month, the company matched expectations with an 18% rise in fiscal Q1 earnings.

Meanwhile, Green Mountain Coffee (GMCR) dived as much as 19% in post-session trading after Starbucks (SBUX) introduced a single-serve coffee maker to compete with Green Mountain's Keurig coffee brewer and accompanying K-Cups. Starbucks was up after hours.
Also Thursday, Stamps.com (STMP) shares shot up nearly 14% after it reportedly settled patent lawsuits with competitor Endicia.

Coach (COH) rose 5% in heavy volume, but it's still struggling with a 76.80 buy point from a three-weeks-tight. The major indexes edged lower in pre-market action Monday, as investors fretted over ongoing European debt concerns and looked past a strong showing by retailers over the holiday weekend.Nasdaq 100, S&P 500 and Dow futures traded slightly lower ahead of the opening bell.The European Union signed an agreement Sunday to provide nearly $90 billion in rescue loans for Ireland. But concerns remain for other European countries, including Portugal and Spain.According to estimates from the National Retail Federation trade group, some 212 million shoppers visited U.S. stores and websites during the first weekend of the holiday season, up from 195 million last year.While online retailers look for continued strong results on Cyber Monday, experts warn that sales could be hurt by e-commerce promotions earlier in the holiday shopping season.The retail results come amid improving U.S. consumer sentiment. The Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer confidence index showed sentiment improving more than expected in November. The index reached its highest level in five months.Top-rated stocks slated to report quarterly earnings results later this week include OmniVision Technologies (OVTI), Semtech (SMTC),  VeriFone (PAY) and Ulta Salon (ULTA).Economic reports on the docket this week include the monthly jobs report, due out Friday, and the Institute for Supply Management's readings of the manufacturing and services industries, also due Friday.In commodities news, oil prices rose to nearly $85 a barrel. Crude was trading slightly above $67 a barrel just six months ago.

Stocks rose Friday, but closed off their session highs. The market got a lift from a solid jobs report and relief over Greece's bond swap, but pulled back in the wake of news that the swap counts as a "credit event," or basically a default.The Nasdaq tacked on 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.1%. Volume declined from Thursday's levels on both main exchanges, taking some punch out of the move higher.After the close, shares of Michael Kors (KORS) plunged. The company announced a secondary stock offering. The luxury apparel company had just hit a new high in regular trading as it continued a heated advance.For the week, the Nasdaq rose 0.4%, while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1%. Each index advanced for a fourth straight week, fighting back from sizable losses suffered earlier in the week. The Dow lost 0.4% for the week.Economic news mostly was positive Friday. The government jobs report for February showed better-than-expected growth, with nonfarm payrolls increasing by 227,000 and the unemployment rate staying at 8.3%. On the downside, payrolls are still 5.3 million below the January 2008 peak and the U.S. trade deficit widened for a third straight month.In the late afternoon Friday, the International Swaps and Derivatives Association said Greece's bond swap counts as a "credit event," meaning holders of credit default swaps likely will be entitled to compensation estimated at $3.2 billion. Analysts have said the ISDA's announcement was expected and the amount is less than feared.Among IBD 50 stocks on Friday, Sourcefire (FIRE) gained 5% in above-average volume and touched a new all-time high. The maker of security software and hardware climbed back above a 46.39 buy point from a short-stroke pattern that it first cleared Monday. It closed 4% beyond 46.39, leaving it near the upper limit of a possible buy zone.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), another IBD 50 name, reversed from a high and finished about flat Friday. The stock was up as much as 3% in reaction to its better-than-expected Q4 results, out late Thursday. Ulta's earnings and sales grew 52% and 23%, respectively. Despite the reversal, it's still well extended past a 75.80 buy point from a cup-shaped consolidation.Starbucks (SBUX) jumped 3% in big turnover, helped by the company's plans to sell single-serve coffee makers. The company, which announced the plan late Thursday, has hit an all-time high and is now well extended past a buying range after lifting off support at its 10-week moving average. Starbucks sports an IBD Composite Rating of 96, near the best-possible grade of 99.  Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), which makes the Keurig single-serve brewers, plunged 16% Friday on the news.On Monday, Clean Energy Fuels (CLNE) is among the companies expected to report quarterly earnings. The day's economic news will include the Treasury's monthly account of the surplus or deficit for the federal government.

regular session, shares hit a new high, closing up 1.5% to 89.27.***Posted 03/06/2012 11:37 AM ETUlta Beauty (ULTA) has carved out a lucrative niche as the largest beauty products retailer that provides a one-stop shop for prestige, mass-market and salon products in the U.S.Ulta reported on Dec. 1 that third-quarter profit soared 68% to 42 cents a share. Sales climbed 22% to $413.1 million.Wall Street is expecting lighter results when the beauty chain reports fourth-quarter results Thu.Analyst consensus is for fourth-quarter earnings per share to rise 42% vs. the same quarter a year earlier, to 68 cents. That would be below the first three quarters of 2011, when EPS rose 61%, 52% and 68%, respectively.But Ulta Beauty's beaten the Street's forecast for profit and revenue growth the last four quarters in a row, so its fourth-quarter results could come in higher than estimates.Its stock price has risen about 80% from a low of 48.28 on Aug. 26 to above 87. From its recession bottom of 5.77 on Jan. 30, 2009, it's advanced 1,410%.Others in the beauty supplies group have benefited as well from rising consumer spending. Rival Sally Beauty (SBH), for example, has nearly doubled from a low of 14.88 on Aug. 19 to above 24. It's up about 800% from its recession low of 2.66.During third-quarter 2011, Ulta Beauty added 7 new stores, bringing its 2011 new-store total to 28, a 16% increase in square footage. The company is projecting bigger growth this year."Based on the quality and strength of our new store pipeline we expect to accelerate our 2012 square footage expansion to the high end of our long-term 15%-to-20% growth range," Chief Executive Chuck Rubin said in a Dec. 1 statement.On Jan. 5, Ulta announced holiday results, with sales for the seven-week period from mid-November to the end of December growing 24.4% to $386 million."We delivered an excellent holiday season," Rubin said then, "with comparable store sales growth of 12.6% balanced across categories and brands, continuing our strong momentum from the first nine months of the year."Based on that, the company raised its fourth-quarter outlook.Ulta Beauty now expects first-quarter EPS of 67-68 cents, in line with analysts estimates, up from its prior view of 62-64 cents.It looks for revenue in the range of $574 million to $579 million, up from its earlier range of $552 million to $562 million. The midpoint of the new guidance is below analysts' projection of $579 million.Ulta Beauty is No. 5 on this week's IBD 50 list of superior stocks, along with Lululemon Athletica (LULUSBH), Michael Kors (KORS) and Apple (AAPL)

Austerity-weary consumers are likely to spend more this holiday season on food and wine for celebrating at home. They're also likely to splurge on cosmetics for themselves, and just about anything Fido wants.

The data from consumer tracker Nielsen point to potential splurge shopping from consumers this November and December, which could boost sales for a range of retailers, from giant Wal-Mart Stores (WMT), salon shop Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and pet retailer PetSmart (PETM).

Households expect to spent 2.3% more this year across five major consumables categories, including beverages, food and household goods. The survey — Nielsen's first holiday forecast of food and household goods — point to more impulse buying, with fewer customers planning to use shopping lists.

"With nearly a quarter of consumers indicating they have already started their holiday shopping by mid-September, I expect 'pragmatic enthusiasm' to inch spending levels higher than last year," James Russo, Nielsen's vice president for global consumer insights, said in a statement.
Nielsen collected data from more than 25,000 U.S. households in mid-September for the report released Thursday.
Among the findings:

Wine sales are likely to lead the alcoholic beverage category, with a 6% dollar and unit growth. Fresh produce sales are expected to climb 4.6% by dollar, and 3.7% by unit, signalling more health-conscious consumers and more home holiday cooking.
Vitamins are expected to be up 9% by dollar, with cosmetics spending up 4.8%.
In the home-care category, pet spending is expected to see the biggest gain, with a 5.9% boost.

There's also room for upside surprises for retailers, the firm says. It notes its consumer confidence measure is at the highest level since before the recession. And while households say they plan to spend the same amount as last year, there is a drop in the number expecting to spend less. There's a smaller drop in those expecting to spend more.
Overall consumers expect to spend $250 to $500 on gifts and holiday spending this year, with online retailers, gift cards and tech products positioned to do well, Nielsen found.

On Wednesday warehouse bulk retailer Costco Wholesale (COST) posted stronger strong-than-expected fiscal Q4 numbers, while Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer, was upbeat about its prospects this holiday season and promised faster rollout of its smaller format stores.
At the same time, Wal-Mart is rolling out same-day delivery as it works to stave off competition from online giant Amazon.com (AMZN).

Amazon and other e-commerce giants look to continue to outpace overall holiday retail sales growth.Austerity-weary consumers are likely to spend more this holiday season on food and wine for celebrating at home. Chuck Rubin had a tough act to follow when he took the helm of Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance from longtime CEO Lyn Kirby a year ago. But the message from Thursday's financial report was clear: so far, so good.

Ulta (ULTA) blew out analysts' expectations with sales of $394.6 million, up 23% from a year ago, with profit climbing 73% to 38 cents a share. Especially, notable was same-store sales growth of 11.3%, which most analysts had expected to slow down after five quarters in double digits.

The results showed the continued traction of Kirby's original concept of creating a chain of beauty "superstores" in off-mall locations, where women could get a haircut, try on makeup and peruse a wide selection of grooming products in one place.

"We believe our consistent performance results from our compelling store experience; expansive and sought-after selection of brands, products and services; our knowledgeable and friendly associates; and our disciplined approach to managing our business," Rubin summarized in the conference call with analysts.
In-Store Boutiques

Rubin also confirmed that Ulta has been testing new in-store boutiques with Lancome, the venerable upscale cosmetics brand. William Blair analyst Daniel Hofkin had published a note earlier this week saying he'd discovered this at one of the 28 stores now carrying Lancome. He tells IBD that the relationship is a significant step in Ulta's plan to get more "prestige" brands into its stores, which get their competitive edge partly by bringing together products at a variety of price points.

"It's really the company's first iconic prestige brand presence," Hofkin said. "If they got it more broadly across the store base — and I think they will over time — it would tend to increase the likelihood they would get additional brands. It's kind of a tipping point."
The company also announced a new partnership with magazine publisher Conde Nast.
Ulta customers get a special $21 annual subscription to both Allure and Glamour magazines, while Ulta will use the magazines' editorial content on its website and in stores.
"I think (the partnership) has a lot of places it can go," Rubin said on the conference call. "Conde Nast has a subscriber base which is very attractive for us to work with them on."

The second quarter also saw the rollout of new in-store boutiques devoted to men's products in most of Ulta's 415 stores. The boutiques feature Procter & Gamble's (PG) Art of Shaving line, as well as razors, colognes and hair-care products.

When Ulta announced the plan June 28, it said this was aimed mainly at women shopping for men, so it isn't expected to bring in hordes of new customers. But it's part of the company's continuous tweaking to make its format more user-friendly.

"There's not necessarily a lot of new product, but it's all aggregated in the boutique," said analyst Hofkin. "They had been scattered throughout the store based on the category. Now it's dedicated, and I think it looks very sharp."

Ulta opened 21 new stores in the quarter, reflecting a resumption of its usual pace after a recessionary slowdown last year. Rubin has said the company is shooting for 1,000 stores by the end of the decade, which means an annual square-footage increase of 15% to 20%. Its plan for this year is to open a total of 61 new stores.

Ulta is still a relatively new presence in many of its markets, so the company is constantly coming up with marketing schemes to raise brand awareness. In May, the company threw a "Love Your Hair" event in its stores, which every week demonstrated products and techniques for a different hair type. Rubin noted that this proved more successful than earlier efforts that focused only on products.
Next month, Ulta will throw a one-day Salon Cut-a-Thon to raise funds for breast-cancer research — and also, it hopes, attract new customers.

The company also makes quite a bit of hay out of its customer-loyalty program, which now has a database of 8.5 million active members who receive various discounts and promos. Rubin says a new initiative this month will start sending customers "refill reminders" on frequently purchased products.
E-Commerce Business
Management is looking to ramp up its still-nascent e-commerce business, partly through a general IT upgrade. But the focus remains on the brick-and-mortar stores, which show no signs of slowing down.
Jefferies analyst Randal Konik says the only competitive threat on the horizon seems to be revitalized department stores.
"Macy's (M) has done a good job of upping the sophistication of its beauty counters," he said. "That could pose a threat from a market-share standpoint. But it's too early to tell."

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters currently expect 41% profit growth this year to $1.64, followed by annual growth in the mid-20s out into the foreseeable future. But in its quarterly report management guided above views, and Hofkin has added 10 cents a share to both his 2011 and 2012 estimates.Chuck Rubin had a tough act to follow when he took the helm of Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance from longtime CEO Lyn Kirby a year ago. But the message from Thursday's financial report was clear: so far, so good.Ulta (ULTA) blew out analysts' expectations with sales of $394.6 million, up 23% from a year ago, with profit climbing 73% to 38 cents a share. Especially, notable was same-store sales growth of 11.3%, which most analysts had expected to slow down after five quarters in double digits.The results showed the continued traction of Kirby's original concept of creating a chain of beauty "superstores" in off-mall locations, where women could get a haircut, try on makeup and peruse a wide selection of grooming products in one place."We believe our consistent performance results from our compelling store experience; expansive and sought-after selection of brands, products and services; our knowledgeable and friendly associates; and our disciplined approach to managing our business," Rubin summarized in the conference call with analysts.In-Store BoutiquesRubin also confirmed that Ulta has been testing new in-store boutiques with Lancome, the venerable upscale cosmetics brand. William Blair analyst Daniel Hofkin had published a note earlier this week saying he'd discovered this at one of the 28 stores now carrying Lancome. He tells IBD that the relationship is a significant step in Ulta's plan to get more "prestige" brands into its stores, which get their competitive edge partly by bringing together products at a variety of price points."It's really the company's first iconic prestige brand presence," Hofkin said. "If they got it more broadly across the store base — and I think they will over time — it would tend to increase the likelihood they would get additional brands. It's kind of a tipping point."The company also announced a new partnership with magazine publisher Conde Nast.Ulta customers get a special $21 annual subscription to both Allure and Glamour magazines, while Ulta will use the magazines' editorial content on its website and in stores."I think (the partnership) has a lot of places it can go," Rubin said on the conference call. "Conde Nast has a subscriber base which is very attractive for us to work with them on."The second quarter also saw the rollout of new in-store boutiques devoted to men's products in most of Ulta's 415 stores. The boutiques feature Procter & Gamble's (PG) Art of Shaving line, as well as razors, colognes and hair-care products.When Ulta announced the plan June 28, it said this was aimed mainly at women shopping for men, so it isn't expected to bring in hordes of new customers. But it's part of the company's continuous tweaking to make its format more user-friendly."There's not necessarily a lot of new product, but it's all aggregated in the boutique," said analyst Hofkin. "They had been scattered throughout the store based on the category. Now it's dedicated, and I think it looks very sharp."Ulta opened 21 new stores in the quarter, reflecting a resumption of its usual pace after a recessionary slowdown last year. Rubin has said the company is shooting for 1,000 stores by the end of the decade, which means an annual square-footage increase of 15% to 20%. Its plan for this year is to open a total of 61 new stores.Ulta is still a relatively new presence in many of its markets, so the company is constantly coming up with marketing schemes to raise brand awareness. In May, the company threw a "Love Your Hair" event in its stores, which every week demonstrated products and techniques for a different hair type. Rubin noted that this proved more successful than earlier efforts that focused only on products.Next month, Ulta will throw a one-day Salon Cut-a-Thon to raise funds for breast-cancer research — and also, it hopes, attract new customers.The company also makes quite a bit of hay out of its customer-loyalty program, which now has a database of 8.5 million active members who receive various discounts and promos. Rubin says a new initiative this month will start sending customers "refill reminders" on frequently purchased products.E-Commerce BusinessManagement is looking to ramp up its still-nascent e-commerce business, partly through a general IT upgrade. But the focus remains on the brick-and-mortar stores, which show no signs of slowing down.Jefferies analyst Randal Konik says the only competitive threat on the horizon seems to be revitalized department stores."Macy's (M) has done a good job of upping the sophistication of its beauty counters," he said. "That could pose a threat from a market-share standpoint. But it's too early to tell."Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters currently expect 41% profit growth this year to $1.64, followed by annual growth in the mid-20s out into the foreseeable future. But in its quarterly report management guided above views, and Hofkin has added 10 cents a share to both his 2011 and 2012 estimates.

Consumer spending rose in July despite high unemployment and economic uncertainty in Europe. U.S. shoppers are ready to open their wallets again to buy new clothing and beauty products, recent results suggest. Designer brand Michael Kors (KORS), big in handbags, posted strong Q1 earnings in mid-August, and the Gap (GPS) said August same-store sales rose 9%.

Francesca's (FRAN), No. 1 on the IBD 50 list, operates small boutique-style stores across the U.S. The apparel retailer stays up to the minute with fashion, and only buys merchandise for delivery no more than 90 days out to ensure the styles are fresh.
Analysts are expecting Francesca's to report a 60% jump in second-quarter earnings to 24 cents per share when it reports Tuesday. Sales are seen rising 38.8% to $71.09 million.
Francesca's debuted in July 2011. It closed at a new high of 36.28 on Aug. 29.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA), an operator of one-stop beauty supply shops, is ranked No. 19 on the IBD 50 list. Ulta offers both bargain items like Herbal Essences shampoo that can be found at local drugstores and high-end products — prestige brands like Redken hair care products — only offered at department stores and salons.
Ulta owes some of its success to the prestige-brand spending. According to the NPD group, high-end brand spending on beauty products rose 11% to $9.5 billion in 2011.
Analysts are expecting Ulta to report a 34% rise in EPS to 51 cents when it reports earnings on Thursday. Wall Street sees sales climbing 20% to $473.8 million.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) will report earnings on Friday. Shares of the Canadian yoga and athletic gear retailer fell sharply in late June on speculation that notorious short-seller David Einhorn had taken a short position on the company. The stock tumbled again in early August but has been on the uptick since, crossing its 50-day moving average in mid-August.
Analysts are expecting Lulu to report a 19% rise in EPS to 31 cents. Sales are seen rising 32.9% to $282.26 million.

The market had erased most losses in late trading Thursday, as retail and cosmetics stocks took the spotlight.
The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were practically unchanged while the NYSE composite was down 0.1%. Volume was higher on the NYSE, lower on the Nasdaq.
Better-than-expected January sales sent the retail sector higher. The SPDR S&P Retail (XRT) ETF was up 2.5%, the best performance among sectors.
Retail accounted for 14 of the top 20 gains among industry groups. Still, the percentage of declining industries was 62%, up from about half of IBD's 197 industry groups down earlier in the session.
The No. 3-ranked Telecom-Fiber Optic group took the worst hit, dragged lower as Alliance Fiber Optic  (AFOP), one of the group's top stocks, sold off 22% in huge trade.

NetLogic Microsystems (NETL) was up 9%, though it had been up as much as 14% earlier after a strong earnings report late Wednesday. NetLogic, which makes processors for networking equipment, plunged on Jan. 20 but found support at its 50-day line.
Cosmetics stocks rallied after Estee Lauder (EL) and Elizabeth Arden (RDEN) topped earnings expectations and raised fiscal year forecasts.

Estee Lauder soared 12% as it bounced off support at the 50-day moving average. Despite strong profit growth lately, its sales gains ranged from 9% to 14%. Elizabeth Arden was up 6% but off the day's best level. The stock is extended after clearing an undefined pattern in mid-December.

Ulta Salon & Cosmetics (ULTA) climbed 6% to a new high after Rival Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) also beat expectations. Stock futures tracked higher Monday as the dollar slipped and commodities rebounded following last week’s steep sell off.
Dow futures climbed 32 points in the pre-market. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 10.5 points and S&P 500 futures gained 5.6 points.
The dollar gave up ground vs. the euro. Oil rose more than 3% after a tough week last week, but held below $100 a barrel. Gold climbed back above $1,500 an ounce, while silver jumped 5%.

On the corporate front, McDonald's (MCD) climbed more than 1% in the pre-market after reporting a 6% rise in April same-store-sales, helped by strong results from the fast-food chain's new McCafe line. Same-store sales rose 4% in the U.S. and 6.5% in Europe, Asia/Pacific, Middle East and Africa. McDonald's shares are shaping a five-month saucer base.

BroadSoft (BSFT) popped 8% ahead of the open after reporting first quarter earnings of 18 cents a share, up from an 8-cent loss the prior year and 6 cents above views. Revenue jumped 70% to $29.7 million vs. views for $28.6 million.

BroadSoft, a developer of voice-over-Internet-protocol software, set Q2 guidance at the high end of expectations and lifted revenue guidance above consensus views. The stock has vaulted 380% since its initial offering last June. It has corrected 31% since March, showing strong accumulation as it works to hold support at its 10-week moving average.
Ulta Salon Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) rose 5% before the bell. Shares of the beauty supplies chain have climbed in nine of the past ten weeks. The stock ended Friday in a three weeks tight pattern.

The market caught its breath last week, but this didn't stop some top-rated stocks from breaking out and gliding higher.When high-quality stocks move higher even when the major indexes are not, it's a positive divergence. Funds are deploying capital with an aim to increase their returns.This is encouraging during the twilight of summer, when trading volume tends to be light.Meanwhile, other members of the IBD 50 are building new bases after making strong rallies in the past. They include Web.com Group (WWWW), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Ancestry.com (ACOM). All three went public in 2005 or later.The pattern of breaking out, rising sharply, correcting and building a new base is a common cycle during a market uptrend.The latest breakouts are originating from solid growth sectors.Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), which broke out on Aug. 17 and finished the week up 11%, added just 1.1% last week. Yet the women's apparel and accessories chain also struck new highs and is now just slightly extended 6% past a 32.69 entry point.The 32.69 buy point is calculated by adding a dime to the highest price within a downward-slanting handle formed by the stock from July 18 through Aug. 2.The stock attempted a breakout on Aug. 7, briefly moving past 32.69, but faded lower in dull trade. Such action does not change the buy point.Cubist Pharmaceuticals (CBST), which ranked No. 49 in Wednesday's list, jumped past a 44.67 cup-with-handle buy point with a 5.6% weekly gain, the biggest among IBD 50 stocks last week.At 45.65, the stock is 2% above the proper entry. Investors should not chase a stock more than 5% beyond the proper buy point.Cubist's earnings shrank 4% in 2011, but have picked up 5%, 52% and 28% in the past three quarters. The specialist in anti-infective medicines has logged solid double-digit revenue growth for seven years in a row.Ulta, which has changed the way women shop for cosmetics and other beauty products, has certainly built a later-stage base. Such bases have a much higher rate of failure. But Ulta's gain since breaching its high of 35.63 first marked in late 2007 is not excessive.The three-year EPS growth rate is 71%. Analysts see Ulta growing fiscal 2013 profit 34% to $2.55 a share.

Stocks extended losses after the Fed beige book noted slowing growth in four of 12 regions.The Nasdaq was down 0.9%, the NYSE composite and S&P 500 0.6%. Turnover was again tracking sharply higher across the board.Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP) fell 4% and sliced its 50-day moving average in brisk trade. The stock had been consolidating in quiet trade. Endo has fallen back to levels from its late March breakout.Open Text (OTEX) lost 2% and breached its 50-day line in heavy volume. The line has provided support in recent months. Open Text is working on a possible base-on-base pattern.On the upside, Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) was off its session peak but still up 9% in active trading. Late Tuesday, the beauty supply retailer beat views with a 61% rise in Q1 earnings and a 21% gain in sales. It also guided Q2 results ahead of expectations. The stock gapped above its 50-day line at the open.Ultratech (UTEK) erased earlier losses and rose more than 1% in brisk trade. Despite recent volatility, the stock has managed to hold above its 10-week moving average. It's also had more signs of accumulation than distribution. The chip equipment maker delivered triple-digit earnings growth in three of the past four quarters.

Stocks were narrowly mixed early Friday following a report that saw the economy add fewer jobs than expected in August. But the unemployment rate fell slightly. The Nasdaq fell 0.1% as Intel's  (INTC) revenue warning weighed on the technology sector. But the S&P 500 edged up 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average ticked up 0.1%. Volume was sharply…

Stocks tacked on more gains Friday after the Labor Department said the economy lost 54,000 jobs in August, fewer than expected. After weakening when the ISM services index came in below estimates, equities made up most of the lost ground.

Stocks tacked on more gains Friday after the Labor Department said the economy lost 54,000 jobs in August, fewer than expected. After weakening when the ISM services index came in below estimates, equities made up most of the lost ground.

The Nasdaq rallied 1.5% and closed back above its 50-day moving average. It was up 1.6% at session peak. Bellwethers Apple (AAPL), Google (GOOG) and Amazon.com (AMZN) were some of the Nasdaq's biggest gainers.
Meanwhile, the NYSE composite and S&P 500 rose 1.3% each and the Dow gained 1.2%. Volume dipped across the board ahead of the long weekend.
For the week, the NYSE composite and S&P 500 jumped 3.8% each and the Dow climbed 2.9%. The Nasdaq gained 3.7%.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) gapped above its 50-day moving average and soared 18% in nearly five times average trade. The stock cleared a 25.99 buy point from a double-bottom base. Ulta's Relative Strength line hit a new high. Late Thursday, the beauty products retailer delivered Q2 earnings that more than doubled and gave an upbeat outlook for Q3.

Silver Wheaton (SLW) erased early losses and rose 3% to a record high, putting shares 9% past a 21.83 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. Silver Wheaton cleared the handle Aug. 26. The Canadian firm buys purchase agreements from silver-and gold-mining companies. Silver Wheaton has delivered three straight quarters of triple-digit earnings and sales growth.
Silver prices Friday hit their highest level since March 2008.
Aruba Networks (ARUN) climbed nearly 4% and neared a three-year high. The stock now sits 5% past an 18.51 buy point from a square-box base.
Phillips-Van Heusen (PVH) and Pep Boys (PBY) will report earnings Tuesday.
After a heavy week of economic data, only two key reports will be out next week. The Fed's beige book will be out Wednesday, and jobless claims will be released Thursday.
