Stock futures were mixed ahead of Monday's open, with large cap plays from Citigroup to Apple placing pressure on early trade. Dow futures were down 21 points, but still trading above fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 2.75 points lower, while Nasdaq 100 futures held 11.5 points in positive territory. Investors will be watching the stock market today to…
Highly rated vitamin and nutritional supplement retailer Vitamin Shoppe (VSI) is expected to report healthy second-quarter profit and sales gains Tuesday before the market opens.

Wall Street consensus is for the company to record a 24% rise in earnings per share to 51 cents. Revenue is projected to accelerate 12.2% to $242.2 million on rising sales of the chain's more than 18,000 items representing some 400-plus brands.
Vitamin Shoppe sports a 97 Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 97% of all stocks.
Although a 24% increase in profit vs. last year would be the lowest in 10 quarters, it would continue a string of double- or triple-digit gains going back 13 quarters.
In the prior four quarters, the company recorded gains of 38%, 48%, 73% and 30%.

Vitamin Shoppe is in the Retail-Specialty group, ranked No. 41 of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. The group includes larger rival nutrition chain GNC (GNC) and Ulta Salon Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA), the beauty products and services chain. Ulta Salon is No. 23 on the IBD 50 list of top stocks, and GNC ranks No. 8.
Vitamin Shoppe rose a bit more than 1% to 57.03 in afternoon trading Monday. GNC slid 0.7% to 38.95 and Ulta Salon climbed 1.2% to 88.85.
Among other top-performing stocks in the group, beauty supplies retail chain Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) was down a few cents at 26.68 and PetSmart (PETM) fell 6 cents to 67.18.
On June 13, Vitamin Shoppe said it expects comparable store sales growth for the rest of the year to be in the mid-single digit range.

The company will announce results amid a round of management reshuffling. On Monday, it said Stephen Bontempo has joined as vice president of e-commerce, reporting to Chief Marketing Officer Lou Weiss. Bontempo was previously senior VP of e-commerce at Fanatics Inc., a professional sports products retail website.

On June 30, Vitamin Shoppe President and Chief Operating Officer Michael Archbold stepped down from those posts. The company had announced on May 8 that he would be leaving. Stocks traded in mixed territory in early-afternoon action Tuesday, as the Nasdaq dipped into the red. The Dow Jones industrial average fared best with a 0.6% gain, but it had been up 0.9%. The S&P 500 tacked on 0.3%, while the Nasdaq lost 0.3%, giving up its earlier gain of nearly 0.3%. Turnover continued to track lower across the board.…

Stocks kept their footing in afternoon action Tuesday, staying in the upper half of the day's trading range. The Nasdaq was up 0.9%. The NYSE composite and S&P 500 added 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. The NYSE composite regained its 50-day moving average. The other major indexes climbed over that key line on Friday. Volume rose on both major exchanges from…
The major indexes pared earlier gains at midday, in a session of sharply higher trading fueled by quadruple witching.
The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow were up 0.2% each, while the NYSE composite edged up 0.1%. Volume soared, with four kinds of June equity futures and options contracts expiring.

Newmont Mining (NEM) climbed 3% in fast trade, reaching its highest point in more than four years. The gold exploration and production firm's stock is one of many rallying as gold prices surge toward record highs.
OmniVision Technologies (OVTI) added 2% in rapid turnover. The chipmaker's stock, which hit a new high, is up 21% for the month of June.

Ulta Salon (ULTA) advanced 2% in brisk volume. The major indexes rebounded to near session highs in late-afternoon action Thursday.
The NYSE composite leapt 2.9%, the S&P 500 2.4%, and the Dow and Nasdaq 2.2% each. But turnover continued to track slightly lower across the board.

Lululemon Athletica (LULU) motored 5% in triple its normal trade, though it was off its session high. The athletic apparel maker posted first-quarter earnings of 27 cents a share, topping Wall Street's consensus of 21 cents. The company also raised its full-year profit and revenue projections.

Ulta Salon (ULTA) picked up 2% in above-average volume. The beauty-store chain operator is trying to bounce back to its 50-day moving average. Its Accumulation/Distribution has fallen to a poor D+ during the market's correction.

Stericycle (SRCL) also climbed 2% in rapid turnover. The medical waste management stock is closing in on its all-time high, set in September 2008. Major averages were mixed about 3-1/2 hours into Wednesday's session. Blue chips were the bright spot as the Dow Jones industrial average showed a gain of 0.6%.
The Dow was helped by shares of IBM (IBM), which rose 2%. Earlier today, Synnex (SNX) agreed to buy IBM's customer-care outsourcing business for $505 million.

The Nasdaq fell 0.2%, weighed by shares of Apple (AAPL). Shares slumped 5% after UBS downgraded the stock to neutral from buy, citing concerns about its pricing strategy unveiled Tuesday with the release of the latest iPhone.
The S&P 500 added 0.1%.
Preliminary data showed NYSE and Nasdaq volume tracking lower than Tuesday.

In the stock market today, China-based search firm Baidu (BIDU) broke out in heavy volume, rising 5%. The company isn't growing as quickly as it once was, but fundamentals are still decent despite decelerating earnings growth in recent quarters.

Meanwhile, IBD 50 firm Biogen Idec (BIIB) closed in on a potential buy point of 234.84. Shares rose 1%. Expectations are high for its oral multiple sclerosis treatment Tecfidera, recently approved by the Food and Drug Administration. Some analysts say sales of the potential blockbuster drug could hit $4 billion by 2017.

And Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR) continued to hold gains after a breakout during the week ended Aug. 23. Shares rose 1% after KeyBanc raised its price target to 100 from 90 after the company's investor day on Tuesday.

On Thursday, watch for earnings reports from Kroger (KR) and Lululemon Athletica (LULU). Both report before the open. The major averages were slightly lower late Monday afternoon as sales of existing homes fell more than expected. The Nasdaq slipped a fraction while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each fell 0.2%. Volume was down 32% on the NYSE and 10% on the Nasdaq compared to the same time Friday. Netflix (NFLX) jumped 4% to a new…
Stocks added to their gains early Wednesday afternoon on hopes that German and European Union officials will step in to bolster Spain's ailing banks.

The Nasdaq was up 2.1% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.9% each. Volume was higher compared with the same time Tuesday. If the price and volume remain strong into the close, it would mark institutional buying — something the market hasn't seen much of lately.
This week, the major indexes have been battling back, closing near session highs. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 have climbed after touching their 200-day moving averages.
Reuters quoted European sources as saying that German and EU officials discussed a solution for Spain's bank woes. The crisis threatens to take down the eurozone.
Auto auction firm Copart (CPRT) and paint retailer Sherwin-Williams (SHW) were the only two IBD 50 stocks to fall in early afternoon trading. Both were down less than 1%.

Coinstar (CSTR), on the heels of a major partnership with Starbucks (SBUX), gapped up 6% in heavy trading. The stock edged up above its 50-day moving average, where it has met resistance. Starbucks climbed 2% as it tries to form a new base. It has also met resistance at its 50-day line.

Ulta Beauty (ULTA) surged 10% in big volume after a Robert W. Baird analyst raised the stock's price target to 110 from 105. The stock appeared to be breaking out of a base, but the handle is in the lower half of the pattern, and the base itself has formed mainly below the 50-day moving average.

Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) jumped 7% in heavy volume, bouncing off support at its 50-day line, as it works on a new base. The company said paid prescriptions for its lone drug Acthar jumped 61% in April from a year earlier. May prescriptions likely soared as much as 80%, it added.

Discount retailer Dollar General (DG) climbed 4% in huge trade, putting it just below a 48.86 buy point in a square-box base. The company said it will sell 30 million common shares in a secondary offering at 46.75. Dollar General won't profit from the sale because the shares are being sold by existing shareholders.
Elsewhere, PetSmart (PETM) rose 3% to a new high. The stock cleared resistance around 59 on May 23 following a strong earnings report.

But mattress makers tumbled after Tempur-Pedic (TPX) warned of a steep decline in second-quarter earnings. The company cited increasing competition in North America. Its shares plunged 48%, undercutting the August 2010 low.

Select Comfort (SCSS) slid 14%, paring an earlier 18% loss, as it knifed below its 200-day line. Mattress Firm (MFRM) plummeted 15%. The shares started crumbling after the close Tuesday, when the company's quarterly revenue missed estimates and management gave a disappointing outlook.

Stocks advanced Thursday as two indexes continued to find support at recent battleground areas. The Nasdaq took the smallest step, rising 0.6%. The S&P 500 and the NYSE composite gained 1.1% and 1%, respectively. The IBD 50 added 0.7%. Volume rose on both major exchanges. The S&P 500 appears to have established support above the 1300 area after knifing above…

Stocks ended slightly higher in lower volume Friday, a muted reaction to what analysts say was a mostly disappointing jobs report. The S&P 500 rose 0.4%. The Dow Jones industrial average added 0.1% and the Nasdaq posted a fractional gain, as both were weighed down by one high-profile tech-stock decline. Volume fell from Thursday's level on both major exchanges, according…

The major indexes showed some pluck Thursday, as they closed with modest gains after spending most of the day in negative territory. The market appeared to shrug off news of increasing violence in Egypt that in the morning had overshadowed some encouraging U.S. economic reports.

The major indexes showed some pluck Thursday, as they closed with modest gains after spending most of the day in negative territory. The market appeared to shrug off news of increasing violence in Egypt that in the morning had overshadowed some encouraging U.S. economic reports.
Want To Hear IBD's Analysis Of Today's Market And Emerging Stocks?Click here to watch the Market Wrap video!
The Nasdaq composite, NYSE composite and S&P 500 all finished up 0.2%. Volume fell from Wednesday's levels on the Nasdaq, but rose on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.

Retail stocks fared well, helped by chains reporting strong same-store sales for January. Among top-rated retailers, Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) gained 6% in strong turnover. The specialty retailer has bounced off its 10-week moving average after clearing a 37.34 square-box buy point on Jan. 6. Ulta finished just 2% past the high of 38.25 that it hit just before its pullback, meaning it remains in a possible buying range.

After hours, JDS Uniphase (JDSU) surged as it posted adjusted Q2 EPS of 29 cents, crushing views. The stock, which boasts a 97 IBD Composite Rating, is well extended from its last proper buy point of 13.10. One new driver for the company is its role as a parts supplier for sensor technology used in Microsoft's (MSFT) Kinect motion-gaming system.

Stericycle (SRCL) also gained as it reported earnings after the bell. The medical-waste handler achieved adjusted EPS of 69 cents, beating views. The stock was trading up in thin after-hours action after gaining 1% in the regular session. Stericycle has been consolidating along its 10-week line.

On the downside, Las Vegas Sands (LVS) fell as much as 6% in extended-hours trading in the wake of a quarterly earnings reports issued after the bell. The casino operator posted Q4 EPS of 42 cents, above views. But revenue came in at $2.02 billion, missing expectations. In the regular session, the stock had gained 2% in above-average trade. Sands has been working on a new base since November.
Weekly initial jobless claims fell by 42,000 last week to 415,000, below the consensus estimate of 422,000, while Q4 U.S. productivity grew 2.6%, also beating views.
On Friday, the Labor Department will release its job numbers for January. Health insurer Aetna (AET) is also expected to report its quarterly earnings.

Health insurer Aetna (AET) is also expected to report its quarterly earnings.

Stocks turned mildly lower in midmorning trading Thursday following a choppy open.The Nasdaq was the sole major index that held onto a gain, up nearly 0.1%. The tech-rich index was up 0.3% in the early going. The NYSE composite slipped 0.5% and the S&P 500 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher across the board, much more on the NYSE.MercadoLibre (MELI) cleared a 73.98 buy point in a 14-week cup with handle, rising 4% for its fourth straight gain. Volume was running double its 50-day average volume. JPMorgan Chase reportedly upgraded the stock to overweight from neutral on Monday.The Latin American online marketplace has proven to be one of the fastest growing companies in IBD's database. Earnings per share rose 79%, 136%, 120%, 125% and 76% from year-ago levels in the past five quarters as sales increased 11% to 47% over the same period. However, sales growth has decelerated over the past three quarters, from 47% to 42%, 28% and 11%.MercadoLibre also has a mediocre C- Accumulation/Distribution Rating. Its base has more distribution than accumulation, too.Ulta Salon (ULTA) gapped up at the open and raced as high as 36.66, up 6% before pulling back for a 4% midday gain. The stock had been consolidating its gains for the past four weeks and found key support at its 50-day moving average. Volume was on pace to nearly triple its 50-day average.The retailer of cosmetics also operates a full-service beauty salon within its large stores. Early Thursday, Ulta raised its Q4 EPS guidance. Also, net sales during the seven-week holiday period grew 18% to $310.4 million. Earnings growth of 62%, 188%, 150% and 79% in the past four quarters accentuate its superior 98 Earnings Per Share Rating. The stock has lifted 38% past a 25.99 double-bottom buy point following its Sept. 3 breakout.On the downside, Target (TGT) plunged nearly 6% in huge volume. Its decline over the past three sessions wiped out six weeks' worth of gains. In the week ended Nov. 5, the discount retail giant broke out of a six-month saucer with handle and a 55.38 buy point, then rallied as much as 10%. Target's December same-store sales missed estimates.
Stocks rose in volatile trading Monday, thanks in part to a rebound in the euro. Earlier, the currency fell to a fresh four-year low below $1.19.
The Nasdaq, NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 0.4% each. The Dow gained 0.3%. Volume was tracking higher on the NYSE and lower on the Nasdaq.

ArthroCare (ARTC) rallied 4% in fast trade. On Friday, the stock reversed lower, but found support at its 50-day moving average. ArthroCare is shaping a cup-type base. The surgical device make lost money in the past two years, but is expected to turn a profit of 89 cents a share this year.
Amazon.com (AMZN) gained 3% after being added to Goldman Sachs' conviction buy list. Goldman cited potential for growth in its Chinese business.

On the downside, Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) fell 2% and slipped back under its 50-day line. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has dropped off to C- from B+ in late May.Stocks rose in volatile trading Monday, thanks in part to a rebound in the euro. Leading stocks enjoyed a strong week, as more broke out from consolidations and the IBD 50 index rose 2.6%.Meanwhile, the Nasdaq and S&P 500 both touched multiyear highs, gaining 2.3% and 2.2% for the week, respectively. The NYSE composite tacked on 2.7%, closing 1% off its March peak.Align Technology (ALGN), Biogen Idec (BIIB) and Ulta Beauty (ULTA) were among the IBD 50 names that cleared buy points.Biogen broke out of a five-week flat base Thursday, although volume was below the 40% minimum desired for a breakout.For Ulta, note that the specialty retailer's most recent pattern was a late-stage base, coming after a long advance with no resets.The IBD 50 lineup also features some stocks that are still working on new bases. Familiar name Lululemon Athletica (LULU) matches this description.The seller of high-end athletic clothing has reappeared in the IBD 50 after surging 18% for the week. Most of that move came Friday, as Lululemon popped after a strong earnings report.With its big weekly gain, Lululemon has etched the right side of a new base that's a bit deeper than ideal, as it corrects 36%. Similar to Ulta, Lululemon is also forming a late-stage pattern.Other basing IBD 50 stocks are nutritional supplements seller  GNC Holdings (GNC) and Tibco Software (TIBX).The worst performer among IBD 50 stocks was Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), a women's clothing retailer. It plunged 21% for the week, sliced through its 40-week moving average and dropped out of the IBD 50 lineup.Late Tuesday, Francesca's posted quarterly results that beat views and hiked its guidance, but investors seemed spooked by news that the company's CEO and co-founder is stepping down.Mellanox Technologies (MLNX) was also among the worst performers, as it dropped 3% for the week. The Israeli tech stock had been on pace for a nice gain, but then fell hard Friday.Stifel Nicolaus downgraded the stock to hold from buy on Friday, citing valuation. On top of that, tech heavyweight Intel (INTC) lowered its Q3 revenue outlook, and that appeared to hurt Mellanox, which provides technology for some Intel servers.Even with the past week's slide, Mellanox remains well-extended past its last proper buying range.

The major indexes remained near intraday highs at midday Wednesday, as stocks continued to show strength in a quiet session.The Nasdaq was up 1.9%, the S&P 500 1.3%, the Dow and NYSE composite 1.2% each. Volume fell across the board ahead of the Thanksgiving holiday.TransGlobe Energy (TGA) surged 9% in nearly four times its normal trade. The oil and gas exploration and production firm vaulted to an all-time high. TransGlobe broke out of a low-priced 12-week cup with handle at 7.97 in the week ended Sept. 17, then quickly climbed into double-digit price territory. The stock is also up 59% this month, far extended from a proper buy point. Funds owning shares have grown from 54 in the fourth quarter of 2009 to 84 in the third quarter this year.Skyworks Solutions (SWKS) also marked a new high, gaining 5% in brisk volume. The maker of chips used for broadband communications is one of several chipmakers marking big gains today, with the Philadelphia semiconductor index up 2.6%. Skyworks, which holds a 97 Composite Rating, cleared a base-on-base pattern in mid-September and has had two successful pullbacks to the 10-week moving average.Ulta Salon (ULTA) rose 4% in nearly three times its usual turnover. The stock is up 33% from a 25.99 double-bottom buy point after its breakout on Sept. 3, two days after the major indexes' Sept. 1 follow-through. The beauty store operator's stock reached its highest point in three years and is closing in on all-time high. Ulta has rung up triple-digit earnings growth in the past two quarters.

The major indexes gained strength in late-session trading Tuesday, as techs led a modest rally.The Nasdaq rose 0.5%, the NYSE composite 0.4%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Dow 0.2%. Volume remained higher across the board.Solar stocks continued their recent rally. Jinko Solar (JKS) advanced 3% in more than twice its normal trade. The maker of solar cells and solar modules has rocketed higher since breaking out of a first base July 7. The stock flashed three straight, big down days in heavy volume at the end of last week, but has started this week with two up days in rapid trade.Ulta Salon (ULTA) gained 4% in heavy turnover. The hair care and cosmetics provider, owner of a highest-possible 99 IBD Earnings Per Share Rating, marched to a 52-week high. It broke out of a double bottom on Sept. 3.On the downside, Cliffs Natural Resources (CLF) fell 5% in nearly double its average volume. The iron ore mining company's stock has formed a base dating back to mid-April, and sits 16% off its 52-week peak.

Stock futures signaled a higher open Friday, but they came off their best levels following a mixed jobs report. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 1 point vs. fair value, S&P 500 futures gained 5 points and Dow futures climbed 32 points. The economy added 96,000 jobs in August, missing expectations of 125,000 jobs, the Labor Department said. Employment in the services…

Investors are hoping yoga apparel retailer Lululemon Athletica (LULU) excelled yet again in the third quarter and that the yoga apparel retailer has its shelves fully stocked as it heads into the key holiday season.

Lululemon reports third-quarter numbers Thursday morning. Analysts expect a 39% surge in earnings per share to 25 cents, and a 34% sales boost to $235.9 million. That would be much slower growth than recent quarters, though Lululemon has a history of delivering upside surprises. As is typical this time of year, analysts and investors will be listening for guidance for the key holiday shopping season.
The Canada-based retailer has been stymied for several months by inventory shortages that forced it to spent big to airship in goods — raising costs and leaving future quarters leaner.
William Blair analyst Sharon Zackfia says she thinks the retailer is still playing catchup, though it's better off than it was earlier in the year.

Lululemon's push into the huge U.S. market in recent years has muted some of the worries about slowing growth in its home Canadian market. It's also attempted to diversify beyond stretchy yoga pants and tank tops into running and cycling apparel. It's also trying to appeal more to men. And it's making a bigger online push.
But its core shopper continues to be female athletes. And Zackfia says those customers aren't limited to larger cities.
"It happens to be an underserved market, and it happens to be underserved everywhere," she said.

Lululemon is on this week's IBD 50 list of the very best stocks based on fundamentals and technicals. Another IBD 50 women-focused retailer, Ulta Beauty (ULTA), will report after the close. Analysts expect the chain of salon and beauty supply stores to report a 65% surge in EPS on a 20% bump in revenue. Ulta's growth has held up despite weaker consumer spending at salons, as customers continued to spend on cosmetics, hair care products and other personal items despite a sluggish economy.

Separately, most major retailers, including Macy's (M), Target (TGT) and J.C. Penney (JCP), report November same-store sales figures Thursday morning. That will give investors a good idea of how holiday spending is going for specific chains and overall — and perhaps an idea of what to expect in December.Investors are hoping yoga apparel retailer Lululemon Athletica (LULU) excelled yet again in the third quarter and that the yoga apparel retailer has its shelves fully stocked as it heads into the key holiday season.Lululemon reports third-quarter numbers Thursday morning. With the market now in a correction, more recent breakouts have unraveled. Polaris Industries  (PII) and Randgold Resources  (GOLD) have reached 8% declines from their buy points. Although they've tried to rebound, shareholders should be considering selling to cut losses short. In this uncertain environment, growth investors should adopt a cautious stance; it's defense time. It's smart to cut losses short,…
Stocks continued to slowly regain some of this morning's lost ground.

The Nasdaq climbed 1.3%, still down from 1.6% at its session peak. The S&P 500 gained 1.2%, while the Dow and NYSE composite rose 1.1% each. Turnover was again tracking higher, but the pace has slowed even more ahead of the long weekend.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) bolted 18%, extending session gains. Earlier the stock cleared a 25.99 buy point from a double-bottom base. Late Thursday, the beauty products maker delivered Q2 earnings that more than doubled and gave an upbeat outlook for Q3.

Acme Packet (APKT) added 2% to a new record high. The stock is on pace for its ninth straight gain. Acme sits 7% past a 33.68 buy point from a rebound off its 10-week moving average. The company makers session border controllers used by communication services providers to deliver data services.

Silver Wheaton (SLW) erased early losses and rose 2% to a new record high. That puts shares 8% past a 21.83 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The Canadian firm buys purchase agreements from silver- and gold-mining companies. It has delivered three straight quarters of triple-digit earnings and sales growth.

Silver hit its highest level since March 2008. Gold fell $3.30 to $1,250 an ounce. It was off by more than $10 during the session. Stocks strengthened after the release of the minutes from the Fed's Aug. 10 meeting. Fed members were concerned about softer economic growth. Several wanted additional stimulus if conditions weakened.The NYSE composite climbed 0.5%, while the Dow and S&P 500 rose 0.4% each. The Nasdaq gained 0.2%. Volume was tracking higher across the board.VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) erased earlier losses and gained 4% to a record high. The stock recently tested its 50-day moving average for the first time since its July 8 breakout. VanceInfo is a Chinese provider of software development and IT services. The company's sales growth accelerated in the latest two quarters.Aruba Networks (ARUN) reversed higher and rallied 5% to its best level since early November 2007. The stock climbed back above an 18.51 buy point from a square-box base. Aruba provides products that enable secure access to data across networks. It has delivered triple-digit profit growth for the past five quarters.Bancolombia (CIB) climbed 5% to a new all-time high. The stock cleared a five-week consolidation.On the downside, Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) fell 2% in heavy trading. The stock has met resistance at its 50-day line in recent sessions. Ulta reports Q2 results after Thursday's close. Analysts are expecting a profit of 18 cents a share on sales of $314.9 million.Elsewhere, December gold settled at $1,250.40 an ounce, up $11.20.

The market caught its breath last week, but this didn't stop some top-rated stocks from breaking out and gliding higher.When high-quality stocks move higher even when the major indexes are not, it's a positive divergence. Funds are deploying capital with an aim to increase their returns.This is encouraging during the twilight of summer, when trading volume tends to be light.Meanwhile, other members of the IBD 50 are building new bases after making strong rallies in the past. They include Web.com Group (WWWW), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Ancestry.com (ACOM). All three went public in 2005 or later.The pattern of breaking out, rising sharply, correcting and building a new base is a common cycle during a market uptrend.The latest breakouts are originating from solid growth sectors.Francesca's Holdings (FRAN), which broke out on Aug. 17 and finished the week up 11%, added just 1.1% last week. Yet the women's apparel and accessories chain also struck new highs and is now just slightly extended 6% past a 32.69 entry point.The 32.69 buy point is calculated by adding a dime to the highest price within a downward-slanting handle formed by the stock from July 18 through Aug. 2.The stock attempted a breakout on Aug. 7, briefly moving past 32.69, but faded lower in dull trade. Such action does not change the buy point.Cubist Pharmaceuticals (CBST), which ranked No. 49 in Wednesday's list, jumped past a 44.67 cup-with-handle buy point with a 5.6% weekly gain, the biggest among IBD 50 stocks last week.At 45.65, the stock is 2% above the proper entry. Investors should not chase a stock more than 5% beyond the proper buy point.Cubist's earnings shrank 4% in 2011, but have picked up 5%, 52% and 28% in the past three quarters. The specialist in anti-infective medicines has logged solid double-digit revenue growth for seven years in a row.Ulta, which has changed the way women shop for cosmetics and other beauty products, has certainly built a later-stage base. Such bases have a much higher rate of failure. But Ulta's gain since breaching its high of 35.63 first marked in late 2007 is not excessive.The three-year EPS growth rate is 71%. Analysts see Ulta growing fiscal 2013 profit 34% to $2.55 a share.
Trying isn't good enough in the world of breakouts, but such action could be worth watching.
Ideally you want to see a stock rush past the buy point in strong volume. But sometimes a stock will dillydally near the buy point. Occasionally such stocks eventually find courage and take off.
Two stocks that appeared recently in the Stocks In The News screen are in the dillydally phase.

Avago Technologies (AVGO) has been trying to clear a 19.65 buy point in a base-on-base pattern. On March 3, it peeked above the buy point in tame volume and then closed below that level. It did it again on Friday and Tuesday. On Wednesday it cleared the buy point in slow trade.

The August 2009 initial public offering has made a habit of odd action. After its IPO, it formed a cup base with a low handle. Low handles are prone to failure, but this one had modest success. It rose 13% before correcting again.

The Singapore-based maker of analog semiconductor devices originally was part of Hewlett-Packard (HPQ). Its earnings grew 125% in fiscal Q1 ended in January and sales rose 24%. That ended four quarters of declining sales.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) has flirted with a 21.72 buy point in recent sessions. It too peeked over the buy point and then retreated. Ulta is nine weeks into a cup-without-handle pattern.
The October 2007 IPO increased earnings 67% and 56% in the past two quarters. Sales advanced 10% and 11% vs. the year-ago periods.

Ulta will report quarterly results Thursday. Analysts expect a 43% EPS pop, to 30 cents a share, and a 13% gain in sales.Trying isn't good enough in the world of breakouts, but such action could be worth watching.Ideally you want to see a stock rush past the buy point in strong volume. Longtime top-rated stock Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance  (ULTA) is set to report its second-quarter earnings after the close Thursday. Analysts are expecting another solid quarter of growth from the beauty chain, with profit up 45% vs. last year to 32 cents a share, and sales rising 19% to $384.2 million.

Analysts also expect slowing same-store sales growth — which last year benefited from the postrecession rebound — coupled with accelerated new store openings. After an investor meeting last June, Oppenheimer estimated same-store sales growth would be 7.5% while William Blair proposed 8.5%, after five quarters in the double digits. But William Blair also expects the store count to rise 16%, the greatest increase since the recession.
Management has stated its long-term goal is to double the store count to 1,000, with a 15% to 20% annual increase until the end of the decade.

"They've been reaccelerating their store-growth plans in the last year," Jefferies analyst Randal Konik told IBD. "Given where the space is in the strip centers, there's still a pretty wide-open runway for continued raw square-footage expansion."

The company just passed its one-year anniversary with Chuck Rubin as CEO, who took over after Lyn Kirby's 11-year reign. Kirby is widely credited with making Ulta the success it is today, adapting the "superstore" model to the beauty business. It's not surprising, then, that Rubin hasn't done anything to upset the apple cart.
"The business has continued its momentum from before he got there," said Konik. "The company's kind of on autopilot, and he's sitting in the driver's seat."

Ulta Salon is No. 4 on this week's IBD 50 list of top companies. Several retailers are high on that elite grouping.Yoga apparel chain Lululemon Athletica (LULU), which reports earnings Friday, is No. 1Longtime top-rated stock Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance  (ULTA) is set to report its second-quarter earnings after the close Thursday. But investors beat up shares of both leading IBD 50 retailers on somewhat weaker outlooks for the critical holiday fourth quarter. Lululemon continued to be stymied by problems other businesses might envy: too much demand for its $98 yoga pants and $50 tanks and other pricey workout clothing.…

Stock futures pointed higher, but trimmed early gains after October retail sales dipped more than expected. Dow futures were up 40 points, down from a 60 point gain in earlier trading. Nasdaq futures advanced 12.25 points and S&P 500 futures traded 5.1 points higher. Retail sales slumped 0.3% in October, down from an upwardly revised 1.3% gain in September and…
As the market struggled to regain footing, five top-rated IBD 50 stocks posted mixed results and guidance in the last week.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) posted outstanding results Tuesday, driving its shares up 8.4% Wednesday, to a new high of 94.74.

But that was offset as other leaders issued disappointing reports or weak guidance, including popular yoga-themed clothing maker Lululemon Athletica (LULU), contact lens maker Cooper Cos. (COO) and agriculture and construction equipment retailer Titan Machinery (TITN).

Discount retailer Dollar General (DG) held the middle ground. Shares of the operator of about 10,000 stores carrying items mostly priced from $1 to $10 reported earnings per share rose 31%, beating analyst views.
The company raised its 2012 profit outlook 3 cents to $2.68 to $2.78 a share. But the midpoint was below Wall Street's projection of $2.77 a share.
Its stock price fell 3.6% on Tuesday — but has risen nearly 8% since then to a new high Friday afternoon.

Ulta Salon, the fast-growing operator of 389 salon and beauty supply stores, said late Tuesday that first quarter profit jumped 46% to 54 cents a share, a penny over analyst forecasts. Sales rose a better-than-expected 23% to $471 million.
The company also raised its second quarter profit guidance to 49-51 cents per share, ahead of the Street's projection of 48 cents, and boosted its long-term goal for U.S. stores.

Lululemon, which has gained popularity in recent years with its yoga-themed line of clothing and in-store yoga classes, said Thursday that first quarter earnings soared 45.5% vs. the same quarter last year, to 32 cents per share. And sales climbed 53% to $285.7 million.

But when it forecast EPS of just 28-30 cents this quarter, below analyst expectations, investors moved to the sidelines. Shares plunged 8.8% to 63.84 Thursday. Lululemon shares edged lower Friday afternoon.

Cooper late Thursday posted a 10% hike in fiscal second quarter EPS to $1.12, on a 6% sales gain of $344.6 million. But the maker of spherical and specialty contact lenses cut its full-year profit forecast.
Shares fell 3.5% Friday afternoon, after finding support at their 200-day moving average. The stock has suffered five days of heavy volume selling in the last seven sessions.
Titan skidded 22% in massive volume Thursday after the tractor and other farm equipment retailer said that quarterly profit fell more than expected.

Titan earned 36 cents, down from 40 cents a year ago, and 2 cents shy of estimates. Sales picked up 33% to $422 million, above views of $393.7 million. But costs spiked 39%, in part due to business expansion costs and a product mix change.
The company affirmed its fiscal 2013 forecast of $2.55 to $2.75 per share profit, in line with analyst estimates.

Shares rose 3.5% Friday afternoon, regaining a small fraction of Thursday's loss.As the market struggled to regain footing, five top-rated IBD 50 stocks posted mixed results and guidance in the last week.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) posted outstanding results Tuesday, driving its shares up 8.4% Wednesday, to a new high of 94.74.But that was offset as other leaders issued disappointing reports or weak guidance, including popular yoga-themed clothing maker Lululemon Athletica (LULU), contact lens maker Cooper Cos. (COO) and agriculture and construction equipment retailer Titan Machinery (TITN).Discount retailer Dollar General (DG) held the middle ground. Shares of the operator of about 10,000 stores carrying items mostly priced from $1 to $10 reported earnings per share rose 31%, beating analyst views.The company raised its 2012 profit outlook 3 cents to $2.68 to $2.78 a share. But the midpoint was below Wall Street's projection of $2.77 a share.Its stock price fell 3.6% on Tuesday — but has risen nearly 8% since then to a new high Friday afternoon.Ulta Salon, the fast-growing operator of 389 salon and beauty supply stores, said late Tuesday that first quarter profit jumped 46% to 54 cents a share, a penny over analyst forecasts. Sales rose a better-than-expected 23% to $471 million.The company also raised its second quarter profit guidance to 49-51 cents per share, ahead of the Street's projection of 48 cents, and boosted its long-term goal for U.S. stores.Lululemon, which has gained popularity in recent years with its yoga-themed line of clothing and in-store yoga classes, said Thursday that first quarter earnings soared 45.5% vs. the same quarter last year, to 32 cents per share. And sales climbed 53% to $285.7 million.But when it forecast EPS of just 28-30 cents this quarter, below analyst expectations, investors moved to the sidelines. Shares plunged 8.8% to 63.84 Thursday. On the heels of its all-around, better-than-expected results and upwardly-revised outlook, shares of Ulta Salon Cosmetics  (ULTA) are trading higher by about 8.5% with less than an hour left in the session. Technically, Friday's bid puts ULTA shares within striking distance of a breakout to fresh and glamorous all-time-highs from a somewhat irregular-looking base that we're willing to let the other guy deliberate over.

One thing not up for deliberation is ULTA's option action. Trading is concentrated in the surrounding money December 70, 75 and 80 calls as shares trade near 74.35. Volume of 600'ish, 1200 and another 600'ish total for those respective strikes has the appearance of a potentially handsome long butterfly position being traded collectively by the crowd.

Ultimately, ULTA's option liquidity / spread width makes the butterfly an unlikely vehicle for trading if one wishes to enter this type position for fair value, i.e. mid-market price, which is currently pricing the spread for $1.50 per contract. Due to that blemish, we consider it unlikely the fly is responsible for Friday's spied volume. We could always look to dig through the prints for confirmation of that fact, but experience tells us the odds on favorites are unrelated odd lot, outrights and maybe verticals as coincidentally responsible for the beautifully lined up, but likely, rare fly position.

Illustrated above is a reduced ratio of 6 x (12) x 6 long butterflies priced for $1.50. We've removed the typical expiration risk line in an effort to place focus on how the position would shape up from today and into the final week of trade. Due to this important and not-to-be overlooked step, the trader is faced with a mid-market profit of $500 if shares remained in the vicinity of 75 versus the "cover of a magazine" glamorous profit of $2,100 in two weeks' time.

What do you think? The sharp sell-offs at the start of the past week helped turn IBD's market outlook a shade more negative, switching it to "uptrend under pressure."
But the market behaved better as it closed out the week, lifting off weekly lows established Tuesday.
For the week, IBD 50 stocks actually managed to gain a little ground on average, edging up 0.2%.
The main indexes all fell for the week. The NYSE lost 3.2%, the S&P 500 2.5% and the Nasdaq 1.9%.
Quite a few IBD 50 stocks now stand beyond proper buying ranges following breakouts. In other words, they're extended more than 5% beyond their ideal entry points.
That leaves IBD-style investors with less to look at while shopping.
On the plus side, that's an encouraging sign of the overall market's health. You want to see highly rated stocks advancing to new highs and then holding up under pressure.
The extended leaders include Intuitive Surgical (ISRG), Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) and SolarWinds (SWI).

Still, some leaders have stayed in potential buying ranges after breaking out. Take a look at MasterCard (MA) and Tractor Supply (TSCO). Plus there's Ulta Salon (ULTA), which triggered a buy signal with heavy volume Nov. 4 from a late-stage base.
Other IBD 50 issues continue to work on bases. That group includes Accretive Health (AH) and Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD). Each is etching a first-stage pattern after resetting its base count.

During the week, leaders generally didn't fall apart. Herbalife (HLF) tumbled Tuesday and set off IBD's 8% sell rule for investors who bought at its recent 60.10 handle entry. But the stock then staged a solid rebound off its 10-week moving average.
Meanwhile, Hansen Natural (HANS) was the week's best performer among IBD 50 stocks, after being one of the laggards in the week ended Oct. 28.
Late on Nov. 3, the energy drinks maker reported third-quarter earnings per share that missed the Street's forecasts by a penny.

But revenue beat expectations, and several analysts hiked their price targets. That helped the stock lift off its 50-day line Friday and hit a new all-time high. Up volume vs. down volume can be a useful tool in looking at stocks. The up-down volume ratio measures total volume on up days vs. that on down days over the past 50 days. This gauge can point to institutional buying or selling. Several stocks that recently showed up in the Stock Spotlight screen are unusually strong by this measure.…
Stocks logged big gains Wednesday as investors set aside global fears and focused on better-than-expected jobless claims and sentiment data.

The Nasdaq rallied 1.9% and the S&P 500 1.5%. The Dow and NYSE composite gained 1.4% each. Despite the big moves, volume fell sharply across the board.
Some retailers again showed nice gains. The S&P retail index tacked on 2.6% and neared a seven-month high.

Tiffany & Co. (TIF) gapped up and advanced 5% to a record high in about three times average trade. The jewelry retailer beat views with a 39% rise in Q3 earnings and boosted its full-year profit forecast. Tiffany cleared a 52.29 buy point from a cup base Oct. 26 and has gained 17%.
IBD 100 member Coach (COH) rallied 4% to a new high in fast trade, putting it 26% past a 45.07 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern.

Amazon.com (AMZN) gapped up and rallied 5% to a record high. Turnover was 50% above average, marking the stock's first heavy-volume gain in nearly three weeks. Amazon.com recently found support at its 50-day moving average for the first time since its Sept. 20 breakout. The online retailer rose ahead of Black Friday, the traditional start of the holiday shopping season. Citigroup also reiterated a buy rating and a 190 target price.

Ulta Salon (ULTA) gapped up and rose 3% to a new high. The stock cleared a 33.60 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. It had broken out from a double-bottom base Sept. 3. The beauty supplier has delivered triple-digit earnings growth in the past two quarters.

Elsewhere, Ancestry.com (ACOM) erased losses and rose nearly 3% to an all-time high in brisk trade. The stock cleared a 28.46 buy point in a three-weeks-tight pattern. Ancestry.com broke out from a cup base Sept. 20. The company provides family history information. Last month it trounced expectations with a 167% surge in Q3 earnings.

On the downside, OpenTable (OPEN) reversed from a fresh record high and fell 5% in triple average trade. The stock, which had been rebounding off its its 50-day moving average, ended a five-session win streak.
No earnings or economic reports are scheduled for Friday, and the market will close at 1 p.m. EST.

Stock futures built on early gains ahead of Wednesday's open. Dow futures were ahead 76.8 points and climbing. Nasdaq 100 futures traded up 23.7 points. S&P 500 futures rose a strong 7.9 points.

The stock market today is open, but bond traders are observing the Veterans Day holiday. Overseas, markets across Asia posted a tightly mixed session. Stocks in Europe were knocking out healthy gains at midday.

Most government offices are closed, making for a sparse U.S. economic calendar. The Labor Department reports its Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey on Thursday. On Friday, the Commerce Department reports October retail sales, the Labor Department gives its October producer price data, and the University of Michigan delivers an initial reading on November consumer sentiment.
Stock action early Wednesday showed Cisco Systems (CSCO) leading the Dow with a 1% gain. Coal miner Consol Energy (CNX) dropped 8%, the worst premarket loss among S&P 500 stocks.
Belgium's Anheuser-Busch InBev (BUD) was flat after announcing it had agreed to buy U.K.-based brewing peer SABMiller in a $107 billion deal. Miller shares rose nearly 3% on the London Exchange.
JCPenney (JCP) spiked 7% after a third-quarter earnings beat. Macy's (M) dived nearly 9% as its Q3 earnings topped expectations, but revenue and Q4 guidance were weak.

Among leaders, a number of big tech names were in motion, with Facebook (FB), LinkedIn (LNKD) and Alphabet (GOOGL) all leaning higher before the open. Apple (AAPL) showed a fractional premarket loss, following a 3% gap-down loss on Tuesday.

Overall, leading stocks were generally quiet. The clear exception was Horizon Pharma (HZNP), which tanked 17% before the bell. Pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts Holdings (ESRX) announced it had ended relations with Linden Care, claiming the pharmacy dispensed only Horizon Pharma medications and failed to meet its contract distribution agreement.

Express Scripts also said it was investigating other pharmacies tied to Horizon. Horizon shares had been fighting to recover from a steep, three-month sell-off. Express Scripts shares dipped 0.3% in premarket trade.

On the upside, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) briefly flashed a 3% premarket gain, topping both the S&P 500 and the IBD 50 lists, then returned to flat trade. The drug maker and partner Sanofi (SNY) reported positive results from a phase 3 clinical trial of its injectable LDL cholesterol treatment Praluent. Regeneron ended Tuesday 1% above a 557.97 buy point in a double-bottom base.Stock futures built on early gains ahead of Wednesday's open. Dow futures were ahead 76.8 points and climbing. Stocks ended mixed Tuesday as the S&P 500 and Dow rose but the Nasdaq reversed lower, dragging some leaders down with it. The Nasdaq moved from a 0.3% gain to a 0.3% loss. The S&P 500 climbed 0.4%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained 0.6%. Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) sank 6% in frantic trade, sinking that much lower below…
Stocks slipped back and forth between mixed turf and slim gains near midday Tuesday, as the early lift from home prices and international trade data faded.
The Nasdaq defended a 0.2% gain. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were a fraction lower each.

Volume ebbed into even weaker territory, down 17% on the Nasdaq and 24% lower on the NYSE, compared to action at the same time Monday. Gains were relatively narrow on the stock market today, with only a third of the 197 industry groups tracked by IBD moving higher in morning trade.
Specialty enterprise software makers showed the widest gain, boosted by ExactTarget (ET), which soared 52% on news that it would be acquired by Salesforce.com (CRM) for $2.3 billion.

Homebuilders less focused in Western states appeared to be under pressure, after an April home price report from CoreLogic noted the widest national price gains in Nevada, California and Arizona. Pulte Group (PHM), Lennar (LEN) and Meritage Homes (MTH) were all down 2%.
The numbers of losers was about equal to winners on the IBD 50 list, although the downside was seeing larger moves.
U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA) was hardest hit, down 5% after announcing a 10 million share offering by a private shareholder. The slip pushed shares well below their 50-day moving average.
Generac Holdings (GNRC) slumped 3% in heavy trade, driving shares back below a 39.48 cup-with-handle buy point.
Biogen (BIIB) dipped 3% in strong trade, aiming toward a fifth straight daily decline. Shares were 9% off their May 28 high, but still well above their 50-day moving average.

Cosmetics can enhance beauty or try to hide the ugly. Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) reported stunning second-quarter results on Thursday, while Elizabeth Arden (RDEN) and others had trouble overcoming their blemishes. Sally Beauty reported a 35% jump in earnings per share to 35 cents, beating estimates by 3 cents. The beauty products supplier has reported 13 straight quarters of double-digit…

Just like the market, Sector Leaders gave a mixed showing Tuesday. Several managed to score gains, but a few issues saw recent gains dwindle. Apple (AAPL) hit yet another new high. It added 2.13 to 701.91 for its fifth straight gain. Volume dropped off for the second straight session and ended 9% below average. It's now 13% past a 619.97…
The major indexes are poised to close lower for the week again, as the market correction continues.
In this climate, the best you can expect from many leading stocks is that they consolidate calmly or correct modestly.
The Weekly Review lineup offers a few names that are doing just that, such as Endo Pharmaceuticals (ENDP), Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Open Text (OTEX).
They were among the names mentioned in last week's column, and their character hasn't changed much.
Endo is working on a base with a potential handle buy point at 42.89.
The drugmaker sports a highest-possible IBD Composite Rating of 99. Endo is one of the many medical stocks that have dominated the Weekly Review list in recent weeks, as investors get more defensive.

Lululemon is shaping a base as it finds support at its 10-week moving average. The seller of high-end workout gear was hit Thursday by a downgrade from FBR Capital Markets, sending it down to its 10-week line.

Open Text is forming a base with a possible entry at 67.18. The Canadian developer of content management software has a 99 Composite Rating, but it is somewhat thinly traded, with an average daily volume of fewer than 400,000 shares.

Broadly speaking, Your Weekly Review features many consumer-related stocks this week. Personal-care names such as Herbalife (HLF) have a presence. Herbalife, a network marketer of weight loss products, is extended past a proper buying range and near an all-time high.

Other consumer-related stocks in the list are specialty retailer Ulta Salon (ULTA), single-serve king Green Mountain Coffee Roasters (GMCR), discount retailer Ross Stores (ROST) and Polaris Industries (PII), a maker of ATVs and snowmobiles.

Green Mountain and Ross are both extended, while Polaris is consolidating. Stocks were off session highs, but still moderately higher as they rebounded from a recent slide.The NYSE composite and S&P 500 climbed 0.8% each, while the Nasdaq rose 0.4%. They had been up between 0.5% and 0.9%. Turnover was tracking lower across the board.Tempur-Pedic International (TPX) jumped 5% in heavy volume as it bounced back from a six-session slide. The stock had been in a sharp uptrend since late last year, but undercut its 10-week line in heavy trading last week. Tempur-Pedic's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has tumbled to a worst-possible E.Avago Technologies (AVGO) gained 2% in brisk trade. It regained all of Wednesday's loss and then some. The stock is forming a potential base-on-base pattern. Earlier Thursday, the chip designer raised its quarterly dividend by a penny to 9 cents a share. Its board also approved a buyback of up to $15 million.Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) reversed earlier losses and rose 1% in fast trade. The beauty supply retailer surged 13% Wednesday on earnings news. Ulta Salon's sits just off a record high, but its Relative Strength line is already at a new high.Texas Instruments (TXN) bounced back from a two-month low and rose nearly 1% in heavy trading. Late Wednesday, the chip giant lowered its outlook for Q2 earnings and sales due to weak demand from a large customer. Analysts speculate that the customer is Nokia (NOK).

Stocks were again mixed ahead of the 2 p.m. EDT release of minutes from the Sept. 21 Fed meeting. Investors will be searching for clues that point to additional stimulus.Thanks to gains in Amazon.com (AMZN), Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG), the Nasdaq rose 0.2%. The Dow and Nasdaq lost 0.4% each, while the S&P 500 slipped 0.2%. Volume was tracking sharply higher on the Nasdaq and lower on the NYSE.Amtech Systems (ASYS) reversed morning losses and rallied nearly 5% in fast trade. Although it's early in the week, the thinly traded stock could be forming a three-weeks-tight pattern. Amtech produces equipment for solar and semiconductor industries. The company lost 18 cents a share last year, but analysts see it making 81 cents this year.Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) also bounced back from earlier weakness and rose 3% to a near two-year high. That puts the stock 16% past a 25.99 buy point from a double-bottom base. The beauty supply retailer's earnings grew by triple-digits in the past two quarters.Fastenal (FAST) gapped down and dropped 4% despite reporting Q3 results above views. Before the open, the operator of construction supply stores delivered a 59% jump in earnings and 23% gain in sales. Shares were down 6% at session lows. The stock is in a lopsided double-bottom base.MercadoLibre (MELI) gapped down and fell as much as 7% in heavy trading. But the stock has since trimmed its loss to 2%. The stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has dropped off to C from A in late August.Elsewhere, gold dropped $6.50 to $1,347.80 an once as the dollar strengthened.

Stocks pulled back after screaming higher on mostly upbeat economic data.The NYSE composite jumped 2.8%, down from 3.1% at session peak. The S&P 500 rallied 2.7%, the Nasdaq 2.6% and the Dow 2.3%. Turnover continued to track sharply higher on both exchanges.VeriFone Systems (PAY) rallied 7% to a 33-month high despite announcing an acquisition. The provider of electronic payment solutions agreed to buy WAY Systems for $6 million upfront, plus more if certain targets are met. VeriFone bounced off its 10-week line last week.Medicis Pharma (MRX) rose 4% to its best levels since November 2007. That puts shares 7% past a 26.65 buy point from a double-bottom base. Macquarie started coverage of the drugmaker with an outperform rating.Aruba Networks (ARUN) climbed 4% to a near three-year high. The stock cleared an 18.51 buy point from a square-box base Aug. 27 and has gained about 3%. Aruba provides software that enables secure access to data, voice and video applications. Last week, the firm topped views with a 233% surge in fiscal Q4 profit. That marked its fourth straight period of triple-digit growth.On the downside, Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) gapped down, tumbled 7% and sliced its 200-day moving average. The stock had been above its long-term support line since last June. Ulta reports Q2 results after Thursday's close. The retailer is expected to earn 18 cents on sales of $314.9 million.VanceInfo Technologies (VIT) reversed from a new record high and fell 3% in fast trade. The reversal erased the bulk of Tuesday's move. VanceInfo recently found support at its 10-week moving average. It cleared a cup-with-handle base July 8.
Stocks held in mixed territory in late-afternoon action Tuesday, as the Nasdaq traded just above its session low.

The Dow Jones industrial average fared best with a 0.5% gain, but it had been up 0.9%. The S&P 500 tacked on 0.2%, while the Nasdaq lost 0.5%, giving up its earlier gain of nearly 0.3%. Turnover continued to track lower across the board.
Among IBD 50 stocks, most issues are now down for the day. Several of these leading stocks are losing ground in heavy turnover.

Apple (AAPL) shed 3% in above-average turnover ahead of its quarterly earnings report after the market's close today. Analysts see EPS up 57% to $10.06 for the company's fiscal second quarter, with sales rising 49% to $36.81 billion. The stock has dropped below its 50-day moving average.

On Monday, Apple also spent much of the session below that key support level, but then managed to regain it by the close. The tech giant, which is trading about 12% below its April 10 high, hasn't finished under its 50-day line since Dec. 19.

Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) also fell ahead of its earnings report after the close, losing 1% in strong volume. First-quarter profit is seen rising 17% to 95 cents a share. Sales are expected to increase 38% to $251.2 million. The restaurant chain, No. 20 in this week's IBD 50, has been consolidating below its 50-day moving average.
Ulta Beauty (ULTA) slumped 6% in huge volume, slicing through its 50-day line. The specialty retailer has been rallying and living above its 50-day since January. It's No. 7 in the IBD 50.

Encouraging earnings news was helping the Dow outperform the other main indexes intraday Tuesday. Among Dow components, AT&T (T) and 3M (MMM) advanced 4% and 2%, respectively, as each blue-chip company reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings.

Also on the earnings front, Netflix (NFLX) plunged 14% in big trade, sinking to its January lows. Late Monday, the streaming video and DVD-rental-by-mail company reported better-than-anticipated quarterly revenue and a narrower-than-expected loss, and management projected that the company would be profitable in Q2. But sales guidance was light and the company's outlook for 200,000 to 800,000 net new subscribers in Q2 disappointed analysts. The former leader continues to wallow below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

Coach (COH) fell nearly 6% in heavy turnover. The handbag and accessories maker reported its fiscal Q3 rose 24% to 77 cents, above expectations. Sales jumped 17% to $1.11 billion, in line with forecasts. But shares appear to be selling off on concerns about slowing North American growth. The stock is in the sixth week of a possible base.

On the upside, Align Technology (ALGN) was up 17% in huge volume following its strong first-quarter results late Monday. The maker of orthodontic products said EPS rose 29% to 27 cents, topping estimates. Revenue also surged a better-than-expected 29% to $135.1 million, and Align lifted its Q2 earnings and revenue guidance above forecasts. The stock has jumped up from support around its 50-day moving average.

The latest economic reports were coming in mixed Tuesday. New-home purchases fell to 328,000 in March, but beat expectations. It's not clear whether Americans are getting healthier or just more competitive. What is clear: The number of participants in competitive sporting events is exploding. Some 507,000 runners finished marathons in the U.S. last year, according to the website Running USA. That's 43% more marathoners finishing races than in 2000. The number of U.S. half-marathons reporting 10,000 or more finishers…

The major stock indexes, taking their cue from the morning's release of a positive monthly jobs report, scored their third straight gain Friday. But volume backed off slightly.The Nasdaq climbed 0.6%, the S&P 500 0.4% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.1%. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 came within spitting distance of their recent highs before backing off.Volume slid on the Nasdaq and on the NYSE, according to preliminary data.Weekly charts show the indexes reversed higher and closed near the top of the Monday-to-Friday trading ranges.Herbalife (HLF) climbed 4% to an all-time high in robust action. Barclays Capital started coverage of the nutritional supplements distributor with an overweight rating. Herbalife is now 9% past a 63.50 buy point from a cup base cleared Feb. 22.Beacon Roofing Supply (BECN) rallied 3% in fast trade and neared a 25.10 buy point in a square-box base. The pattern is forming the second part of a base-on-base pattern. Beacon Roofing cleared a 21.08 trigger from a cup-with-handle base in January.SXC Health Solutions (SXCI) reversed lower from an earlier 5% advance, ending with a minimal gain. Goldman Sachs had upgraded shares to buy from neutral. SXC is extended after bouncing off its 50-day line last month.Michael Kors (KORS) shot up 5% to a new high. The December IPO has hardly taken a breather since coming public in December, but it has yet to form a base. Last month, the luxury apparel and accessory retailer blew past views with an 87% jump in fiscal Q3 earnings and a 68% rise in sales.Spirit Aerosystems (SPR) climbed 2% to a near-52-week high in heavy trading. The stock is following through after clearing a 24.94 buy point from a base Wednesday in more than double its average trade. Spirit Aerosystems cleared a cup-with-handle base in early February.Ulta Beauty (ULTA) reversed from a new high and ended about unchanged. Volume doubled from its normal pace. The stock was up as much as 3% in reaction to late Thursday's better-than-expected Q4 results. Despite the reversal, Ulta is still 18% past a 75.80 buy point from a cup base.Questcor Pharmaceuticals (QCOR) dived 6% in 2-1/2 times its average volume. The drugmaker said February prescriptions of its bread-and-butter Acthar product, a treatment for multiple sclerosis, infantile spasms and nephrotic syndrome, slipped sequentially from January. The stock gapped below its 50-day moving average at the open.
Stocks opened higher Friday after a November jobs report fell short of expectations, but left room for optimism.
The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 added 1.1% each. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 1%. In early trading, volume was lower compared with the same time Thursday.
Financials led the Dow, with Bank of America  (BAC) and JPMorgan (JPM) up more than 3% each.

The addition of 140,000 jobs in November fell short of expectations. But it was in line with the average job growth of about 130,000 in recent months. The average workweek held rock steady at 34.3 hours.

Among leaders in the stock market, Ultra Salon  (ULTA) surged 5% in early trade after reporting late Thursday its third-quarter sales and earnings topped expectations. The stock had fallen more than 8% below a 74.10 buy point, triggering a loss-cutting sell rule. It is now rising from the 10-week line and is just below its buy point.

Spreadtrum Communications  (SPRD) climbed 4% in heavy trade. The China-based maker of chips for mobile communications is rising off its 10-week moving average. The stock cleared a deep cup-with-handle base in October.

Concho Resources  (CXO) jumped 3%, extending a breakout above a 99.57 buy point. The oil producer, focused on Permian basin production in West Texas, doubled its sales growth in each of the past two quarters.
Stocks wavered to a split finish after a round of mixed economic data Tuesday. They also closed the month of August with fat losses.

The Dow and NYSE rose 0.1% each and the S&P 500 edged up a fraction. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq dropped 0.3%. Chip issues stumbled for the second straight session. The Philadelphia semiconductor index lost 1.9%. Deutsche Bank noted slowing demand and downgraded a number of chip equipment makers.
For all of August, the Nasdaq tumbled 6.2%, erasing the bulk of July's gains. The S&P 500 shed 4.7%, Dow 4.3% and NYSE composite 4.2%.
Volume surged across the board from Monday's depressed levels.

Radiant Systems (RADS) reversed opening losses and rallied 7% in more than triple its average volume. The stock has gained 18% since clearing a 15.21 buy point from a handle in a double-bottom base Aug. 6. Radiant makes point-of-sale systems for the hospitality and retail industries. Its sales growth accelerated in recent quarters.

ARM Holdings (ARMH) bucked weakness among chip issues. The stock gapped up and gained 6% to its best levels in more than eight years. It recently tested its 10-week moving average for the first time since its June breakout. ARM makes chips for a number of electronic devices, including Apple's (AAPL) iPhone. Analysts see ARM's earnings jumping 50% this year.

On the downside, IPG Photonics (IPGP) erased early gains and fell nearly 4% in more than twice its average trade. Despite the reversal, the stock still sits 12% past a 19.30 buy point from a cup base. IPG makes lasers for materials processing.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrances (ULTA) also lost nearly 4% in heavy trading. The stock has met resistance at its 50-day line in recent sessions. Ulta's Accumulation/Distribution Rating has dropped to C- from a B+ in late July. The retailer reports Q2 results after Thursday's close. Analysts are expecting a profit of 18 cents a share on sales of $314.9 million.

Stocks dismissed mixed economic data and climbed in a seesaw session Friday. Retail sales unexpectedly fell and business inventories rose less than forecast. But consumer sentiment came in above expectations.

The Nasdaq rallied 1.1% and closed back above its 200-day moving average. Gains lifted by software and data-storage helped the tech-laden index. Meanwhile, the NYSE composite climbed 0.5%. The Dow and S&P 500 gained 0.4% each. Turnover dropped sharply across the board and came in below average.
The Dow snapped a three-week losing streak, gaining 2.8%. The NYSE composite climbed 3.2%, the S&P 500 2.5% and the Nasdaq 1.1%.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics and Fragrances (ULTA) leapt 10%, regaining its 50-day line in more than 10 times average trade. That pushed the stock's Accumulation/Distribution Rating to B+ from D just two sessions ago. There was no news to account for the move.

Salesforce.com (CRM) reversed early losses and rose 4% to a fresh record high. The stock extended its win streak to four sessions. Analysts see the cloud computing firm's full-year earnings rising 43%.
VeriFone Holdings (PAY)climbed 4% on an upgrade and regained its 50-day moving average. Raymond James upgraded the electronic payment services firm to strong buy from outperform.

Treehouse Foods (THS) bounced back from opening losses and rose 2% to a record high, putting the stock 6% past a 47.10 buy point from a three-weeks-tight pattern. Treehouse makes coffee cream, sauces and private-label soups. Its earnings grew between 32% and 61% in the past four quarters.

No economic data will be out Monday, but La-Z-Boy (LZB) will report earnings after the close.Stocks dismissed mixed economic data and climbed in a seesaw session Friday. Stocks erased early losses Friday to end higher for the first time in three days.
Stocks erased early losses Friday to end higher for the first time in three days.

The S&P 500 and NYSE composite climbed 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. Both regained their respective 50-day moving averages, which they'd lost in Thursday's session. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq rose 0.5% but remained under its 50-day line. Volume dropped sharply on both major exchanges.
For the week, the Nasdaq fell 2.5%, the biggest weekly loss in seven months. The NYSE composite fell 2% and the S&P 500 1.3%.

99 Cents Only Stores (NDN) gapped up and leapt 17% after receiving an offer to go private. The discount retailer's founding family and investment firm Leonard Green & Partners LP offered $19.09 a share — a 14% premium to Thursday's close.

Ulta Salon, Cosmetics & Fragrance (ULTA) gapped up and gained 9% in about six times average trade. Late Thursday, the retailer beat estimates with a 38% rise in Q4 earnings and a 20% gain in sales. It also pegged Q1 profit above views. Ulta cleared a square-box base in January and tested its 10-week line in February.

Sina (SINA) rose 3% in slightly above-average trade. It closed slightly below a new high reached intraday. The stock has gained in recent sessions on takeover chatter. Sina operates a Chinese Web portal and Weibo — a microblogging tool.

Sohu.com (SOHU) jumped 6% on a small rise in above-average trade. Still, that marks its first gain in heavy trade in just over a month. The stock is rebounding off its 10-week line after breaking out in February.

On the downside, Zumiez (ZUMZ) skidded 7% in more than twice its average trade. Late Thursday, the action sports apparel and accessories chain reported a 48% rise in Q4 earnings and an 18% gain in sales. Both were above views. But the company expects to break even or lose 3 cents a share in the current quarter vs. views for a profit of a penny a share. Zumiez found support at its 50-day moving average.

Stocks stayed positive but retreated from session highs in late-afternoon action Friday. They had been helped by a solid jobs report and relief over Greece's bond swap, but pulled back on news that Greece's swap counts as a "credit event." The Nasdaq was up 0.5%, the S&P 500 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.1%. Volume continued to track…

Nu Skin Enterprises (NUS) led a trio of beauty-related companies with better-than-expected quarterly results, sending shares higher Thursday.Nu Skin, sells anti-aging and nutritional products, mostly overseas. Fourth-quarter earnings rose 31% to 76 cents a share. Wall Street had expected 72 cents. Revenue rose 23% to $495.3 million, beating analyst forecasts for $480.78 million. Greater China sales shot up 66% to $110.6 million. European sales fell 8% to $38.3 million, as that region struggles.The company sees first-quarter EPS of 68-71 cents on sales of $437 million-$447 million, both better than Wall Street forecasts of 67 cents on revenue of $434.64 million. Nu Skin also raised its full-year 2012 forecasts.Nu Skin, part of the current week's elite IBD list, also hiked its quarterly dividend by 25% to 20 cents a share.Nu Skin shares gapped up to a new high at the open, rising 4.7% to 52.97 as of 9:50 a.m. Eastern. But gains cooled to 1.9% at 2 p.m. Eastern.Meanwhile, Elizabeth Arden (RDEN) reported fiscal second-quarter profit of $1.42 a share, up 18% vs. a year earlier and 3 cents above Wall Street forecasts. The maker of perfume, skin care and cosmetics said revenue rose 6% to $429.9 million, just above forecasts. International sales rose 9.4% while North America sales climbed 4.4%. Gross margins climbed to 50.4% from 47.6%.But Elizabeth Arden's future doesn't smell so good. It sees Q3 sales of $238 million-$243 million on EPS of 0-4 cents. Analysts expect $243.45 mil in revenue and a 6-cent gain. The company warned that "continued global economic uncertainty" may hurt demand.Arden's shares dived at the open, falling 11.4% to 32.75 at 9:50 a.m. Eastern. But shares recovered to edge modestly higher at 2 p.m. ET.Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH) said adjusted first-quarter profit rose 32% to 29 cents — 3 cents better than forecast. That snapped a three-quarter string of decelerating growth. Sales climbed 9% to $864.8 million, also above estimates. Same-store sales rose 7.1%.Sally Beauty shares rose 2% in early morning trade. That picked up to a 4.9% advance in mid-afternoon trade.The retailer operates more than 4,000 beauty supply stores in the U.S. and 10 other countries. Its Sally Beauty stores cater to retail consumers. Its CosmoProf and Armstrong McCall stores sell exclusively to beauty professionals.Meanwhile, Estee Lauder (EL) reports Friday morning. The cosmetics maker is expected to report a 19% EPS gain to $1.06 for its fiscal second quarter after reporting a 45% Q1 profit rise on Nov. 3. Sales should advance 10% to $2.74 billion. Estee Lauder shares were flat in early Thursday trade, but fell 0.9% in mid-afternoon trading.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which combines salon services and a full range of personal care products, isn't expected to report quarterly results until next month. But it's the top-rated stock in the IBD 50. Shares rose about 1% in the early going, near record highs. They fell less than 1% at 2 p.m. ET.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter: @EdCarson1.

Black Friday has come and gone, but holiday gift-buying is just getting started. Many consumer-related companies are on the current IBD 50 list of the very best stocks. Ulta Salon & Cosmetics (ULTA), Lululemon Athletica (LULU) and Dollar Tree (DLTR) are top-rated retailers. Ulta and Lululemon also report quarterly results on Thursday. MasterCard (MA) and Visa (V) will benefit from all those credit- and debit-card transactions.A word of caution. The overall stock market is in a correction and has been dependent on European headlines for the past several weeks.2. Ulta Salon & CosmeticsUlta Salon combines beauty salons with a wide selection of hair care and other beauty products at a variety of price points.Earnings rose 73% in the latest quarter — well above forecasts and the best gain in four quarters. Sales advanced 23%, the best gain in three years.On Dec. 1, analysts expect Ulta to report another quarter of beautiful results: 65% EPS growth to 38 cents on a 20% sales rise to $406.1 million.Ulta Salon's shares have held up well in a rough 2011. They found support at the 200-day line in late August, then at the 50-day in early October and November. But with the major averages falling hard, Ulta has dropped back below the 50-day line. Ulta is a late-stage stock, which means a future breakout is at greater risk of failing.4. MasterCard21. VisaThe kings of plastic don't actually carry credit balances themselves. Instead, issuing banks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM) carry the default risk. Instead, No. 1 Visa and No. 2 MasterCard benefit from fees on transactions, so the more purchases the better.In the latest quarter, MasterCard's earnings per share rose 43% — 17% above forecasts — the best increase in 11 quarters. Revenue growth accelerated for a fourth straight quarter to 27%, the best in more than three years.The larger but slower-growing Visa's enjoyed 20% profit growth on a 13% revenue rise in Q3.MasterCard shares fell nearly 4% last week, but with the major averages falling even worse, their Relative Strength line edged up to record highs. Shares are falling toward their 50-day average, but are still above that level.Visa shares only fell 2% last week, but did fall below their 50-day line.6. Lululemon AthleticaLululemon's athletic apparel remain a trendy gift-buying location for people who can't or won't spend $70 on yoga-inspired pants for themselves.Lululemon has had trouble keeping up with demand all year, which has curbed sales and boosted shipping costs, but made it easier for the Canadian-based retailer to charge full price.In its latest quarterly results, Lululemon said profit shot up 73% to 26 cents while sales gained 39% to $212.3 million. Analysts officially expect slower growth in Thursday's release: a 39% EPS rise to 25 cents on a 234% sales advance to $234.9 million. But Lululemon has consistently beaten EPS views by more than 10%.Lululemon shares have been trending lower since their July 20 peak, falling 6% last week and 18% so far in November. The stock, now below its 200-day moving average, may need to meditate before attempting another advance.15. Dollar TreeThe discounter sells everything for $1 or less. That consistent selling point is appealing to consumers in a tough economy. Beefing up frozen and refrigerated food products has boosted customer trips and purchases.Dollar Tree's Q3 earnings, released Nov. 17, rose 19% to 87 cents a share. It was the 11th straight quarter of double-digit profit growth. Sales rose 12% to $1.6 billion. Both beat profit forecasts.Dollar Tree shares fell below their 50-day line in mid-November. They are trying to move higher again — rising nearly 1% last week — but are meeting resistance at that key level.Dollar Tree is part of IBD's top-rated Retail-Discount & Variety group. Several other value-oriented stores are part of the IBD 50, including Ross Stores (ROST), Dollar General (DG), TJX Cos. (TJX)and Family Dollar (FDO).Check out IBD 50's top 5 cloud computing stocks as well.Follow Ed Carson on Twitter.
